[p_102].description: The clause excludes deposits 'credited or refunded to tenants as disclosed on the Rent Roll.' If a Seller has applied a security deposit to a tenant's past-due rent prior to closing, the Buyer inherits a lease with no security. The Buyer should require the Seller to replenish any security deposits applied to defaults during the escrow period.
[p_102].problematic_text: except for deposits which have been credited or refunded to tenants as disclosed on the Rent Roll
[p_102].title: Exclusion of Applied Security Deposits
[p_102].user_recommendation: Change to: 'except for deposits which have been refunded to tenants in the ordinary course of business and in accordance with the terms of the Leases, provided that if any deposits have been applied by Seller against a tenant default prior to Closing, Seller shall credit Buyer an amount equal to the deposit so applied.'

[p_102].description: While the paragraph allows for post-closing tax adjustments, it does not set a 'cut-off' date. This can lead to indefinite accounting liabilities for the Buyer.
[p_102].problematic_text: any difference in ad valorem taxes for the year of sale actually paid by Buyer shall be adjusted between the parties upon receipt of written evidence of the payment thereof.
[p_102].title: Lack of Time Limit on Tax Re-Proration
[p_102].user_recommendation: Add: 'The provisions of this Section shall survive the Closing for a period of twelve (12) months, after which time all prorations shall be deemed final.'

[p_102].description: Cross-reference the Rent Roll against actual bank statements for security deposit accounts to ensure all 'non-refundable' or 'credited' deposits are legitimate and documented.
[p_102].title: Security Deposit Verification
[p_102].user_recommendation: Cross-reference the Rent Roll against actual bank statements for security deposit accounts to ensure all 'non-refundable' or 'credited' deposits are legitimate and documented.

[p_103].description: Seller reserves the right to collect delinquent rents post-closing. While they cannot evict, they could still sue a tenant. This could damage the Buyer's relationship with a key tenant or trigger a tenant to stop paying current rent to the Buyer in retaliation.
[p_103].problematic_text: Seller reserves the right after Closing to collect delinquent rents from tenants for periods prior to the Closing Date
[p_103].title: Seller's Unrestricted Right to Sue Tenants
[p_103].user_recommendation: Add: '...provided, however, Seller shall not be permitted to commence any legal action or proceeding against any tenant that remains in possession of its premises at the Property without Buyer's prior written consent, which may be withheld in Buyer's sole discretion.'

[p_103].description: Review the aged accounts receivable report 5 days before closing to identify which tenants are delinquent and estimate the potential for Seller interference post-closing.
[p_103].title: Delinquency Audit
[p_103].user_recommendation: Review the aged accounts receivable report 5 days before closing to identify which tenants are delinquent and estimate the potential for Seller interference post-closing.

[p_104].description: The Buyer is made responsible for repaying tenants for over-collections made by the Seller. If the credit received at closing is based on an inaccurate estimate, the Buyer may end up out-of-pocket when the final reconciliation occurs.
[p_104].problematic_text: In either event, Buyer shall be responsible for crediting or repaying those amounts to the appropriate tenants.
[p_104].title: Buyer Liability for Seller's Over-Collections
[p_104].user_recommendation: Add: '...provided that Seller shall indemnify and hold Buyer harmless from any claims by tenants for Operating Expense Pass-throughs attributable to Seller’s period of ownership to the extent such amounts exceed the credits provided to Buyer at Closing.'

[p_105].description: The clause suggests the Buyer must pay the Seller for under-collections only after 'receipt from said tenants.' This is generally safe, but the Buyer should ensure they are not obligated to use 'best efforts' or incur costs to collect the Seller's money.
[p_105].problematic_text: an adjustment will be made between the parties after year-end billing to and receipt from said tenants.
[p_105].title: Buyer as Seller's Collection Agent
[p_105].user_recommendation: Add: 'Buyer shall have no obligation to institute legal proceedings or incur any costs to collect such under-collected amounts for the benefit of Seller.'

[p_105].description: Verify the 'base year' determinations mentioned in the text. If the Seller has incorrectly calculated the base year, the reconciliation will be flawed, potentially leading to tenant disputes.
[p_105].title: Base Year Verification
[p_105].user_recommendation: Verify the 'base year' determinations mentioned in the text. If the Seller has incorrectly calculated the base year, the reconciliation will be flawed, potentially leading to tenant disputes.

[p_106].description: The Buyer is asked to indemnify the Seller for 'all claims' related to In-Process TI Work. This could include claims arising from the Seller's own negligence, pre-closing contract breaches, or injuries that occurred before the Buyer took title.
[p_106].problematic_text: Buyer shall defend, indemnify and hold Seller harmless from all claims, losses, liabilities and expenses (including attorneys' fees and costs) incurred by or asserted against Seller and related to the In Process TI Work.
[p_106].title: Overbroad Indemnity for TI Work
[p_106].user_recommendation: Change to: 'Buyer shall defend, indemnify and hold Seller harmless from all claims... to the extent arising from Buyer's acts or omissions after the Closing Date. Seller shall remain liable for and shall indemnify Buyer against any claims arising from work performed or contracts entered into by Seller prior to the Closing Date.'

[p_106].description: If the escrowed funds are insufficient to cover the TI work, the Seller is supposed to reimburse the Buyer. However, if the Seller is a Single Purpose Entity (SPE), 'demand' for reimbursement may be worthless after the Seller has distributed the sale proceeds.
[p_106].problematic_text: if the amount in escrow is insufficient for such purpose, Seller shall reimburse Buyer for such deficiency upon demand.
[p_106].title: Unsecured Seller Reimbursement for TI Deficiencies
[p_106].user_recommendation: Add: 'Seller's obligation to reimburse Buyer for such deficiency shall survive the Closing for [e.g., 12-24] months and shall be backed by [a parent guaranty/a holdback of proceeds].'

[p_106].description: During Due Diligence, obtain a certified list of all 'In Process TI Work,' copies of all contracts, and lien waivers for work completed to date.
[p_106].title: TI Status Audit
[p_106].user_recommendation: During Due Diligence, obtain a certified list of all 'In Process TI Work,' copies of all contracts, and lien waivers for work completed to date.

[p_134].description: Verify that Section 16 (referenced in p_150) contains specific protocols for email delivery, such as a requirement for a read receipt or a 'deemed received' timeframe, to avoid disputes over whether a notice was actually delivered.
[p_134].title: Email Notice Protocol
[p_134].user_recommendation: Verify that Section 16 (referenced in p_150) contains specific protocols for email delivery, such as a requirement for a read receipt or a 'deemed received' timeframe, to avoid disputes over whether a notice was actually delivered.

[p_152].description: This 'Entire Agreement' or merger clause prevents the buyer from relying on any verbal promises, marketing materials, or emails exchanged during negotiations. If the seller made specific claims about the property's condition, income, or zoning that are not explicitly written in this document, the buyer cannot sue for breach based on those claims.
[p_152].problematic_text: The parties agree that there are no oral agreements, understandings, representations or warranties that are not expressly set forth herein.
[p_152].title: Exclusion of Extrinsic Representations
[p_152].user_recommendation: Buyer should ensure that all material representations relied upon during due diligence (e.g., rent rolls, environmental reports, or specific seller promises) are explicitly incorporated into the 'Representations and Warranties' section or attached as Exhibits.

[p_153].description: The phrase 'where permitted by this Agreement' indicates that the buyer's ability to transfer the contract to a successor or affiliate is restricted elsewhere in the document. For a buyer, the ability to assign the contract to a single-purpose entity (SPE) or an affiliate for financing and liability purposes is critical.
[p_153].title: Conditional Binding Effect on Assigns
[p_153].user_recommendation: Cross-reference this with the 'Assignment' section of the contract. If the Assignment section requires Seller's consent for all transfers, revise it to allow 'assignment to any entity controlled by, or under common control with, Buyer' without Seller's consent.

[p_15].description: The Seller is reserving the right to pursue claims against contractors, designers, and warrantors even after the sale. This could create a conflict where both Buyer and Seller are pursuing the same third party, or where the Seller settles a claim that affects the Buyer's ability to recover for defects discovered post-closing.
[p_15].problematic_text: Seller reserves and retains the right, on a non-exclusive basis with Buyer, to assert all claims, defenses, counter claims, and cross claims of Seller against any third parties under any warranties, guaranties, and agreements related to design, construction or performance of the Property
[p_15].title: Seller Retention of Third-Party Claims
[p_15].user_recommendation: Revise to clarify that Seller's reserved rights are limited to claims arising from liabilities incurred by Seller prior to the Closing Date and that such reservation does not diminish the warranties assigned to Buyer. Add: 'provided, however, that Seller’s reservation of rights shall not impair Buyer’s rights under any warranties assigned to Buyer at Closing.'

[p_164].description: Verify that any 'further instruments' requested do not expand the Buyer's financial obligations or liabilities beyond those expressly stated in the Agreement.
[p_164].title: Scope of Further Assurances
[p_164].user_recommendation: Verify that any 'further instruments' requested do not expand the Buyer's financial obligations or liabilities beyond those expressly stated in the Agreement.

[p_166].description: While mutual, the indemnity requires the Buyer to pay for legal defense and costs if any person claims a commission 'by, through or under' the Buyer. If the Buyer had casual conversations with multiple brokers, this could trigger a duty to defend the Seller.
[p_166].problematic_text: each agrees to and does hereby indemnify and hold the other harmless against the payment of any commission to any person or entity claiming by, through or under Seller or Buyer, as applicable.
[p_166].title: Broad Mutual Brokerage Indemnity
[p_166].user_recommendation: Ensure the Buyer has a definitive list of all brokers consulted and specifically excludes them or confirms no agreements exist. No change to text needed if Buyer is certain of their broker relationships.

[p_166].description: Ensure the blank spaces for the Broker's name and the 'separate agreement' details are filled and reviewed before execution to ensure the Buyer is not inadvertently responsible for the Broker's Fee.
[p_166].title: Incomplete Broker Information
[p_166].user_recommendation: Ensure the blank spaces for the Broker's name and the 'separate agreement' details are filled and reviewed before execution to ensure the Buyer is not inadvertently responsible for the Broker's Fee.

[p_167].description: The Buyer is waiving the right to receive the Washington State Seller Disclosure Statement (Form 17). This statement covers critical items like title, water, sewer, structural, systems, and HOA issues. Waiving this shifts the entire burden of discovery to the Buyer's inspection, with no baseline representation from the Seller.
[p_167].problematic_text: BUYER HEREBY WAIVES ITS RIGHT TO RECEIVE THE SELLER DISCLOSURE STATEMENT REFERRED TO THEREIN.
[p_167].title: Waiver of Statutory Disclosure Statement
[p_167].user_recommendation: Change to: 'Seller shall provide the Seller Disclosure Statement to Buyer within five (5) days of the Effective Date; provided, however, that Buyer's sole remedy for inaccuracies therein shall be the right to terminate this Agreement during the Review Period.'

[p_168].description: The clause appears to force the Buyer to waive the statutory right to rescind the agreement upon receipt of the Environmental disclosure. Under RCW 64.06, a buyer usually has 3 days to rescind after receiving the disclosure. By waiving this 'by executing this Agreement,' the Buyer loses the ability to walk away if the Environmental section reveals contamination or underground tanks.
[p_168].problematic_text: by executing this Agreement, Buyer waive [sic]
[p_168].title: Waiver of Right to Rescind (Incomplete Clause)
[p_168].user_recommendation: Revise to: 'Seller shall provide the "Environmental" section of the Seller Disclosure Statement within three (3) days of the Effective Date. Buyer shall have three (3) business days from receipt of such section to rescind this Agreement and receive a full refund of the Earnest Money if the contents are unsatisfactory to Buyer in Buyer's sole discretion.'

[p_168].description: The text of p_168 is cut off. Obtain the full text to ensure no additional waivers of liability or rights are hidden in the missing portion.
[p_168].title: Incomplete Sentence/Paragraph
[p_168].user_recommendation: The text of p_168 is cut off. Obtain the full text to ensure no additional waivers of liability or rights are hidden in the missing portion.

[p_16].description: Verify that the numerical and written dollar amounts match the agreed-upon Letter of Intent (LOI).
[p_16].title: Purchase Price Verification
[p_16].user_recommendation: Verify that the numerical and written dollar amounts match the agreed-upon Letter of Intent (LOI).

[p_182].description: If the individual signing on behalf of the Seller does not have the legal authority to bind the entity, the contract may be voidable. For a Buyer, this creates significant risk if the Seller attempts to back out of the deal by claiming the signatory lacked corporate authority.
[p_182].title: Unverified Signatory Authority
[p_182].user_recommendation: Ensure the signature block is preceded by the full legal name of the Seller entity and that the signatory is signing in their capacity as an authorized officer (e.g., 'SELLER: [Entity Name], a [State] [Entity Type], By: [Name], Its: [Title]').

[p_182].description: Verify that the name entered here matches exactly with the 'Seller' defined in the preamble and the name registered with the Secretary of State.
[p_182].title: Entity Name Consistency
[p_182].user_recommendation: Verify that the name entered here matches exactly with the 'Seller' defined in the preamble and the name registered with the Secretary of State.

[p_186].description: Purchase agreements often calculate critical deadlines (Due Diligence Period, Earnest Money Deposit) from the 'Effective Date.' If the execution date is left blank or if there is a gap between the Seller's execution and the Buyer's execution, the timeline for performance becomes ambiguous.
[p_186].title: Ambiguous Effective Date Trigger
[p_186].user_recommendation: Add a specific 'Effective Date' provision stating: 'The Effective Date of this Agreement shall be the date upon which the last of the Buyer or Seller has executed this Agreement and delivered a fully executed copy to the other party.'

[p_186].description: Confirm whether the Seller or Buyer is expected to sign last, as the final signature date usually dictates the start of the contingency periods.
[p_186].title: Execution Sequence
[p_186].user_recommendation: Confirm whether the Seller or Buyer is expected to sign last, as the final signature date usually dictates the start of the contingency periods.

[p_18].description: The bracketed language directs the Escrow Holder to pay the Initial Deposit directly to the Seller upon receipt. This is 'hard money' from day one. If the Seller goes bankrupt or refuses to return the money after a valid termination, the Buyer has no security and must sue the Seller to recover funds.
[p_18].problematic_text: [Upon receipt, Escrow Holder shall promptly pay the Initial Deposit to Seller.]
[p_18].title: Immediate Release of Deposit to Seller
[p_18].user_recommendation: Delete the bracketed sentence. The deposit should be held in escrow by the Title Company until Closing or termination of the Agreement.

[p_18].description: The clause states the deposit is non-refundable upon receipt. This contradicts the purpose of a Due Diligence Period. The Buyer should be able to get the deposit back if they terminate during the inspection period.
[p_18].problematic_text: The Initial Deposit will become non-refundable upon Escrow Holder's receipt except in case of Seller's default hereunder.
[p_18].title: Premature Non-Refundability
[p_18].user_recommendation: Change to: 'The Initial Deposit shall be refundable to Buyer if Buyer terminates this Agreement prior to the expiration of the Due Diligence Period. Thereafter, the Deposit shall be non-refundable except as otherwise provided in this Agreement.'

[p_18].description: Confirm the Title Insurance Company is a reputable national provider and that the 'business days' for delivery align with the Buyer's banking capabilities.
[p_18].title: Escrow Holder Identity
[p_18].user_recommendation: Confirm the Title Insurance Company is a reputable national provider and that the 'business days' for delivery align with the Buyer's banking capabilities.

[p_194].description: Similar to the Seller's block, if the Buyer is an entity (LLC/Corp), the signature must reflect that the individual is signing on behalf of the entity to avoid personal liability for the individual and to ensure the entity is properly bound.
[p_194].title: Signatory Capacity for Buyer
[p_194].user_recommendation: Ensure the Buyer's signature block includes the entity name and the word 'By:' before the name line to clarify the representative capacity.

[p_194].description: If the Buyer is using a Special Purpose Entity (SPE) for the acquisition, ensure the signatory has been granted authority via a corporate resolution.
[p_194].title: Authorized Signatory Verification
[p_194].user_recommendation: If the Buyer is using a Special Purpose Entity (SPE) for the acquisition, ensure the signatory has been granted authority via a corporate resolution.

[p_19].description: Similar to the Initial Deposit, the bracketed language allows the Seller to take possession of the Additional Deposit immediately. This removes the protection of an independent escrow holder.
[p_19].problematic_text: [Upon receipt, Escrow Holder shall promptly pay the Additional Deposit to Seller.]
[p_19].title: Immediate Release of Additional Deposit
[p_19].user_recommendation: Delete the bracketed sentence to ensure the Additional Deposit remains in escrow.

[p_19].description: The text limits refundability only to 'Seller's default.' It should also be refundable if conditions precedent (like title clearance, casualty, or condemnation) are not met, even if those don't technically constitute a 'default' by Seller.
[p_19].problematic_text: The Additional Deposit is nonrefundable, except in case of Seller's default hereunder, and as otherwise expressly provided in this Agreement.
[p_19].title: Narrow Refundability Scope
[p_19].user_recommendation: Revise to: 'The Deposit shall be non-refundable except in the event of a Seller default, the failure of a condition precedent to Buyer's obligation to close, or as otherwise expressly provided herein.'

[p_200].description: Verify that the legal description inserted here matches the 'Exhibit A' attached to the PSA and, more importantly, matches the legal description provided in the Title Commitment/Preliminary Report.
[p_200].title: Legal Description Verification
[p_200].user_recommendation: Verify that the legal description inserted here matches the 'Exhibit A' attached to the PSA and, more importantly, matches the legal description provided in the Title Commitment/Preliminary Report.

[p_20].description: The term 'paid in cash' is archaic and technically implies physical currency. In commercial transactions, this should be clarified to ensure wire transfers of immediately available funds are required and accepted.
[p_20].problematic_text: shall be paid in cash on the Closing Date
[p_20].title: Ambiguous Payment Method
[p_20].user_recommendation: Change 'paid in cash' to 'paid by wire transfer of immediately available United States funds'.

[p_20].description: The bracketed language '[plus accrued interest thereon]' suggests that whether the Buyer receives credit for interest earned on the Deposit is still a point of negotiation. As the Buyer, you want to ensure all interest earned on your capital is applied toward the Purchase Price.
[p_20].title: Uncertainty Regarding Interest Credit
[p_20].user_recommendation: Remove the brackets and confirm the language: 'plus all accrued interest thereon'.

[p_21].description: The allocation of the Purchase Price between personal and real property has significant depreciation and transfer tax implications. If the dollar amount is left blank or filled in without professional tax advice, the Buyer may lose significant tax benefits or face challenges from the IRS/Department of Revenue.
[p_21].problematic_text: The sum of $____________ of the Purchase Price shall be allocated to the Personal Property
[p_21].title: Arbitrary Tax Allocation
[p_21].user_recommendation: Ensure the blank is filled with a value supported by a qualified appraisal or tax professional. Add: 'Seller and Buyer agree to report the transaction for federal and state tax purposes in accordance with such allocation.'

[p_21].description: Consult with a tax advisor to determine the optimal allocation for depreciation purposes before finalizing this amount.
[p_21].title: Verify Personal Property Value
[p_21].user_recommendation: Consult with a tax advisor to determine the optimal allocation for depreciation purposes before finalizing this amount.

[p_23].description: The paragraph mentions 'following items' but the subsequent paragraph [p_24] only explicitly lists the Survey. It does not explicitly list the Title Commitment or underlying exception documents in the delivery obligation, which could delay the due diligence clock.
[p_23].problematic_text: Seller shall deliver the following items to Buyer within seven (7) days
[p_23].title: Limited Scope of Deliverables
[p_23].user_recommendation: Revise to: 'Seller shall deliver the following items (collectively, the "Due Diligence Documents") to Buyer...'

[p_23].description: Verify that 7 days is sufficient for the Buyer's title officer to receive and review these documents, or ensure the 'Feasibility Period' does not start until these are received.
[p_23].title: Confirm Delivery Timeline
[p_23].user_recommendation: Verify that 7 days is sufficient for the Buyer's title officer to receive and review these documents, or ensure the 'Feasibility Period' does not start until these are received.

[p_243].description: The phrase 'all of its right, title and interest in' is characteristic of a quitclaim deed rather than a warranty deed. A warranty deed should convey the real property itself, not merely whatever interest the Grantor might happen to have. Using 'right, title and interest' can weaken the buyer's ability to claim a breach of the covenant of seisin if the seller actually owns less than a fee simple interest.
[p_243].problematic_text: grants, bargains, and conveys, unto the said Grantee all of its right, title and interest in that certain real property
[p_243].title: Quitclaim-Style Granting Language
[p_243].user_recommendation: Change to: 'grants, bargains, and conveys, unto the said Grantee that certain real property'

[p_243].description: While not strictly prohibited, including the assignment of leases within the recorded Special Warranty Deed is unconventional. Leases are typically assigned via a separate 'Assignment and Assumption of Leases.' Including them in the deed makes the leasehold transfer a matter of public record and may complicate the chain of title or lead to requests for lease disclosures from the county assessor.
[p_243].problematic_text: and the lessor's or landlord's interest in all space leases or occupancy agreements covering all or any portion of such real property
[p_243].title: Inclusion of Leases in Recorded Deed
[p_243].user_recommendation: Remove the reference to leases from the Deed and ensure they are covered exclusively in a separate Assignment and Assumption of Leases agreement.

[p_243].description: Ensure the Grantor name matches the 'Seller' name in the PSA and the 'Vested Owner' in the Title Report. Ensure the Grantee name matches the 'Buyer' (or its designated assignee).
[p_243].title: Entity Accuracy
[p_243].user_recommendation: Ensure the Grantor name matches the 'Seller' name in the PSA and the 'Vested Owner' in the Title Report. Ensure the Grantee name matches the 'Buyer' (or its designated assignee).

[p_244].description: The deed is made subject to 'matters set forth in Exhibit B.' If Exhibit B is not strictly limited to the 'Permitted Exceptions' agreed upon during the title review period, the Seller could unilaterally include title defects or encumbrances that the Buyer did not approve, effectively exempting those items from the special warranty of title.
[p_244].problematic_text: expressly subject to the matters set forth in Exhibit B attached hereto
[p_244].title: Undefined Scope of Exceptions
[p_244].user_recommendation: Change to: 'expressly subject only to those Permitted Exceptions set forth in Exhibit B attached hereto, which Permitted Exceptions are defined in that certain Purchase and Sale Agreement between Grantor and Grantee dated [Date].'

[p_24].description: The phrase 'in the possession of Seller' is too narrow. The Seller may have surveys held by their attorneys, engineers, or lenders that are not physically in their 'possession' but are under their 'control.'
[p_24].title: Limited Search Obligation for Survey
[p_24].user_recommendation: Change to 'in the possession or reasonable control of Seller, including any surveys held by Seller’s attorneys, consultants, or lenders.'

[p_24].description: The Seller is providing the 'Existing Survey' without any obligation to disclose if they know it is inaccurate (e.g., if new improvements were made after the survey date).
[p_24].problematic_text: The most recent survey of the Property, if any (“Existing Survey”) in the possession of Seller.
[p_24].title: Lack of Seller Representation on Survey Accuracy
[p_24].user_recommendation: Add: 'To Seller's knowledge, there have been no material changes to the Property since the date of the Existing Survey that would render it inaccurate.'

[p_25].description: The definition of Title Documents is tied to the 'Commitment' and 'Exceptions,' but the review period in [p_26] starts from the 'Effective Date' rather than the date Buyer actually receives these documents. If the Title Company or Seller is slow to deliver the documents, the Buyer's 10-day review window is effectively shortened.
[p_25].problematic_text: ten (10) days from the Effective Date (the “Title Review Period”)
[p_25].title: Title Review Clock Starts Prematurely
[p_25].user_recommendation: Change 'ten (10) days from the Effective Date' to 'ten (10) days after Buyer’s receipt of the Title Documents'.

[p_26].description: The clause specifies that failure to notify Seller of objections within 10 days constitutes 'approval of all exceptions.' This is a 'silent waiver' that can result in the Buyer being forced to take title subject to severe encumbrances (e.g., easements that prevent development) if a deadline is missed by even one day.
[p_26].problematic_text: Buyer's failure to timely notify Seller... shall constitute approval of all exceptions and of the condition of title to the Property.
[p_26].title: Deemed Approval of Title Exceptions
[p_26].user_recommendation: Revise to state that if Buyer fails to provide notice, the condition is deemed 'not satisfied' or 'disapproved,' or at minimum, require Seller to provide a second notice before a waiver is deemed to occur.

[p_26].description: The current language makes all title cures optional for the Seller ('Seller elects not to remove'). Standard commercial practice requires the Seller to remove 'Mandatory Cure Items' (e.g., mortgages, deeds of trust, mechanic's liens, and delinquent taxes) regardless of whether the Buyer objects.
[p_26].problematic_text: Seller shall have ten (10) days... to give Buyer... (ii) notice that Seller elects not to remove or cure such Title Objection.
[p_26].title: Lack of Mandatory Cure Items
[p_26].user_recommendation: Add: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, Seller shall be obligated to remove at or prior to Closing all monetary liens, delinquent taxes, and any encumbrances created by or through Seller after the Effective Date (collectively, "Mandatory Cure Items").'

[p_26].description: Verify that the 'Due Diligence Period' mentioned here (which allows termination) extends beyond the Seller's 10-day response period. If the DD period ends before the Seller responds, the Buyer loses their termination right.
[p_26].title: Due Diligence Period Alignment
[p_26].user_recommendation: Verify that the 'Due Diligence Period' mentioned here (which allows termination) extends beyond the Seller's 10-day response period. If the DD period ends before the Seller responds, the Buyer loses their termination right.

[p_27].description: The clause prevents the extension of the Closing Date for title review. If a supplemental report reveals a major defect (e.g., a new lien or lis pendens) shortly before closing, the Buyer may be forced to choose between terminating the deal or closing on a defective title without sufficient time for the cure process.
[p_27].problematic_text: in no event shall title review extend the Closing Date.
[p_27].title: Prohibition on Closing Extensions for Title Issues
[p_27].user_recommendation: Change to: 'If a supplemental report is issued within ten (10) days of the scheduled Closing Date, the Closing Date shall be extended as necessary to provide Buyer and Seller the full review and cure periods set forth herein.'

[p_28].description: The Seller is conveying title via a 'special warranty deed.' While common in commercial transactions, this only warrants against defects created during the Seller's ownership. A 'general warranty deed' would provide broader protection for the Buyer against all prior defects.
[p_28].problematic_text: special warranty deed in the form of attached Exhibit B
[p_28].title: Special Warranty Deed Limitation
[p_28].user_recommendation: If the Buyer has significant leverage, request a 'General Warranty Deed.' If not, ensure Exhibit B is reviewed to ensure the 'special' warranties are not overly diluted.

[p_28].description: Review Exhibit B (the Deed form) to ensure it matches the 'special warranty' description and does not contain additional 'as-is' disclaimers that undermine the warranty.
[p_28].title: Exhibit B Review
[p_28].user_recommendation: Review Exhibit B (the Deed form) to ensure it matches the 'special warranty' description and does not contain additional 'as-is' disclaimers that undermine the warranty.

[p_29].description: The paragraph limits requested endorsements to those 'agreed to by Title Company during the Due Diligence Period.' This prevents the Buyer from requesting necessary endorsements for new issues discovered via supplemental reports after the DD period has expired.
[p_29].problematic_text: requested by Buyer and agreed to by Title Company during the Due Diligence Period
[p_29].title: Endorsement Request Limitation
[p_29].user_recommendation: Change to: 'requested by Buyer and agreed to by Title Company prior to Closing; provided that any endorsements related to the initial Commitment shall be requested during the Due Diligence Period.'

[p_29].description: The paragraph mentions 'payment of its normal premium' but does not specify which party pays for the 'extended coverage' vs. 'standard coverage' or the endorsements. In many jurisdictions, the Seller pays for standard and the Buyer pays the 'extended' uplift.
[p_29].problematic_text: upon payment of its normal premium
[p_29].title: Ambiguity in Title Policy Costs
[p_29].user_recommendation: Clarify: 'Seller shall pay the cost of a standard ALTA owner's policy, and Buyer shall pay the additional cost for extended coverage and any endorsements requested by Buyer.'

[p_311].description: The paragraph uses 'Assignor' and 'Assignee', whereas the defined terms for the 'Agreement' typically refer to 'Seller' and 'Buyer'. If this paragraph is intended to be the signature block for the main Purchase and Sale Agreement, the terminology is inconsistent. If it is part of an Exhibit (Assignment form), it should clearly distinguish itself from the 'Agreement' defined in the preamble.
[p_311].problematic_text: Assignor and Assignee have executed this Agreement
[p_311].title: Inconsistent Party Naming
[p_311].user_recommendation: Change 'Assignor and Assignee' to 'Seller and Buyer' if this is the PSA signature page. If this is an Exhibit, change 'this Agreement' to 'this Assignment'.

[p_311].description: Linking the execution to the 'day and year first written above' can be problematic for assignment documents. Assignments should generally be effective as of the 'Closing Date' to ensure a clean break in liability and right to income. If the date 'first written above' is the date of the PSA (the reference date), the assignment might technically pre-date the actual transfer of title.
[p_311].problematic_text: as of the day and year first written above.
[p_311].title: Effective Date Ambiguity
[p_311].user_recommendation: Change to 'as of the Closing Date' or 'as of the date of the Closing' to ensure the transfer of leases and contracts aligns with the transfer of the Real Property.

[p_332].description: The defined term 'Rent Roll' refers to the version identified in the 'Due Diligence Documents'. For the purpose of the Assignment and Assumption of Leases, the Buyer needs the most current version. Relying on an old Rent Roll from the DD period may exclude new leases or amendments executed during the escrow period.
[p_332].title: Static Rent Roll Reference
[p_332].user_recommendation: Revise the placeholder to require: 'The Rent Roll as of the Closing Date, certified by Seller as true, correct, and complete, and attached hereto as Exhibit A-1.'

[p_332].description: Ensure that the final version of this schedule includes not just the Rent Roll, but all active lease amendments, letter agreements, and guarantees to ensure all 'Leases' (as defined) are legally transferred.
[p_332].title: Verify Lease Schedule Completeness
[p_332].user_recommendation: Ensure that the final version of this schedule includes not just the Rent Roll, but all active lease amendments, letter agreements, and guarantees to ensure all 'Leases' (as defined) are legally transferred.

[p_335].description: The paragraph is a header for the 'Assignment and Assumption of Contracts and Intangibles'. As a Buyer, it is critical that the actual form of this assignment (usually an Exhibit) contains a 'further assurances' clause and a clear indemnity where the Seller remains liable for all obligations arising prior to the Closing Date.
[p_335].problematic_text: Assignment and Assumption of Contracts and Intangibles
[p_335].title: Missing Form of Assignment Protections
[p_335].user_recommendation: Ensure the form of assignment includes: 'Assignor shall indemnify and hold Assignee harmless from any claims arising from the Contracts and Intangibles prior to the Closing Date, and Assignee shall indemnify Assignor for claims arising on or after the Closing Date.'

[p_335].description: Verify if any of the 'Contracts' being assigned require third-party consent. The Assignment form should include a representation that all necessary consents have been obtained.
[p_335].title: Contract Consent Review
[p_335].user_recommendation: Verify if any of the 'Contracts' being assigned require third-party consent. The Assignment form should include a representation that all necessary consents have been obtained.

[p_45].description: The phrase 'In addition to all other conditions' creates uncertainty by suggesting there are hidden or unlisted conditions elsewhere in the agreement that could allow the Seller to refuse to close. Conditions precedent should be exhaustive to ensure certainty of closing.
[p_45].problematic_text: In addition to all other conditions to Seller's obligations in this Agreement
[p_45].title: Open-Ended Conditions Precedent
[p_45].user_recommendation: Change to 'Subject only to the satisfaction or waiver by Seller of the following conditions...'

[p_48].description: Requiring representations to be 'complete' is a higher and more subjective standard than 'true and correct.' A representation could be accurate but deemed 'incomplete' by a Seller looking for an excuse to terminate. This creates a 'backdoor' termination right.
[p_48].problematic_text: true, accurate and complete in all material respects
[p_48].title: Overly Broad Standard for Representations
[p_48].user_recommendation: Change to 'true and correct in all material respects'

[p_49].description: The paragraph allows for termination if conditions are not met but fails to specify that the Deposit must be returned to the Buyer if the termination is due to a failure of a condition (rather than a default). Without this, the Seller might attempt to retain the Deposit after terminating.
[p_49].problematic_text: this Agreement may be terminated by the party benefiting from such condition by written notice to the other party.
[p_49].title: Lack of Deposit Return Clarity
[p_49].user_recommendation: Append the following: 'In the event of such termination, the Deposit shall be immediately returned to Buyer, and except for those provisions which expressly survive termination, neither party shall have any further rights or obligations hereunder.'

[p_49].description: The paragraph refers to 'Sections 5.1 through 5.4' and 'Section 5.5'. Based on the provided text, [p_45] appears to be Section 5.5. If the numbering in the final document does not align perfectly, the waiver and termination rights may be legally unenforceable or applied to the wrong sections.
[p_49].problematic_text: The conditions set forth in Sections 5.1 through 5.4are for the exclusive benefit of Buyer and the conditions set forth in Section 5.5 are for the exclusive benefit of Seller.
[p_49].title: Potential Internal Reference Mismatch
[p_49].user_recommendation: Verify that [p_45] through [p_48] are indeed contained within Section 5.5 and that Sections 5.1-5.4 refer to Buyer's conditions (e.g., due diligence, financing).

[p_49].description: Confirm that the paragraph numbers in the final execution version match the 'Section 5.x' references in [p_49].
[p_49].title: Verify Section Numbering
[p_49].user_recommendation: Confirm that the paragraph numbers in the final execution version match the 'Section 5.x' references in [p_49].

[p_4].description: The term 'delivered' is not defined. In a dispute, it may be unclear whether delivery occurs upon hitting 'send' on an email, physical receipt by a party, or receipt by their respective legal counsel. Since the Effective Date triggers all contingency periods (due diligence, financing, etc.), any ambiguity can lead to missed deadlines.
[p_4].problematic_text: executed and delivered by the last of Buyer and Seller
[p_4].title: Ambiguity in 'Delivery' for Effective Date
[p_4].user_recommendation: Change to: 'executed and delivered (including delivery by electronic transmission/email) by the last of Buyer and Seller'

[p_4].description: The preamble identifies a specific 'Buyer' without mentioning 'and/or assigns.' While assignment is often covered in a later boilerplate section, failing to establish the right to assign to a related entity (e.g., an LLC formed for the purchase) at the outset can create friction if the Seller later claims the specific identity of the Buyer was a material term of the contract.
[p_4].title: Lack of Assignment Flexibility in Preamble

[p_4].description: Verify that the legal name of the Seller matches the name on the current vesting deed/title report to ensure the party has the legal authority to sell.
[p_4].title: Entity Verification
[p_4].user_recommendation: Verify that the legal name of the Seller matches the name on the current vesting deed/title report to ensure the party has the legal authority to sell.

[p_55].description: The representation regarding governmental violations is qualified by 'Seller's Actual Knowledge,' which, as defined in [p_59], excludes any duty to investigate. This allows the Seller to remain willfully ignorant of violations that would be discovered by a simple review of property records or inquiry with the property manager.
[p_55].title: Knowledge-Qualified Violation Rep
[p_55].user_recommendation: Change to 'To Seller's knowledge, after due inquiry of the property manager and a review of Seller's property files...'

[p_56].description: The representation only covers litigation against the 'Seller' entity. It does not explicitly cover litigation against the 'Property' itself (e.g., in rem actions) or litigation against the Seller that specifically relates to the Property.
[p_56].problematic_text: there is no litigation pending or threatened against Seller.
[p_56].title: Narrow Scope of Litigation Rep
[p_56].user_recommendation: Change to 'there is no litigation pending or threatened against Seller or the Property, or which would affect Seller's ability to perform its obligations under this Agreement.'

[p_57].description: Verify through independent title search and zoning report, as the 'Actual Knowledge' qualifier limits the Seller's liability if they haven't checked recent municipal filings.
[p_57].title: Condemnation Verification
[p_57].user_recommendation: Verify through independent title search and zoning report, as the 'Actual Knowledge' qualifier limits the Seller's liability if they haven't checked recent municipal filings.

[p_58].description: This paragraph uses 'To the best of Seller’s knowledge,' whereas other paragraphs use 'To Seller's Actual Knowledge.' Since 'Actual Knowledge' is specifically defined in [p_59] to limit liability, the use of a different, undefined term here creates ambiguity. Seller may argue it means the same as the restricted definition, while Buyer may argue it implies a duty to investigate.
[p_58].problematic_text: To the best of Seller’s knowledge
[p_58].title: Inconsistent Knowledge Standard
[p_58].user_recommendation: Standardize the knowledge qualifier throughout the agreement. If using the defined term, ensure the definition in [p_59] is expanded to include due inquiry.

[p_58].description: The representation that lease copies are 'true, correct and complete' is qualified by 'in all material respects.' This allows the Seller to omit minor amendments or side letters that they unilaterally deem non-material, which could impact Buyer's underwriting.
[p_58].problematic_text: true, correct and complete in all material respects.
[p_58].title: Materiality Qualifier in Lease Accuracy
[p_58].user_recommendation: Change to 'true, correct and complete in all respects.'

[p_58].description: Cross-reference the representations in this paragraph with the Tenant Estoppel Certificates obtained during due diligence to ensure no discrepancies exist regarding concessions or defaults.
[p_58].title: Tenant Estoppel Comparison
[p_58].user_recommendation: Cross-reference the representations in this paragraph with the Tenant Estoppel Certificates obtained during due diligence to ensure no discrepancies exist regarding concessions or defaults.

[p_59].description: The definition of 'Actual Knowledge' explicitly states it is 'without such person undertaking any investigation.' This is highly problematic for a Buyer as it protects a Seller who deliberately avoids checking their own files or speaking to their property manager to avoid 'actual' knowledge of a defect.
[p_59].problematic_text: without such person undertaking any investigation.
[p_59].title: Ostrich Clause (No Investigation)
[p_59].user_recommendation: Replace with 'after due inquiry of the property manager and a review of Seller's records related to the Property.'

[p_59].description: This clause states that if any Due Diligence Materials (which could be thousands of pages in a data room) contain information inconsistent with the Seller's representations, the representations are 'deemed modified.' This effectively shifts the entire burden of discovery to the Buyer and allows the Seller to make false representations as long as the truth is buried somewhere in the data room.
[p_59].problematic_text: To the extent the Due Diligence Materials... contains express provisions or information that are inconsistent with the foregoing representations and warranties, such representations and warranties shall be deemed modified
[p_59].title: Knowledge Override / Anti-Sandbagging
[p_59].user_recommendation: Delete this entire sentence. The Seller should stand behind its representations regardless of what is in the data room, unless specifically disclosed in a Disclosure Schedule.

[p_59].description: While it is standard to limit liability to the entity, the broad covenant that Buyer will bring 'no action of any kind' against the named individuals could potentially bar claims for fraud or intentional misrepresentation by those individuals.
[p_59].problematic_text: Buyer covenants that it will bring no action of any kind against any such individuals
[p_59].title: Covenant Not to Sue Individuals
[p_59].user_recommendation: Add: '...except in the case of fraud or intentional misrepresentation by such individuals.'

[p_59].description: Ensure the blank space for the named individual is filled with the person most likely to have day-to-day operational knowledge of the property (e.g., the Asset Manager or Lead Portfolio Manager).
[p_59].title: Identify Knowledge Individual
[p_59].user_recommendation: Ensure the blank space for the named individual is filled with the person most likely to have day-to-day operational knowledge of the property (e.g., the Asset Manager or Lead Portfolio Manager).

[p_70].description: The clause requires Seller to maintain insurance 'currently in force.' If the Seller's current coverage is inadequate or expires during the escrow period, the Buyer has no protection requiring the Seller to maintain industry-standard coverage or specific limits.
[p_70].problematic_text: Seller shall maintain all casualty and liability insurance currently in force with respect to the Property.
[p_70].title: Vague Insurance Maintenance Standard
[p_70].user_recommendation: Change to: 'Seller shall maintain all casualty and liability insurance currently in force with respect to the Property, and shall not reduce or cancel such coverage prior to Closing.'

[p_71].description: The percentage and square footage requirements for the 'Minimum Tenant Estoppels' are blank. Without these numbers, the condition is unenforceable or provides the Buyer with no guaranteed level of tenant verification.
[p_71].problematic_text: represent not less that _______ percent (__%) of the net rentable square footage of the Property, including Tenant Estoppels from all tenants who lease more than _____ rentable square feet
[p_71].title: Unspecified Minimum Estoppel Threshold
[p_71].user_recommendation: Fill in the blanks with protective numbers, e.g., '75 percent' and 'all tenants who lease more than 5,000 rentable square feet' (or 'Major Tenants' as defined elsewhere).

[p_71].description: The Seller's Lease Certificate (used when a tenant fails to provide an estoppel) is limited to 'Seller's knowledge.' This shifts the risk of lease disputes to the Buyer if the Seller claims they 'didn't know' about a tenant's side agreement or default.
[p_71].problematic_text: certifying, to Seller’s knowledge, those matters included in the attached form of Tenant Estoppel
[p_71].title: Weak Seller Lease Certificate Standard
[p_71].user_recommendation: Remove 'to Seller's knowledge' or add: 'provided, however, that if a tenant subsequently asserts a claim or defense contrary to the Seller’s Lease Certificate, such certificate shall be treated as a representation and warranty of Seller that survives Closing.'

[p_71].description: The Seller explicitly disclaims any obligation to obtain subordination agreements, which may be a requirement for the Buyer's lender.
[p_71].problematic_text: Seller shall have no obligation to obtain and deliver any such subordination agreements to Buyer.
[p_71].title: No Obligation for Subordination Agreements
[p_71].user_recommendation: Change to: 'Seller shall use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain and deliver such subordination agreements, provided that Seller shall not be required to expend any out-of-pocket funds or commence litigation in connection therewith.'

[p_71].description: Verify that Exhibit G (the Estoppel form) contains all necessary lender-required language, including confirmation of rent, security deposits, and no landlord defaults.
[p_71].title: Exhibit G Review
[p_71].user_recommendation: Verify that Exhibit G (the Estoppel form) contains all necessary lender-required language, including confirmation of rent, security deposits, and no landlord defaults.

[p_72].description: The Buyer is required to release all third-party sources and preparers of information (e.g., environmental consultants, surveyors, engineers) retained by the Seller. This prevents the Buyer from seeking recourse against a professional who may have committed malpractice in a report the Buyer relied upon.
[p_72].problematic_text: BUYER AGREES TO FULLY AND IRREVOCABLY RELEASE ALL SUCH SOURCES OF INFORMATION AND PREPARERS OF INFORMATION AND DOCUMENTATION AFFECTING THE PROPERTY WHICH WERE RETAINED BY SELLER
[p_72].title: Broad Release of Third-Party Information Providers
[p_72].user_recommendation: Delete this release or add: 'except to the extent Buyer is named as an authorized user or third-party beneficiary of such reports or documentation.'

[p_72].description: Seller disclaims the accuracy or completeness of all due diligence materials. While common in 'As-Is' sales, this can be problematic if the Seller provides misleading or incomplete records intentionally.
[p_72].problematic_text: SELLER MAKES NO REPRESENTATIONS AS TO THE ACCURACY OR COMPLETENESS OF SUCH INFORMATION.
[p_72].title: Disclaimer of Accuracy of Due Diligence Materials
[p_72].user_recommendation: Add: 'except that Seller represents that it has not intentionally withheld or misrepresented any material information in the Due Diligence Materials.'

[p_72].description: Confirm that Section 7 (referenced as the exception to the AS-IS clause) contains robust representations regarding environmental, zoning, and physical condition to balance this broad disclaimer.
[p_72].title: Section 7 Cross-Reference
[p_72].user_recommendation: Confirm that Section 7 (referenced as the exception to the AS-IS clause) contains robust representations regarding environmental, zoning, and physical condition to balance this broad disclaimer.

[p_74].description: The release is so broad ('any and all losses... arising out of or in any way connected with the Property') that it could be interpreted to release the Seller from a breach of the representations and warranties in Section 7 immediately upon Closing, rendering the survival period useless.
[p_74].problematic_text: forever release Seller... of and from any and all losses, liabilities, damages, claims, demands, causes of action, costs and expenses, whether known or unknown, arising out of or in any way connected with the Property
[p_74].title: Release Extinguishes Seller's Reps and Warranties
[p_74].user_recommendation: Add a carve-out: '...except for (i) the warranties of Seller contained in the Deed, (ii) the representations and warranties of Seller in Section 7 which survive Closing, and (iii) any other obligations of Seller under this Agreement which expressly survive Closing.'

[p_74].description: The environmental release only carves out claims for hazardous substances 'caused by Seller.' It is often difficult to prove the Seller 'caused' a release versus merely owning the property while it existed. This could prevent the Buyer from seeking contribution for pre-existing conditions.
[p_74].problematic_text: regarding the release of any hazardous substances on the Property caused by Seller.
[p_74].title: Narrow Environmental Carve-out
[p_74].user_recommendation: Change to: 'regarding the release of any hazardous substances on the Property existing as of the Closing Date or caused by Seller or its agents.'

[p_76].description: The release of the Seller is broad and only carves out specific representations in Section 7.1 and post-closing obligations. It fails to carve out fraud, intentional misrepresentation, or breaches of the purchase agreement itself occurring prior to closing that are discovered later.
[p_76].problematic_text: The foregoing release shall not, however, affect Seller’s liability for or under (a) any representations and warranties made specifically by Seller in Section 7.1 above to the extent same survive Closing as provided therein; or (b) any other obligations of Seller identified herein which are to be performed after Closing.
[p_76].title: Narrow Carve-outs from Release
[p_76].user_recommendation: Revise to: 'The foregoing release shall not, however, affect Seller’s liability for or under (a) any representations and warranties made specifically by Seller in Section 7.1 above to the extent same survive Closing as provided therein; (b) any other obligations of Seller identified herein which are to be performed after Closing; or (c) any claims arising from fraud or intentional misrepresentation by Seller.'

[p_79].description: The current language only applies 50% of the second extension fee toward the Purchase Price. This effectively increases the cost of the property if the Buyer needs the full extension period, penalizing the Buyer for using a right they are paying for.
[p_79].problematic_text: one-half (1/2) of the Extension Fee paid by Buyer, if any, for the second extension shall be applicable to the Purchase Price.
[p_79].title: Partial Application of Extension Fee
[p_79].user_recommendation: Change 'one-half (1/2) of the Extension Fee' to 'the full amount of the Extension Fee'.

[p_79].description: The extension fee is only refundable in the event of a Seller default. If the contract terminates due to other reasons where the Buyer is typically entitled to a refund of the Deposit (e.g., failure of a condition precedent, title defects, casualty, or condemnation), the Buyer would lose the Extension Fee.
[p_79].problematic_text: The Extension Fee shall be nonrefundable, except in case of Seller's default.
[p_79].title: Limited Refundability of Extension Fees
[p_79].user_recommendation: Revise to: 'The Extension Fee shall be nonrefundable, except in the case of Seller's default or as otherwise expressly provided in this Agreement for the return of the Deposit to Buyer (including, without limitation, termination due to casualty, condemnation, or the failure of a condition precedent for Buyer's benefit).'

[p_79].description: Ensure the number of business days required for notice (currently blank) provides enough time for the Buyer to evaluate the need for an extension without being so long that it creates a 'dead zone' before closing.
[p_79].title: Verify Extension Notice Period
[p_79].user_recommendation: Ensure the number of business days required for notice (currently blank) provides enough time for the Buyer to evaluate the need for an extension without being so long that it creates a 'dead zone' before closing.

[p_80].description: The language grants possession subject to 'rights of tenants in possession under Leases.' If 'Leases' is not strictly defined to only include those disclosed to and approved by Buyer, the Buyer could be forced to accept undisclosed occupants or 'squatters' claiming leasehold rights.
[p_80].problematic_text: subject to the rights of tenants in possession under Leases.
[p_80].title: Possession Subject to Undisclosed Leases
[p_80].user_recommendation: Revise to: 'subject to the rights of tenants in possession under the Leases specifically disclosed to and approved by Buyer in writing.'

[p_81].description: Allowing Seller to deliver documents 'on' the Closing Date can lead to delays in funding and recording, especially if the Escrow Holder requires time to review documents or if the wire transfer cut-off times are early in the day.
[p_81].problematic_text: On or before the Closing Date
[p_81].title: Late Delivery of Closing Documents
[p_81].user_recommendation: Change to: 'At least one (1) business day prior to the Closing Date'

[p_81].description: The list of documents following [p_81] (in the next batch) must be reviewed to ensure all necessary transfer tax forms, affidavits of non-foreign status, and tenant notices are included.
[p_81].title: Review Seller's Delivery List
[p_81].user_recommendation: The list of documents following [p_81] (in the next batch) must be reviewed to ensure all necessary transfer tax forms, affidavits of non-foreign status, and tenant notices are included.

[p_8].description: The clause states the Seller will 'sell and convey' but does not specify the quality of the deed. In Washington, a Buyer should specifically require a 'Statutory Warranty Deed' to ensure the Seller warrants against all defects in title. Without this specification, the Seller might attempt to provide a Bargain and Sale Deed or a Quitclaim Deed, which offer significantly less protection.
[p_8].problematic_text: Seller agrees to sell and convey to Buyer
[p_8].title: Failure to Specify Deed Type
[p_8].user_recommendation: Change to: 'Seller agrees to sell and convey to Buyer by Statutory Warranty Deed'

[p_9].description: The definition is limited to the land described in Exhibit A. It fails to explicitly include appurtenances, easements, water rights, and mineral rights that may be associated with the land. A Buyer should ensure the definition is broad enough to capture all rights 'running with the land.'
[p_9].problematic_text: All that certain real property located at ______________________________________, Washington, as more particularly described in Exhibit A attached hereto (the “Real Property”);
[p_9].title: Narrow Definition of Real Property
[p_9].user_recommendation: Change to: 'All that certain real property located at ______________________________________, Washington, as more particularly described in Exhibit A attached hereto, together with all rights, privileges, easements, and appurtenances thereto (the “Real Property”);'

[p_9].description: Confirm that Exhibit A is attached and that the legal description (metes and bounds or lot/block) is identical to the description in the preliminary title report.
[p_9].title: Exhibit A Verification
[p_9].user_recommendation: Confirm that Exhibit A is attached and that the legal description (metes and bounds or lot/block) is identical to the description in the preliminary title report.

p_10.description: Verify via title report that all necessary easements for access, utilities, and drainage are indeed appurtenant to the land and not personal to the current owner.
p_10.title: Verification of Appurtenant Rights
p_10.user_recommendation: Verify via title report that all necessary easements for access, utilities, and drainage are indeed appurtenant to the land and not personal to the current owner.

p_100.description: The phrase 'or otherwise' is overly broad and could be used to demand that the Buyer produce documents or enter into agreements not previously contemplated or agreed upon in the PSA.
p_100.problematic_text: or otherwise to close the Escrow
p_100.title: Vague Catch-all for Closing Documents
p_100.user_recommendation: Change to 'or as reasonably required by Escrow Holder to close the Escrow'

p_101.description: The defined term 'Title Policy' specifies an 'extended coverage owner's policy.' However, this paragraph shifts the cost of the 'extended' portion of that premium to the Buyer. In many commercial transactions, it is customary for the Seller to pay the full premium for the Owner's Policy (including extended coverage), while the Buyer pays for endorsements and lender-related costs.
p_101.problematic_text: Seller shall pay the premium for the portion of the Title Policy attributable to “standard” coverage. Buyer shall pay the incremental premium to obtain “extended” coverage
p_101.title: Buyer Responsible for Extended Title Coverage Premium
p_101.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Seller shall pay the full premium for the Title Policy (including the cost of “extended” coverage).'

p_101.description: Relying on 'county custom' for recording fees can lead to uncertainty and minor disputes at closing, as customs can vary or be interpreted differently by escrow officers.
p_101.problematic_text: paid in the manner customary for the county in which the Property is located
p_101.title: Ambiguous Allocation of Recording Fees
p_101.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Recording fees shall be split equally between Buyer and Seller.' (Or specify that Seller pays for recording releases and Buyer pays for recording the Deed).

p_101.description: Since Buyer is responsible for all endorsement costs, ensure that the Due Diligence period allows enough time to receive a title commitment and quote for necessary endorsements (e.g., zoning, survey, access) to budget accordingly.
p_101.title: Endorsement Cost Verification
p_101.user_recommendation: Since Buyer is responsible for all endorsement costs, ensure that the Due Diligence period allows enough time to receive a title commitment and quote for necessary endorsements (e.g., zoning, survey, access) to budget accordingly.

p_108.description: The paragraph limits the conditions for closing to only the delivery of funds/documents and title readiness. It fails to include the satisfaction of Seller's representations, warranties, and covenants as a prerequisite for the Escrow Holder to close.
p_108.problematic_text: when and only when each of the following conditions have been satisfied:
p_108.title: Incomplete Conditions to Closing
p_108.user_recommendation: Change to: 'when and only when each of the following conditions have been satisfied or waived in writing by the party for whose benefit the condition exists:' and add a condition: '(iii) Seller has performed all obligations and complied with all covenants required by this Agreement, and all of Seller’s representations and warranties remain true and correct as of the Closing Date.'

p_109.description: The phrase 'All funds and documents' is non-specific. It does not explicitly reference the specific closing deliveries required of the Seller (e.g., FIRPTA affidavit, Bill of Sale, Assignment of Leases).
p_109.problematic_text: All funds and documents have been delivered to Escrow Holder
p_109.title: Vague Document Delivery Requirement
p_109.user_recommendation: Change to: 'All funds and documents required to be delivered by Seller and Buyer pursuant to [Insert Section Numbers for Seller/Buyer Deliveries] of this Agreement have been delivered to Escrow Holder;'

p_11.description: The definition excludes fixtures leased by Seller or owned by tenants without requiring a specific list. This creates a risk that essential operating equipment (e.g., HVAC units, solar panels, or specialized lighting) might be removed or reclaimed by third parties after closing without the Buyer's prior knowledge.
p_11.problematic_text: excluding any fixtures owned by tenants or leased by Seller from third parties
p_11.title: Ambiguity in Excluded Fixtures
p_11.user_recommendation: Change to: 'excluding only those fixtures owned by tenants or leased by Seller from third parties as specifically identified in Schedule [X] attached hereto'

p_11.description: Request a list of all third-party leased equipment and fixtures to ensure no critical infrastructure is excluded from the sale.
p_11.title: Fixture Ownership Audit
p_11.user_recommendation: Request a list of all third-party leased equipment and fixtures to ensure no critical infrastructure is excluded from the sale.

p_110.description: The phrase 'prepared to deliver' is legally ambiguous. The standard for closing is that the Title Company must be 'irrevocably committed' to issue the policy in the specific form (including endorsements) agreed upon during due diligence.
p_110.problematic_text: Title Company is prepared to deliver the Title Policy.
p_110.title: Weak Title Policy Condition
p_110.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Title Company is irrevocably committed to issue the Title Policy to Buyer, in the form and with the endorsements approved by Buyer during the Due Diligence Period, upon the recording of the Deed and the payment of the applicable premium.'

p_111.description: The provision grants interest to the Seller for sums due 'after the Closing.' If the closing is delayed due to the Seller's default or failure to perform, the Seller should not benefit from interest accruing on the purchase price during that delay.
p_111.problematic_text: Interest accruing on all sums due Seller after the Closing shall be for the account of Seller.
p_111.title: Ambiguity Regarding Interest on Delayed Closing
p_111.user_recommendation: Add: '; provided, however, that if Closing is delayed due to a default by Seller, all interest accruing on the Deposit and Closing Payment during such delay shall be for the account of Buyer.'

p_111.description: Verify if the Buyer has specific preferences for the type of 'interest bearing accounts' (e.g., government-backed, money market) to ensure principal protection.
p_111.title: Investment Instructions
p_111.user_recommendation: Verify if the Buyer has specific preferences for the type of 'interest bearing accounts' (e.g., government-backed, money market) to ensure principal protection.

p_112.description: Allowing the Escrow Holder to disburse funds 'as Seller may otherwise direct' creates risks regarding FIRPTA withholding compliance and potential fraudulent transfers. Buyer needs to ensure funds go to the titled owner or a legally authorized agent to avoid tax liability or title challenges.
p_112.problematic_text: or as Seller may otherwise direct.
p_112.title: Unrestricted Third-Party Disbursement
p_112.user_recommendation: Change to: 'or as Seller may otherwise direct in writing, provided that any such direction to a third party is subject to Buyer's reasonable approval and compliance with applicable tax withholding requirements, including FIRPTA.'

p_113.description: Confirm with the Escrow Holder that the Deed will be recorded immediately upon Closing and that the 'delivery' to Buyer includes a copy of the recorded instrument with the recorder's stamp.
p_113.title: Verification of Recording Sequence
p_113.user_recommendation: Confirm with the Escrow Holder that the Deed will be recorded immediately upon Closing and that the 'delivery' to Buyer includes a copy of the recorded instrument with the recorder's stamp.

p_114.description: The phrase 'party entitled thereto or benefited thereby' is subjective and lacks a specific mechanism for determination. This could lead to disputes at closing regarding the distribution of original documents, keys, or prorated funds if the closing statement is not perfectly aligned with this clause.
p_114.problematic_text: to the party entitled thereto or benefited thereby
p_114.title: Ambiguity in Escrow Item Distribution
p_114.user_recommendation: Change to 'to the party entitled thereto pursuant to the terms of this Agreement and the final Closing Statement approved by Buyer and Seller.'

p_116.description: The provision instructs the Escrow Holder to deliver the Deposit to the Seller upon a default without requiring mutual consent or a judicial determination. This allows a Seller to unilaterally declare a default and demand the funds, potentially forcing the Buyer to sue to recover a Deposit that was wrongfully taken.
p_116.problematic_text: THE ESCROW HOLDER IS HEREBY INSTRUCTED BY SELLER AND BUYER TO DELIVER THE DEPOSIT TO SELLER IN SUCH EVENT
p_116.title: Unilateral Instruction for Deposit Release
p_116.user_recommendation: Change to 'THE ESCROW HOLDER IS HEREBY INSTRUCTED BY SELLER AND BUYER TO DELIVER THE DEPOSIT TO SELLER IN SUCH EVENT ONLY UPON RECEIPT OF JOINT WRITTEN INSTRUCTIONS FROM BUYER AND SELLER OR A FINAL, NON-APPEALABLE ORDER FROM A COURT OF COMPETENT JURISDICTION.'

p_116.description: The liquidated damages are intended to be the 'sole and exclusive remedy.' However, the carve-out for 'indemnification' is dangerously broad. If the general indemnity clause in the agreement (often found in p_15 or similar) includes 'breach of contract,' the Seller could bypass the liquidated damages cap by suing under an indemnity theory.
p_116.problematic_text: THE FOREGOING LIMITATION OF REMEDY SHALL NOT APPLY TO BUYER'S INDEMNIFICATION OR REPAIR AND RESTORATION OBLIGATIONS
p_116.title: Broad Indemnity Carve-out to Liquidated Damages
p_116.user_recommendation: Change to 'THE FOREGOING LIMITATION OF REMEDY SHALL NOT APPLY TO BUYER'S INDEMNIFICATION OBLIGATIONS ARISING OUT OF THIRD-PARTY CLAIMS, OR BUYER'S REPAIR AND RESTORATION OBLIGATIONS...'

p_116.description: Verify local state law requirements for liquidated damages formatting.
p_116.title: Statutory Compliance for Liquidated Damages
p_116.user_recommendation: Verify local state law requirements for liquidated damages formatting.

p_117.description: Ensure both parties actually initial the spaces in p_118. In many jurisdictions, failure to initial the liquidated damages clause specifically renders it void, potentially exposing the Buyer to unlimited damages or specific performance.
p_117.title: Execution Requirement
p_117.user_recommendation: Ensure both parties actually initial the spaces in p_118. In many jurisdictions, failure to initial the liquidated damages clause specifically renders it void, potentially exposing the Buyer to unlimited damages or specific performance.

p_119.description: The clause explicitly waives the Buyer's right to seek specific performance. In real estate, where properties are unique, the ability to force the Seller to convey the property is the Buyer's most powerful leverage. Without it, a Seller can 'walk' from the deal if they get a better offer, simply by paying a capped amount of costs.
p_119.problematic_text: Buyer expressly waives its right to specific performance, and any other damage claims.
p_119.title: Waiver of Specific Performance
p_119.user_recommendation: Delete the waiver of specific performance. Revise to: 'Buyer shall have the right to either (i) terminate this Agreement and receive a refund of the Deposit and the reimbursement of costs described above, or (ii) seek specific performance of this Agreement.'

p_119.description: There is a significant clerical error ('Fifty Hundred Thousand' vs '$50,000'). Furthermore, capping the Buyer's recovery of out-of-pocket costs to $50,000 may be insufficient to cover due diligence, legal fees, and financing costs for a commercial transaction.
p_119.problematic_text: in no event to exceed Fifty Hundred Thousand Dollars ($50,000)
p_119.title: Ambiguous and Capped Cost Reimbursement
p_119.user_recommendation: Clarify the amount and increase the cap to a more realistic figure (e.g., $100,000 or $250,000 depending on deal size). Change to: 'in no event to exceed One Hundred Thousand Dollars ($100,000).'

p_119.description: The Buyer's right to a remedy is conditioned on 'all other conditions to Seller's obligations... have been satisfied.' This could allow a Seller to intentionally block a condition from being satisfied to avoid being in 'default' and thus avoid paying the Buyer's costs.
p_119.problematic_text: and if all other conditions to Seller's obligations to consummate the sale of the Property to be satisfied as of the date of such default or failure of condition have been satisfied at the time of such default or failure
p_119.title: Conditional Default Remedy
p_119.user_recommendation: Add: '...satisfied (or waived by Seller, or would have been satisfied but for Seller's default or interference).'

p_12.description: By limiting the definition to property 'owned by Seller,' the buyer may lose out on property used in operations that is being financed or held under a capital lease where title hasn't technically passed, even if the buyer is expected to assume the obligation.
p_12.title: Ownership Limitation on Personal Property
p_12.user_recommendation: Change to: 'personal property owned by Seller (or in which Seller has a leasehold or possessory interest)'

p_12.description: Ensure the bracketed exclusion list is completed and that a full inventory of included personal property (FF&E) is attached as an exhibit.
p_12.title: Personal Property Inventory
p_12.user_recommendation: Ensure the bracketed exclusion list is completed and that a full inventory of included personal property (FF&E) is attached as an exhibit.

p_120.description: If the Buyer elects to proceed after a casualty, they receive an assignment of insurance proceeds. However, the Seller is not required to credit the Buyer for the amount of the deductible. This effectively increases the Purchase Price for the Buyer by the amount of the deductible.
p_120.problematic_text: Buyer shall receive an assignment of the proceeds of any casualty insurance otherwise payable to Seller
p_120.title: Missing Insurance Deductible Credit
p_120.user_recommendation: Add: '...plus a credit against the Purchase Price in the amount of any deductible under Seller's insurance policy.'

p_120.description: The threshold for what constitutes 'material' damage is left blank. This creates uncertainty regarding when the Buyer has the right to terminate the agreement.
p_120.problematic_text: damage is material if the reasonable estimated cost of repair exceeds $_________
p_120.title: Undefined Materiality Threshold
p_120.user_recommendation: Insert a specific dollar amount or a percentage of the Purchase Price (e.g., 5% of the Purchase Price).

p_120.description: Verify Seller's current insurance coverage limits and deductibles to ensure the 'assignment of proceeds' is actually valuable.
p_120.title: Insurance Policy Review
p_120.user_recommendation: Verify Seller's current insurance coverage limits and deductibles to ensure the 'assignment of proceeds' is actually valuable.

p_121.description: While the clause is generally fair, it does not explicitly state that fees incurred in appeals or bankruptcy proceedings are covered, which can be a significant expense.
p_121.problematic_text: reasonable attorney fees, and all other reasonable litigation expenses
p_121.title: Narrow Prevailing Party Definition
p_121.user_recommendation: Change to: 'reasonable attorney fees (including those incurred in connection with any appeals or post-judgment collection proceedings), and all other reasonable litigation expenses...'

p_122.description: The clause allows for email notice but relies on 'electronic confirmation of such delivery.' This can be ambiguous (e.g., does an automated 'delivered' receipt count if the recipient didn't see it?).
p_122.problematic_text: as evidenced by the notifying party's receipt of written or electronic confirmation of such delivery or refusal
p_122.title: Electronic Notice Verification
p_122.user_recommendation: Add: 'provided that any notice sent by email shall also be sent by overnight courier on the same day to be effective.'

p_122.description: Ensure all addresses, email addresses, and fax numbers for Buyer, Seller, and Sample Law Firm LLP are fully populated in the final execution version.
p_122.title: Missing Contact Information
p_122.user_recommendation: Ensure all addresses, email addresses, and fax numbers for Buyer, Seller, and Sample Law Firm LLP are fully populated in the final execution version.

p_13.description: The phrase 'to the extent transferable' is self-executing and does not obligate the Seller to actually attempt to transfer the property or obtain necessary consents from third parties (like software licensors or permit issuers).
p_13.problematic_text: to the extent transferable by Seller
p_13.title: Passive Transfer Obligation
p_13.user_recommendation: Add: 'Seller shall use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain any required consents for the transfer of such Intangible Property at no cost to Buyer.'

p_13.description: The exclusion of all claims against third parties relating to the period prior to closing is dangerous. If there is a latent construction defect, a warranty claim for a roof installed a year ago, or an unpaid insurance claim for recent damage, the Buyer needs these claims to be assigned so they can recover costs for repairs they will eventually have to make.
p_13.problematic_text: but excluding any present or future claims of Seller against any third parties that relate to any period of time prior to the Closing
p_13.title: Broad Exclusion of Pre-Closing Claims
p_13.user_recommendation: Change to: 'but excluding any present or future claims of Seller against any third parties that relate to any period of time prior to the Closing, except for (i) warranty claims related to the Improvements, (ii) claims for damages to the Property that have not been repaired as of Closing, and (iii) claims against tenants for unpaid rent or other charges for which Buyer is not credited at Closing.'

p_13.description: Review all 'Service Contracts' to determine which are terminable and which must be assumed, as this definition automatically includes them in the purchase.
p_13.title: Service Contract Review
p_13.user_recommendation: Review all 'Service Contracts' to determine which are terminable and which must be assumed, as this definition automatically includes them in the purchase.

p_14.description: While 'Leases' includes the agreements, it does not explicitly mention the transfer of the Seller's interest in security deposits, letters of credit, or prepaid rents. While often handled in prorations, explicitly including them in the asset definition ensures they are legally transferred via the Bill of Sale/Assignment of Leases.
p_14.problematic_text: all leases and other agreements to occupy the Real Property
p_14.title: Omission of Security Deposits
p_14.user_recommendation: Change to: 'all leases and other agreements to occupy the Real Property... together with all security deposits, letters of credit, and other credit enhancements held by Seller in connection therewith.'

p_14.description: Cross-reference this definition with the actual Rent Roll to ensure all licenses or 'agreements to occupy' (like cell tower leases or kiosk licenses) are captured.
p_14.title: Rent Roll Verification
