p_14.user_recommendation: Cross-reference this definition with the actual Rent Roll to ensure all licenses or 'agreements to occupy' (like cell tower leases or kiosk licenses) are captured.

p_154.description: The current language requires Seller's consent for assignment but does not require that consent to be reasonably withheld. This allows the Seller to arbitrarily block a legitimate transfer or demand a 'consent fee' to approve a transfer to a third party.
p_154.problematic_text: Buyer may not assign its interest under this Agreement without Seller's prior written consent
p_154.title: Unfettered Seller Discretion on Assignment
p_154.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Buyer may not assign its interest under this Agreement without Seller's prior written consent, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed.'

p_154.description: The definition of 'control' requires both majority ownership AND managerial control. This may be too restrictive for institutional buyers, private equity funds, or joint ventures where the Buyer entity might be managed by an affiliate that holds a minority stake or where the ownership is split 50/50.
p_154.problematic_text: “control” and similar terms mean ownership of a majority of the beneficial interest in, and managerial control over the assignee entity
p_154.title: Restrictive Definition of Control
p_154.user_recommendation: Change to: '“control” and similar terms mean (i) the direct or indirect ownership of more than fifty percent (50%) of the voting and/or beneficial interest in the assignee entity, or (ii) the power to direct the management and policies of such entity.'

p_154.description: Verify if the Buyer intends to remain liable after assignment. The clause is silent on whether the assignor is released. Usually, Sellers insist on the original Buyer remaining liable; if the Buyer wants a 'clean break' upon assignment to a well-capitalized affiliate, language must be added to release the original Buyer.
p_154.title: Original Buyer Liability
p_154.user_recommendation: Verify if the Buyer intends to remain liable after assignment. The clause is silent on whether the assignor is released. Usually, Sellers insist on the original Buyer remaining liable; if the Buyer wants a 'clean break' upon assignment to a well-capitalized affiliate, language must be added to release the original Buyer.

p_155.description: To effect a 1031 exchange, the Buyer must typically assign its rights to a Qualified Intermediary (QI). While the clause mentions cooperation, it should explicitly state that assignment to a QI is permitted without Seller's consent to avoid conflict with the restrictive assignment language in p_154.
p_155.problematic_text: both parties will cooperate to facilitate such an exchange
p_155.title: Lack of Qualified Intermediary Assignment Language
p_155.user_recommendation: Add: 'Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this Agreement, either party may assign its rights (but not its obligations) under this Agreement to a qualified intermediary for the purpose of effecting a tax-deferred exchange without the other party's consent.'

p_155.description: Cooperating in another party's 1031 exchange can expose the cooperating party to potential tax liabilities or legal costs if the exchange is challenged. The Buyer should be indemnified if the Seller's exchange causes issues.
p_155.problematic_text: neither party shall incur additional cost or expense on the other party's behalf
p_155.title: Missing 1031 Indemnity
p_155.user_recommendation: Add: 'The party requesting the exchange shall indemnify, defend, and hold the other party harmless from and against any and all liability, claims, or costs (including reasonable attorneys' fees) arising out of or in connection with the requesting party's 1031 exchange.'

p_156.description: The county for venue is left blank. This creates ambiguity and potential for jurisdictional disputes if a lawsuit is filed.
p_156.problematic_text: Venue for any dispute under this Agreement shall be in _________ County, Washington.
p_156.title: Missing Venue Designation
p_156.user_recommendation: Fill the blank with the county where the Property is located to ensure local jurisdiction.

p_156.description: Consider adding the word 'exclusive' before 'venue' to prevent the parties from attempting to move the case to federal court or another jurisdiction if they have diversity of citizenship.
p_156.title: Exclusive Venue
p_156.user_recommendation: Consider adding the word 'exclusive' before 'venue' to prevent the parties from attempting to move the case to federal court or another jurisdiction if they have diversity of citizenship.

p_158.description: Ensure all referenced exhibits (e.g., Legal Description, Bill of Sale form, Assignment of Leases form) are actually attached to the final execution version and have been reviewed for consistency with the main body of the PSA.
p_158.title: Exhibit Completeness
p_158.user_recommendation: Ensure all referenced exhibits (e.g., Legal Description, Bill of Sale form, Assignment of Leases form) are actually attached to the final execution version and have been reviewed for consistency with the main body of the PSA.

p_159.description: Verify that all critical dates in the agreement (Closing, Due Diligence expiration, etc.) are realistic and provide sufficient buffer, as 'Time is of the Essence' allows the Seller to terminate for even minor delays.
p_159.title: Strict Deadline Enforcement
p_159.user_recommendation: Verify that all critical dates in the agreement (Closing, Due Diligence expiration, etc.) are realistic and provide sufficient buffer, as 'Time is of the Essence' allows the Seller to terminate for even minor delays.

p_161.description: This clause allows the Seller to continue marketing the property and negotiating with other buyers even after the contract is signed, up until the end of the Due Diligence Period. This effectively turns the PSA into an 'option' for the Seller and puts the Buyer at risk of being 'gazumped' after spending significant money on inspections and legal fees.
p_161.problematic_text: Buyer understands and agrees that Seller shall have the right to continue to market the Property and/or to negotiate with other potential Buyers of the Property until the expiration of the Due Diligence Period and the satisfaction or waiver in writing of all conditions to the obligations of Buyer under this Agreement.
p_161.title: Lack of Exclusivity / Seller's Right to Market
p_161.user_recommendation: Delete the final sentence of p_161 in its entirety to ensure the Buyer has exclusive rights to the property upon execution.

p_163.description: The confidentiality clause does not include an exception for disclosures required by law, subpoena, or government regulation. This could put the Buyer in breach if they are legally compelled to disclose the contract terms (e.g., for tax filings, SEC requirements, or litigation).
p_163.problematic_text: provided that each party may disclose the terms of this Agreement to its lenders, partners, consultants and professional advisors as necessary or convenient for the completion of this transaction.
p_163.title: Narrow Confidentiality Exceptions
p_163.user_recommendation: Revise the proviso to read: 'provided that each party may disclose the terms of this Agreement (i) to its lenders, partners, affiliates, potential investors, consultants and professional advisors as necessary or convenient for the completion of this transaction, or (ii) as may be required by law, court order, or applicable government or securities regulations.'

p_169.description: The fragment suggests the Buyer is waiving the right to receive the 'balance' of a completed disclosure. This prevents the Buyer from having a full understanding of known property defects or history before proceeding.
p_169.problematic_text: s its right to receive the balance of the completed Seller Disclosure Statement.
p_169.title: Waiver of Right to Complete Disclosure
p_169.user_recommendation: Revise to ensure Buyer receives a fully completed Seller Disclosure Statement: 'Seller shall deliver a fully completed Seller Disclosure Statement within [X] days of the Effective Date.'

p_170.description: The clause exempts the Seller from updating the Disclosure Statement even if new material defects are discovered. This allows the Seller to remain silent about newly discovered issues (e.g., environmental leaks, structural failures) that occur between the initial disclosure and closing.
p_170.problematic_text: Buyer further agrees that any information discovered by Buyer concerning the Property shall not obligate Seller to prepare and deliver to Buyer a revised or updated Seller Disclosure Statement. Buyer hereby waives any right to receive an updated or revised Seller Disclosure Statement, regardless of the source of any new information.
p_170.title: Waiver of Updated Disclosures
p_170.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Seller shall be obligated to provide Buyer with an updated Seller Disclosure Statement within three (3) business days of Seller becoming aware of any material change in the condition of the Property or any information that makes the prior disclosure inaccurate.'

p_170.description: The Buyer is forced to warrant they are not relying on the Seller's Disclosure Statement. This 'non-reliance' clause is designed to defeat future claims of fraud or negligent misrepresentation, as the Buyer is contractually agreeing that the Seller's statements did not influence their decision to buy.
p_170.problematic_text: will acquire the Property solely on the basis of and in reliance upon such examinations and not on any information provided in any Seller Disclosure Statement
p_170.title: Disclaimer of Reliance on Disclosures
p_170.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'Buyer shall be entitled to rely on the accuracy of the information provided by Seller in the Seller Disclosure Statement, subject to the results of Buyer's independent inspections.'

p_170.description: Verify if the Buyer meets the legal definition of a 'sophisticated buyer' in the relevant jurisdiction, as this status is used here to justify the waiver of standard consumer/buyer protections.
p_170.title: Sophisticated Buyer Status
p_170.user_recommendation: Verify if the Buyer meets the legal definition of a 'sophisticated buyer' in the relevant jurisdiction, as this status is used here to justify the waiver of standard consumer/buyer protections.

p_171.description: In Washington State, RCW 64.06 provides buyers with a statutory right to rescind the agreement if the Seller Disclosure Statement is not provided or contains material errors. This clause waives that protection entirely, even for future updates.
p_171.problematic_text: BUYER HEREBY WAIVES, TO THE FULLEST EXTENT PERMISSIBLE BY LAW, THE RIGHT TO RESCIND THIS AGREEMENT PURSUANT TO ANY PROVISION OF RCW 64.06... THIS WAIVER OF THE RIGHT TO RESCIND APPLIES TO THE SELLER DISCLOSURE STATEMENT PROVIDED TO BUYER DURING THE REVIEW PERIOD AND APPLIES PROSPECTIVELY TO ANY UPDATED OR REVISED SELLER DISCLOSURE STATEMENTS
p_171.title: Waiver of Statutory Rescission Rights (RCW 64.06)
p_171.user_recommendation: Delete this paragraph in its entirety to preserve statutory rescission rights, or at minimum, add: '...provided, however, that Buyer does not waive the right to rescind in the event of intentional misrepresentation or fraud by Seller.'

p_171.description: Confirm if the property type (e.g., commercial vs. residential) triggers RCW 64.06. If the property is strictly commercial, the statute may not apply by default, but the inclusion of this waiver suggests the Seller is attempting to preempt any argument that it does.
p_171.title: Applicability of RCW 64.06
p_171.user_recommendation: Confirm if the property type (e.g., commercial vs. residential) triggers RCW 64.06. If the property is strictly commercial, the statute may not apply by default, but the inclusion of this waiver suggests the Seller is attempting to preempt any argument that it does.

p_174.description: Ensure the execution date is filled in accurately at the time of signing to establish the 'Effective Date' if the agreement relies on this for timeline calculations.
p_174.title: Execution Date
p_174.user_recommendation: Ensure the execution date is filled in accurately at the time of signing to establish the 'Effective Date' if the agreement relies on this for timeline calculations.

p_181.description: Verify that the individual signing has the legal authority to bind the Buyer entity.
p_181.title: Authorized Signatory
p_181.user_recommendation: Verify that the individual signing has the legal authority to bind the Buyer entity.

p_245.description: The clause expressly excludes all covenants arising by 'statutory or other implication.' In many jurisdictions, statutes provide implied covenants (such as the covenant against encumbrances) that protect the buyer. While this is a Special Warranty Deed, a blanket exclusion of all statutory protections can leave the buyer with less protection than is standard for a special warranty, particularly regarding the grantor's own acts.
p_245.problematic_text: excludes all covenants arising or to arise by statutory or other implication
p_245.title: Broad Exclusion of Statutory Warranties
p_245.user_recommendation: Change to: 'excludes all covenants arising or to arise by statutory or other implication, except to the extent such covenants are consistent with the limited warranty of title expressly set forth herein.'

p_259.description: Verify that the signature block for the Deed includes the correct notary acknowledgment form required by the state where the Real Property is located to ensure the deed is recordable.
p_259.title: Notary/Acknowledgment Requirement
p_259.user_recommendation: Verify that the signature block for the Deed includes the correct notary acknowledgment form required by the state where the Real Property is located to ensure the deed is recordable.

p_260.description: Confirm that the 'Attach Legal Description' placeholder is filled with the exact legal description from the Title Commitment and that it matches the Survey.
p_260.title: Legal Description Accuracy
p_260.user_recommendation: Confirm that the 'Attach Legal Description' placeholder is filled with the exact legal description from the Title Commitment and that it matches the Survey.

p_261.description: Ensure the list of Permitted Exceptions attached here matches the final list approved by Buyer during the Title/Survey review period.
p_261.title: Permitted Exceptions Consistency
p_261.user_recommendation: Ensure the list of Permitted Exceptions attached here matches the final list approved by Buyer during the Title/Survey review period.

p_265.description: The Bill of Sale 'sells, transfers and conveys' the property but does not explicitly state that the Seller owns the property free and clear of liens or that the Seller warrants title to the personal property. Without this, the Buyer may inadvertently take personal property subject to undisclosed security interests or third-party claims.
p_265.problematic_text: does hereby sell, transfer and convey to... all personal property owned by Seller
p_265.title: Lack of Title Warranty for Personal Property
p_265.user_recommendation: Change to: 'does hereby sell, transfer, and convey to Buyer, and warrants title to, all personal property owned by Seller... free and clear of all liens, security interests, and encumbrances.'

p_265.description: The Bill of Sale refers to 'all personal property owned by Seller and located on or in or used in connection with the Property.' If there are specific high-value items (e.g., specialized equipment, vehicles, or proprietary software systems), relying on a general description without a detailed Schedule I can lead to disputes over what was 'used in connection with' the property.
p_265.problematic_text: including, without limitation, those items described in Schedule I
p_265.title: Ambiguity in Personal Property Scope
p_265.user_recommendation: Ensure Schedule I is populated with a comprehensive inventory of all significant personal property, including serial numbers or specific identifiers where applicable.

p_267.description: While the seller warrants ownership, the provision lacks an explicit survival period and an indemnity clause. If a third-party lienholder (e.g., an equipment lessor or secured creditor) emerges after closing, the buyer may have limited recourse without a survival clause that extends beyond the deed recording.
p_267.problematic_text: Seller hereby represents and warrants to Buyer that Seller is the lawful owner of such personal property, and that such personal property is free and clear of all liens, encumbrances, conditional sales contracts, security interests and claims.
p_267.title: Lack of Survival and Indemnity for Personal Property Title
p_267.user_recommendation: Append the following: 'This representation and warranty shall survive the Closing for a period of [e.g., 12-24] months, and Seller shall indemnify, defend, and hold Buyer harmless from any claims, losses, or damages arising from a breach of this representation.'

p_284.description: Verify that a comprehensive, itemized list of all critical equipment, furniture, and fixtures is attached to this exhibit. Ensure serial numbers are included for high-value items to prevent 'swapping' prior to closing.
p_284.title: Inventory Verification
p_284.user_recommendation: Verify that a comprehensive, itemized list of all critical equipment, furniture, and fixtures is attached to this exhibit. Ensure serial numbers are included for high-value items to prevent 'swapping' prior to closing.

p_289.description: The title 'Assignment and Assumption' combined with a general preamble often leads to the Buyer (Assignee) inadvertently assuming all liabilities under the leases, including those that accrued prior to the closing date (e.g., unpaid tenant improvements, security deposit disputes, or landlord defaults).
p_289.problematic_text: THIS ASSIGNMENT AND ASSUMPTION OF LEASES (this “Assignment”)... is between [Assignor] and [Assignee].
p_289.title: Unrestricted Assumption of Lease Liabilities
p_289.user_recommendation: Ensure the body of this Assignment includes a 'Cut-Off' provision: 'Assignee assumes only those obligations under the Leases that arise and are performable from and after the Closing Date. Assignor shall remain solely liable for all obligations, defaults, and liabilities arising under the Leases prior to the Closing Date, and shall indemnify Assignee against the same.'

p_289.description: Confirm that the 'Assignor' entity is exactly the same legal entity as the 'Seller' in the main PSA, and that the 'Assignee' is the intended taking entity (or its permitted assignee).
p_289.title: Entity Consistency Check
p_289.user_recommendation: Confirm that the 'Assignor' entity is exactly the same legal entity as the 'Seller' in the main PSA, and that the 'Assignee' is the intended taking entity (or its permitted assignee).

p_291.description: The definition of 'Leases' is limited to those specifically described in Schedule I. If a lease, amendment, or letter of intent is inadvertently omitted from the schedule, the Buyer may lack the formal assignment of rights needed to enforce that lease or collect rent, despite owning the underlying property.
p_291.problematic_text: which leases are described in Schedule I attached hereto (the “Leases”)
p_291.title: Restrictive Definition of Leases
p_291.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'which leases are described in Schedule I attached hereto, together with all amendments, modifications, renewals, or extensions thereof, and all guaranties related thereto (collectively, the “Leases”).'

p_291.description: Cross-reference Schedule I of this Assignment against the certified Rent Roll and the Diligence Materials to ensure every active tenant and license agreement is listed.
p_291.title: Schedule I Reconciliation
p_291.user_recommendation: Cross-reference Schedule I of this Assignment against the certified Rent Roll and the Diligence Materials to ensure every active tenant and license agreement is listed.

p_293.description: Ensure the 'dated effective as of' date matches the final execution date of the Purchase and Sale Agreement to avoid incorporation by reference errors.
p_293.title: Consistency of Effective Date
p_293.user_recommendation: Ensure the 'dated effective as of' date matches the final execution date of the Purchase and Sale Agreement to avoid incorporation by reference errors.

p_299.description: The assignment transfers 'right, title and interest' in the Leases but does not explicitly mention the transfer of physical security deposits, letters of credit, or prepaid rents. Without explicit language, the Buyer may face claims from tenants for the return of deposits that the Seller failed to actually credit or transfer at closing.
p_299.problematic_text: Assignor hereby assigns to Assignee all of its right, title and interest in and to the Leases
p_299.title: Omission of Security Deposits and Prepaid Rents
p_299.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'Assignor hereby assigns to Assignee all of its right, title and interest in and to the Leases, including, without limitation, all security deposits, letters of credit, and prepaid rents held by Assignor in connection with the Leases.'

p_299.description: The paragraph assigns the leases but fails to allocate liability for breaches occurring before the Conveyance Date. The Buyer could be held liable by tenants for the Seller's prior defaults (e.g., failure to maintain the premises or overcharging CAM) without a clear indemnity from the Seller.
p_299.problematic_text: Assignor hereby assigns to Assignee all of its right, title and interest in and to the Leases;
p_299.title: Lack of Liability Allocation (Pre-Closing vs. Post-Closing)
p_299.user_recommendation: Add the following: 'Assignor shall indemnify and hold Assignee harmless from any claims or liabilities arising under the Leases prior to the Conveyance Date. Assignee shall indemnify and hold Assignor harmless from any claims or liabilities arising under the Leases from and after the Conveyance Date.'

p_299.description: Verify if any tenant security deposits are held as Letters of Credit. If so, ensure the assignment includes language requiring the Seller to cooperate in the formal transfer of the LC beneficiary rights with the issuing bank.
p_299.title: Letter of Credit Transfer Requirements
p_299.user_recommendation: Verify if any tenant security deposits are held as Letters of Credit. If so, ensure the assignment includes language requiring the Seller to cooperate in the formal transfer of the LC beneficiary rights with the issuing bank.

p_301.description: The indemnity is limited to 'obligations under the Leases.' This may not cover liabilities arising from the Seller's tortious acts, omissions, or negligence that occurred on the property prior to closing but are not strictly 'obligations' defined within the lease document itself.
p_301.problematic_text: arising out of the Assignor's obligations under the Leases
p_301.title: Narrow Scope of Seller Indemnity
p_301.user_recommendation: Change to: 'arising out of the Assignor's ownership of the Leases or the Assignor's acts or omissions related thereto occurring prior to the Conveyance Date.'

p_301.description: Verify that the survival period for this indemnity matches the general survival period for representations and warranties in the main Purchase and Sale Agreement (PSA).
p_301.title: Survival Period Alignment
p_301.user_recommendation: Verify that the survival period for this indemnity matches the general survival period for representations and warranties in the main Purchase and Sale Agreement (PSA).

p_303.description: The current language has the Buyer assuming 'all' obligations. Without qualifying that these are obligations 'to be performed after' the closing, the Buyer could inadvertently assume liability for the Seller's past breaches or unperformed maintenance that should have been completed prior to the Conveyance Date.
p_303.problematic_text: Assignee hereby assumes all of Assignor's obligations under the Leases
p_303.title: Broad Assumption of Past Obligations
p_303.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Assignee hereby assumes all of Assignor's obligations under the Leases first arising and required to be performed from and after the Conveyance Date.'

p_305.description: Ensure this 'prevailing party' clause does not conflict with the dispute resolution or arbitration sections in the main PSA (e.g., if the PSA requires mediation before fee-shifting applies).
p_305.title: Consistency with PSA Dispute Resolution
p_305.user_recommendation: Ensure this 'prevailing party' clause does not conflict with the dispute resolution or arbitration sections in the main PSA (e.g., if the PSA requires mediation before fee-shifting applies).

p_31.description: The Due Diligence Period is tied to a specific calendar date rather than a duration following the delivery of Due Diligence Documents. If the Seller delays delivery of the documents (allowed up to 3 business days or potentially longer if they breach), the Buyer's actual time to review those documents is reduced.
p_31.problematic_text: on or before 5 p.m. Pacific time on ____________________ (the period from the Effective Date through such date and time is referred to herein as the “Due Diligence Period”)
p_31.title: Fixed Due Diligence Expiration Date
p_31.user_recommendation: Change to a floating duration: 'on or before 5 p.m. Pacific time on the date that is [e.g., 30] days following the date Seller has delivered all Due Diligence Documents to Buyer.'

p_31.description: Review 'Schedule 1' immediately to ensure it includes all critical items: environmental reports, rent rolls, service contracts, utility bills, and historical maintenance records.
p_31.title: Verify Schedule 1 Completeness
p_31.user_recommendation: Review 'Schedule 1' immediately to ensure it includes all critical items: environmental reports, rent rolls, service contracts, utility bills, and historical maintenance records.

p_32.description: The Seller is disclaiming all responsibility for the accuracy or completeness of the documents provided. If the Seller provides an outdated or incorrect environmental report or rent roll, the Buyer may have no recourse for relying on that information unless it is specifically covered in Section 7.
p_32.problematic_text: without representation or warranty as to the accuracy or completeness of such materials
p_32.title: Disclaimer of Document Accuracy
p_32.user_recommendation: Revise to: '...without representation or warranty as to the accuracy or completeness of such materials, except that Seller represents and warrants that (i) the Due Diligence Documents provided constitute all material records regarding the Property in Seller's possession or control, and (ii) to Seller's knowledge, the documents provided are true, correct, and complete copies of the originals.'

p_32.description: Verify that Section 7 contains robust representations regarding the financial and physical status of the property to offset this disclaimer.
p_32.title: Cross-Reference Section 7
p_32.user_recommendation: Verify that Section 7 contains robust representations regarding the financial and physical status of the property to offset this disclaimer.

p_33.description: Limiting inspections to 'nonintrusive' prevents the Buyer from conducting Phase II environmental testing (e.g., soil borings) or invasive structural/roofing tests if the initial 'nonintrusive' inspection reveals a potential issue.
p_33.problematic_text: conduct such nonintrusive inspections, tests and studies
p_33.title: Restriction to Nonintrusive Inspections
p_33.user_recommendation: Add: '...provided, however, that if Buyer's initial inspections recommend further testing, Buyer may conduct intrusive testing subject to Seller's prior written consent, which shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed.'

p_33.description: The right of entry is restricted to the 'Due Diligence Period.' The Buyer may need access after this period for insurance appraisals, contractor estimates for planned improvements, or a final walk-through prior to Closing.
p_33.problematic_text: During the Due Diligence Period, Seller shall provide Buyer with reasonable access
p_33.title: Access Limited to Due Diligence Period
p_33.user_recommendation: Change 'During the Due Diligence Period' to 'From the Effective Date through the Closing Date'.

p_33.description: Fill the blank for advance notice. Recommend 24 or 48 hours to ensure the Buyer can move quickly during a short DD period.
p_33.title: Define Notice Period
p_33.user_recommendation: Fill the blank for advance notice. Recommend 24 or 48 hours to ensure the Buyer can move quickly during a short DD period.

p_337.description: Ensure the date of this Assignment is the actual Closing Date of the transaction to avoid gaps in liability or operational authority.
p_337.title: Effective Date Alignment
p_337.user_recommendation: Ensure the date of this Assignment is the actual Closing Date of the transaction to avoid gaps in liability or operational authority.

p_339.description: The definition of 'Contracts' is limited strictly to those listed on Schedule I. If a critical service contract is inadvertently omitted from the schedule, the Buyer may lack the legal standing to enforce it or benefit from its terms post-closing.
p_339.problematic_text: which service contracts are described in Schedule I attached hereto (the “Contracts”)
p_339.title: Restrictive Definition of Contracts
p_339.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'which service contracts are described in Schedule I attached hereto, and all other service contracts affecting the Property which Assignee has agreed to assume in writing (collectively, the “Contracts”).'

p_339.description: Cross-reference Schedule I against the list of Service Contracts approved during the Due Diligence period to ensure no critical utilities or maintenance agreements are missing.
p_339.title: Schedule I Reconciliation
p_339.user_recommendation: Cross-reference Schedule I against the list of Service Contracts approved during the Due Diligence period to ensure no critical utilities or maintenance agreements are missing.

p_341.description: Verify that the date and parties of the Purchase and Sale Agreement (PSA) are correctly inserted to ensure the incorporation by reference is legally valid.
p_341.title: PSA Reference Accuracy
p_341.user_recommendation: Verify that the date and parties of the Purchase and Sale Agreement (PSA) are correctly inserted to ensure the incorporation by reference is legally valid.

p_343.description: The phrase 'certain intangible personal property' is dangerously vague. It implies a limitation that could exclude critical assets like building warranties, permits, licenses, trade names, or architectural plans. As the Buyer, you want an assignment of *all* intangibles.
p_343.problematic_text: certain intangible personal property with respect to the Property
p_343.title: Vague Definition of Intangibles
p_343.user_recommendation: Change 'certain intangible personal property' to 'all intangible personal property owned by Assignor and used in connection with the Real Property and Improvements, including, without limitation, all warranties, guarantees, licenses, permits, approvals, certificates of occupancy, and trade names.'

p_347.description: The provision excludes all claims by the Assignor arising from matters before the Conveyance Date. This is problematic if there are outstanding warranty claims, insurance claims for property damage, or causes of action against contractors for defective work performed prior to closing. The Buyer needs these claims to offset the cost of repairs or to enforce warranties.
p_347.problematic_text: excluding claims by Assignor, if any, arising out of matters occurring before the Conveyance Date
p_347.title: Broad Exclusion of Pre-Closing Claims
p_347.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'excluding claims by Assignor, if any, arising out of matters occurring before the Conveyance Date, except to the extent such claims relate to the physical condition of the Property, warranties for Improvements, or the value of the Intangible Property from and after the Conveyance Date.'

p_347.description: Verify if any of the 'Contracts' or 'Intangible Property' require third-party consents for assignment. If so, ensure the main PSA requires Seller to obtain these consents as a condition to closing.
p_347.title: Contract Assignability
p_347.user_recommendation: Verify if any of the 'Contracts' or 'Intangible Property' require third-party consents for assignment. If so, ensure the main PSA requires Seller to obtain these consents as a condition to closing.

p_349.description: The Seller's indemnity is limited strictly to 'obligations under the Contracts.' It does not cover liabilities arising from the 'Intangible Property' (such as IP infringement or permit violations) or general liabilities related to the ownership/operation of the property prior to the Conveyance Date.
p_349.problematic_text: arising out of Assignor's obligations under the Contracts
p_349.title: Narrow Indemnity Scope
p_349.user_recommendation: Change to: 'arising out of Assignor's ownership or operation of the Property, the Intangible Property, or Assignor's obligations under the Contracts.'

p_349.description: The term 'originating' is ambiguous. It is unclear if it refers to when the underlying act occurred, when the obligation accrued, or when a third party filed a claim. Using 'accruing' or 'occurring' is standard for clarity.
p_349.problematic_text: originating prior to the Conveyance Date
p_349.title: Ambiguous Trigger for Indemnity
p_349.user_recommendation: Change to: 'accruing or arising out of acts or omissions occurring prior to the Conveyance Date'

p_35.description: The term 'reasonable advance notice' is subjective and could lead to disputes if the Seller believes notice was insufficient, potentially delaying inspections.
p_35.problematic_text: Buyer shall give Seller reasonable advance notice of such entry
p_35.title: Vague Notice Requirement
p_35.user_recommendation: Change 'reasonable advance notice' to 'at least twenty-four (24) hours’ prior notice (which may be given via email to Seller or Seller’s agent).'

p_35.description: Verify if there are any existing 'agreements' (e.g., complex tenant leases or property management contracts) that impose specific restrictions on entry that the Buyer must follow.
p_35.title: Compliance with 'Agreements'
p_35.user_recommendation: Verify if there are any existing 'agreements' (e.g., complex tenant leases or property management contracts) that impose specific restrictions on entry that the Buyer must follow.

p_351.description: The Buyer is assuming 'all' obligations under the Contracts. Without a temporal qualifier, the Buyer could be held liable for the Seller's pre-closing breaches or unpaid balances that existed prior to the Conveyance Date. The assumption should be limited to obligations first arising after the transfer.
p_351.problematic_text: Assignee hereby assumes all of Assignor's obligations under the Contracts
p_351.title: Unrestricted Assumption of Obligations
p_351.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Assignee hereby assumes all of Assignor's obligations under the Contracts to the extent such obligations first arise and are required to be performed from and after the Conveyance Date.'

p_351.description: Ensure the 'Conveyance Date' in this assignment matches the 'Closing Date' or 'Proration Date' in the main PSA to prevent gaps in liability coverage.
p_351.title: Proration Alignment
p_351.user_recommendation: Ensure the 'Conveyance Date' in this assignment matches the 'Closing Date' or 'Proration Date' in the main PSA to prevent gaps in liability coverage.

p_357.description: While the clause allows for counterparts, it does not explicitly authorize the delivery of signature pages via electronic means (PDF/DocuSign). In modern transactions, relying solely on 'originals' can cause delays or disputes regarding the validity of the execution if wet-ink originals are not immediately exchanged.
p_357.problematic_text: This Assignment may be executed in any number of counterparts, each of which shall be deemed an original, but all of which taken together shall constitute one and the same instrument.
p_357.title: Ambiguity Regarding Electronic Signatures
p_357.user_recommendation: Add the following: 'Delivery of an executed counterpart of this Assignment by facsimile or other electronic transmission (including .pdf or electronic signature) shall be equally as effective as delivery of a manually executed counterpart.'

p_36.description: Requiring the Buyer to restore the property to its 'prior condition' is an impossibly high standard for invasive testing (like soil borings or Phase II ESAs). It should be 'substantially the same' condition.
p_36.problematic_text: restore the Property to its prior condition
p_36.title: Strict Restoration Obligation
p_36.user_recommendation: Change to 'restore the Property to substantially the same condition as existed immediately prior to such inspections and tests.'

p_36.description: Confirm that the carve-out for 'non-negligent aggravation' is acceptable to Buyer's insurance carrier, as this is a favorable but specific protection for the Buyer.
p_36.title: Indemnity Carve-out Strength
p_36.user_recommendation: Confirm that the carve-out for 'non-negligent aggravation' is acceptable to Buyer's insurance carrier, as this is a favorable but specific protection for the Buyer.

p_37.description: Allowing insurance to be 'reasonably satisfactory to Seller' gives the Seller a potential 'back-door' way to delay inspections by rejecting the Buyer's insurance certificates.
p_37.problematic_text: with insurance limits and coverage reasonably satisfactory to Seller
p_37.title: Subjective Insurance Approval
p_37.user_recommendation: Delete 'reasonably satisfactory to Seller' and rely on the specific $2,000,000 limit mentioned, or specify the exact types of coverage required (e.g., Workers Comp, Auto).

p_377.description: The title 'Assignment and Assumption' suggests the Buyer will take on all obligations under the Service Contracts. Without specific 'cut-off' language in the actual form of this schedule, the Buyer risks assuming liabilities for Seller's pre-closing defaults or unpaid invoices.
p_377.problematic_text: Assignment and Assumption of Contracts and Intangible Property
p_377.title: Risk of Unfiltered Assumption of Liabilities
p_377.user_recommendation: Ensure the form of Assignment associated with this Schedule explicitly states: 'Assignee assumes only those obligations under the Service Contracts arising from and after the Closing Date, and Assignor shall remain liable for all obligations and liabilities arising prior to the Closing Date.'

p_377.description: Verify that the Buyer has the right to designate which Service Contracts are being assumed and which must be terminated by the Seller prior to closing, rather than a blanket assumption of all 'Intangible Property' as defined.
p_377.title: Verify Contract Termination Rights
p_377.user_recommendation: Verify that the Buyer has the right to designate which Service Contracts are being assumed and which must be terminated by the Seller prior to closing, rather than a blanket assumption of all 'Intangible Property' as defined.

p_38.description: The indemnity survives termination indefinitely. This creates a long-tail liability for the Buyer.
p_38.problematic_text: The terms of this Section 5.2 shall survive termination of this Agreement.
p_38.title: Indefinite Survival of Indemnity
p_38.user_recommendation: Add a time limit: 'The terms of this Section 5.2 shall survive termination of this Agreement for a period of nine (9) months.'

p_382.description: A 'Certificate of Rent Roll' is only as valuable as the standard of accuracy it guarantees. If the certificate is qualified by 'to the best of Seller's knowledge' or lacks a survival period, the Buyer has limited recourse if the rent, security deposits, or lease terms are discovered to be inaccurate post-closing.
p_382.title: Inadequate Rent Roll Certification
p_382.user_recommendation: Ensure the form of Certificate requires the Seller to certify that the Rent Roll is 'true, correct, and complete in all material respects' and that this certification survives the closing for the same period as the general Representations and Warranties.

p_382.description: Compare the data in the Rent Roll Certificate against Tenant Estoppel Certificates to identify discrepancies in security deposits or lease expiration dates.
p_382.title: Cross-Reference Rent Roll with Estoppels
p_382.user_recommendation: Compare the data in the Rent Roll Certificate against Tenant Estoppel Certificates to identify discrepancies in security deposits or lease expiration dates.

p_39.description: If the Buyer fails to send a notice by the deadline (due to administrative error or oversight), they are 'deemed' to have approved the property, making the deposit non-refundable. This is a 'hard' contingency.
p_39.problematic_text: If Buyer fails to deliver the Termination Notice to Seller on or before the expiration of the Due Diligence Period, Buyer shall be deemed to have timely provided an Approval Notice.
p_39.title: Deemed Approval (Silent Waiver)
p_39.user_recommendation: Change 'deemed to have timely provided an Approval Notice' to 'deemed to have timely provided a Termination Notice.' This ensures that if the Buyer is silent, the deal dies and the deposit is protected.

p_39.description: The requirement to 'diligently and in good faith pursue' due diligence is a subjective standard that a Seller could use to claim a breach of contract if the Buyer decides to terminate for a reason the Seller dislikes.
p_39.problematic_text: Buyer shall promptly commence, and shall diligently and in good faith pursue, its due diligence reviews hereunder
p_39.title: Subjective Performance Standard
p_39.user_recommendation: Delete 'and shall diligently and in good faith pursue'. The Buyer's right to terminate is already stated as being in its 'sole and absolute discretion,' which is the stronger and preferred standard.

p_39.description: The Buyer is required to give the Seller all third-party reports (which the Buyer paid for) upon termination. This provides a windfall to the Seller at the Buyer's expense.
p_39.problematic_text: upon Seller's written request, Buyer shall deliver to Seller copies of all third party reports, studies and test results regarding the Property procured or obtained by Buyer.
p_39.title: Uncompensated Delivery of Reports
p_39.user_recommendation: Add: '...provided that Seller shall reimburse Buyer for fifty percent (50%) of the actual, out-of-pocket cost of such reports.' Also, add that reports are delivered 'without representation or warranty and subject to the rights of the preparers.'

p_39.description: Confirm that 'sole and absolute discretion' is retained in the final version, as this is the most protective language for a Buyer's right to walk away.
p_39.title: Sole Discretion Standard
p_39.user_recommendation: Confirm that 'sole and absolute discretion' is retained in the final version, as this is the most protective language for a Buyer's right to walk away.

p_391.description: The Seller is qualifying the accuracy of the Rent Roll to 'actual knowledge, without investigating.' This 'head-in-the-sand' standard allows the Seller to avoid liability for inaccuracies that could have been discovered through a simple review of their own records. For a Buyer, the Rent Roll is a fundamental valuation document; its accuracy should be absolute or at least based on a diligent review of the leases.
p_391.problematic_text: to its actual knowledge, without investigating
p_391.title: Weak Knowledge Qualifier in Rent Roll Certification
p_391.user_recommendation: Delete 'to its actual knowledge, without investigating' and replace with 'Seller represents and warrants that...'

p_391.description: The use of 'in all material respects' regarding a Rent Roll is problematic. Specific financial figures such as security deposit amounts, monthly rent, and arrearages should be precise. A 'materiality' threshold allows for small discrepancies across many units that can aggregate into a significant financial shortfall for the Buyer post-closing.
p_391.problematic_text: true and correct in all material respects
p_391.title: Materiality Qualifier on Financial Data
p_391.user_recommendation: Change to 'true, correct, and complete.' If a materiality qualifier must remain, define it as a specific dollar threshold (e.g., 'in all respects except for variances not exceeding $500 in the aggregate').

p_391.description: Ensure that the 'attached Rent Roll' referenced in this certificate is the final, updated version provided at the end of the due diligence period, and not an outdated version from the initial offering.
p_391.title: Verification of Rent Roll Attachment
p_391.user_recommendation: Ensure that the 'attached Rent Roll' referenced in this certificate is the final, updated version provided at the end of the due diligence period, and not an outdated version from the initial offering.

p_391.description: Verify that the blank date for the certification is required to be as of the Closing Date or no more than 3-5 days prior to Closing to ensure the data is current.
p_391.title: Certification Date
p_391.user_recommendation: Verify that the blank date for the certification is required to be as of the Closing Date or no more than 3-5 days prior to Closing to ensure the data is current.

p_405.description: If the PSA mandates a specific 'Form of Estoppel Certificate' without allowing for lender-requested modifications, the Buyer may find the delivered estoppels insufficient to satisfy financing requirements. Lenders often require specific language regarding offsets, defaults, and subordination that may not be in a generic exhibit form.
p_405.title: Inflexible Estoppel Form
p_405.user_recommendation: Revise the reference to the exhibit in the main body of the PSA to state: '...in the form attached hereto as Exhibit [X], or such other form as may be reasonably required by Buyer’s lender, provided that Seller shall not be required to request a tenant to provide an estoppel in a form more extensive than required under such tenant’s Lease.'

p_405.description: Verify with the Buyer's lender whether the form attached as [p_405] contains the necessary certifications regarding 'no defaults,' 'no prepaid rent,' and 'no landlord obligations for TIs/commissions.'
p_405.title: Lender Requirements
p_405.user_recommendation: Verify with the Buyer's lender whether the form attached as [p_405] contains the necessary certifications regarding 'no defaults,' 'no prepaid rent,' and 'no landlord obligations for TIs/commissions.'

p_41.description: The condition only requires that items be 'delivered.' It does not specify that they must be executed, acknowledged (where necessary), or in a form and substance reasonably satisfactory to the Buyer. This could allow a Seller to technically satisfy the condition by delivering non-conforming or poorly drafted documents.
p_41.problematic_text: Seller shall have delivered those items described in Section 11.3 hereof
p_41.title: Vague Delivery Standard
p_41.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Seller shall have executed and delivered those items described in Section 11.3 hereof, in form and substance reasonably satisfactory to Buyer and, where applicable, in recordable form;'

p_41.description: Verify that Section 11.3 (referenced in p_41) and Section 8.1 (referenced in p_81) are consistent and include all necessary closing documents (Deed, Bill of Sale, Assignment of Leases, FIRPTA, etc.).
p_41.title: Cross-Reference Check
p_41.user_recommendation: Verify that Section 11.3 (referenced in p_41) and Section 8.1 (referenced in p_81) are consistent and include all necessary closing documents (Deed, Bill of Sale, Assignment of Leases, FIRPTA, etc.).

p_411.description: A static checklist often omits critical items such as environmental 'Phase I' reports, structural/mechanical surveys, historical utility bills, or unrecorded licenses/permits. If the Seller is only obligated to provide items on this specific list, the Buyer may be deprived of material information during the contingency period.
p_411.title: Incomplete Due Diligence Checklist
p_411.user_recommendation: Add a 'catch-all' provision to the end of the checklist: '...and any and all other material documents, reports, studies, or correspondence in Seller’s possession or control relating to the ownership, operation, maintenance, or physical condition of the Property.'

p_411.description: Confirm that the 'Due Diligence Period' or 'Inspection Period' does not commence until the Seller has delivered all items listed in [p_411] to the Buyer's data room.
p_411.title: Due Diligence Clock
p_411.user_recommendation: Confirm that the 'Due Diligence Period' or 'Inspection Period' does not commence until the Seller has delivered all items listed in [p_411] to the Buyer's data room.

p_42.description: While the definition of 'Title Policy' includes endorsements, this condition should explicitly state that the commitment includes the specific endorsements requested during the Due Diligence Period. Furthermore, it should specify that the commitment is at standard rates to prevent the Title Company from demanding extraordinary premiums to cover risks that should be Seller's responsibility to clear.
p_42.problematic_text: Title Company shall be irrevocably committed to issue the Title Policy pursuant to Section 4 hereof
p_42.title: Omission of Endorsements and Premium Terms
p_42.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Title Company shall be irrevocably committed to issue the Title Policy (including all endorsements requested by Buyer pursuant to Section 4) at standard premium rates;'

p_43.description: The phrase 'in all material respects' creates a 'double materiality' hurdle if the underlying representations in Section 5.2 already contain materiality qualifiers (e.g., 'Seller has no material knowledge of...'). This makes it significantly harder for a Buyer to claim a condition has failed because they must prove the breach itself was material on top of the existing qualifier.
p_43.problematic_text: true, accurate and complete in all material respects
p_43.title: Double Materiality Qualifier
p_43.user_recommendation: Change to: 'true, accurate and complete in all respects (provided that any representation or warranty already qualified by materiality shall be true and correct in all respects);'

p_43.description: The paragraph makes the truth of reps a condition, but it does not explicitly require the Seller to deliver a 'Bring-Down Certificate' at closing. Without a formal certificate, the Buyer may lack a clear document to sue upon if reps are later found to be false as of the Closing Date.
p_43.problematic_text: Each representation and warranty made by Seller in this Agreement shall be true, accurate and complete
p_43.title: Lack of 'Bring-Down' Certificate Requirement
p_43.user_recommendation: Add: '...and Seller shall have delivered a certificate to Buyer at Closing, dated as of the Closing Date, certifying the same.'

p_44.description: The condition only requires that estoppels be 'substantially in the form of Exhibit H.' It does not require that the estoppels be 'clean' (i.e., that they do not disclose tenant defaults, landlord defaults, or claims of offset). A tenant could return an estoppel in the correct form but disclose a massive landlord default, and the Seller would technically satisfy this condition.
p_44.problematic_text: Seller shall have delivered the Minimum Tenant Estoppels, each substantially in the form of Exhibit H attached hereto.
p_44.title: Lack of 'Clean' Estoppel Requirement
p_44.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Seller shall have delivered the Minimum Tenant Estoppels, each substantially in the form of Exhibit H, and none of which shall disclose any material default by landlord or tenant, any claim of offset, or any other information materially inconsistent with the Leases or Seller’s representations.'

p_44.description: The lead-in paragraph [p_40] says conditions must be met 'at or prior to Closing.' If the Seller delivers the Minimum Tenant Estoppels five minutes before Closing, the Buyer has no time to review them or verify the information with tenants. This creates significant operational and financial risk.
p_44.problematic_text: at or prior to the Closing
p_44.title: Timing of Estoppel Delivery
p_44.user_recommendation: Add to p_44: '...which Estoppels shall be delivered to Buyer no later than five (5) business days prior to the Closing Date.'

p_44.description: The defined term 'Minimum Tenant Estoppels' contains blanks for percentages and square footage. Ensure these are filled with high thresholds (e.g., 75-100% of square footage and all 'Major Tenants').
p_44.title: Verify Estoppel Thresholds
p_44.user_recommendation: The defined term 'Minimum Tenant Estoppels' contains blanks for percentages and square footage. Ensure these are filled with high thresholds (e.g., 75-100% of square footage and all 'Major Tenants').

p_50.description: The clause requires the Buyer to pay half of the escrow cancellation fees regardless of why the agreement is terminated (unless under Section 13). If the Seller defaults or a condition precedent fails through no fault of the Buyer, the Buyer should not be penalized with these costs.
p_50.problematic_text: the parties shall equally share any cancellation fee of the Escrow Holder.
p_50.title: Unfair Allocation of Cancellation Fees
p_50.user_recommendation: Change to: 'the parties shall equally share any cancellation fee of the Escrow Holder; provided, however, that if this Agreement is terminated due to a Seller default, Seller shall pay all such cancellation fees.'

p_50.description: Verify that Section 13 (referenced in p_50) adequately covers Seller Default and provides for the return of the Deposit to the Buyer.
p_50.title: Cross-reference Section 13
p_50.user_recommendation: Verify that Section 13 (referenced in p_50) adequately covers Seller Default and provides for the return of the Deposit to the Buyer.

p_53.description: While the paragraph states the agreement doesn't violate contracts, it does not explicitly state that no third-party or governmental consents are required for the Seller to complete the sale. This could lead to delays or legal challenges if a lender or partner consent is missing.
p_53.problematic_text: do not, and at the time of Closing, will not, violate any provisions of any contract or judicial order to which Seller is a party or to which Seller is subject.
p_53.title: Missing Representation on Consents
p_53.user_recommendation: Add: 'and no consent, waiver, approval or authorization of, or filing with, any person or governmental authority is required in connection with the execution and delivery of this Agreement by Seller.'

p_53.description: There is no representation that the Seller is not currently involved in bankruptcy proceedings or is not insolvent. This is a standard protection for Buyers to ensure the transaction isn't voidable as a fraudulent transfer.
p_53.title: Lack of Anti-Insolvency Representation
p_53.user_recommendation: Add: 'Seller has not (i) made a general assignment for the benefit of creditors, (ii) filed any voluntary petition in bankruptcy, or (iii) received notice of any involuntary petition in bankruptcy filed against it.'

p_54.description: The Rent Roll is the primary basis for property valuation. Qualifying this representation with 'Seller's Actual Knowledge'—especially when the defined term 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' explicitly disclaims any duty to investigate—is highly risky for the Buyer. The Seller should be able to warrant the accuracy of their own financial records absolutely.
p_54.problematic_text: To Seller's Actual Knowledge, the rent roll identified in the Due Diligence Documents (the “Rent Roll”) is true and correct in all material respects.
p_54.title: Weak Knowledge Qualifier for Rent Roll
p_54.user_recommendation: Remove 'To Seller's Actual Knowledge,' or at a minimum, revise the definition of 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' to include a duty of reasonable inquiry of the property manager.

p_54.description: The phrase 'in all material respects' is subjective. In a large multi-tenant property, small errors across many leases can aggregate into a significant financial discrepancy that the Seller might argue is not 'material' to the whole deal.
p_54.problematic_text: is true and correct in all material respects.
p_54.title: Vague Materiality Standard
p_54.user_recommendation: Change to: 'is true, correct, and complete.' If materiality must remain, define it (e.g., 'material' means any discrepancy exceeding $X,XXX in annual aggregate rent).

p_54.description: The definition of 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' contains a blank space for a name. Ensure a specific individual (e.g., the Asset Manager or Principal) is named and that they are the person most likely to have knowledge of the property's operations.
p_54.title: Identify Knowledge Party
p_54.user_recommendation: The definition of 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' contains a blank space for a name. Ensure a specific individual (e.g., the Asset Manager or Principal) is named and that they are the person most likely to have knowledge of the property's operations.

p_60.description: The 'deemed to have known' provision creates an imputed knowledge standard. It allows the Seller to escape liability for a false representation if the truth was buried anywhere in the 'Property Information' (data room, reports, etc.), even if the Buyer did not actually see it. This effectively shifts the burden of the Seller's honesty onto the Buyer's diligence team.
p_60.problematic_text: Buyer shall be “deemed to have known” that a representation or warranty was untrue, inaccurate or incorrect at the time of the Closing if any Property Information furnished or made available to or otherwise obtained by Buyer contains express information which is inconsistent with such representation or warranty.
p_60.title: Constructive Knowledge/Anti-Sandbagging Clause
p_60.user_recommendation: Delete the 'deemed to have known' sentence entirely. If Seller insists on a knowledge waiver, limit it to the 'Actual Knowledge' of specific named individuals on the Buyer's team, and exclude information merely 'made available' in a data room.

p_60.description: The $50,000 floor is a 'basket' that prevents the Buyer from recovering for any breaches that don't meet this high dollar amount. Depending on the purchase price, $50,000 may be too high, allowing the Seller to make multiple 'small' misrepresentations with impunity.
p_60.problematic_text: Buyer’s damages as a result of such representations or warranties being untrue, inaccurate or incorrect are, in the aggregate, less than $50,000
p_60.title: High Minimum Claim Threshold (Basket)
p_60.user_recommendation: Lower the threshold to a more reasonable amount (e.g., $10,000 or $25,000) and clarify that once the threshold is met, the Buyer is entitled to recover from the first dollar (a 'tipping basket') rather than just the excess.

p_60.description: Cross-reference the definition of 'Property Information' in Section 1. If it is defined broadly to include all documents provided by Seller, the risk in B12_R1 is significantly amplified.
p_60.title: Definition of Property Information
p_60.user_recommendation: Cross-reference the definition of 'Property Information' in Section 1. If it is defined broadly to include all documents provided by Seller, the risk in B12_R1 is significantly amplified.

p_61.description: The cap applies not just to representations and warranties, but also to 'covenants and other obligations.' This is dangerous for a Buyer. If the Seller fails to perform a post-closing covenant (like a tax proration or a repair obligation), their liability should not be capped. Furthermore, there is no exception for fraud or intentional misrepresentation.
p_61.problematic_text: the aggregate liability of either party arising pursuant to or in connection with the representations, warranties, covenants and other obligations (whether express or implied) of such party in this Agreement... shall not exceed $___________
p_61.title: Overly Broad Liability Cap
p_61.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'the aggregate liability of Seller for breaches of representations and warranties shall not exceed [Amount]... provided, however, that this cap shall not apply to (i) Seller's breach of any covenants, (ii) Seller's fraud or intentional misrepresentation, or (iii) Seller's indemnity obligations regarding [specific items like brokers or taxes].'

p_61.description: The liability cap is currently blank. Without a negotiated amount, the Buyer's potential recovery is undefined, and the Seller will likely push for a very low percentage of the purchase price.
p_61.title: Undefined Liability Cap Amount
p_61.user_recommendation: Insert a specific dollar amount or percentage. For a Buyer, a typical cap ranges from 5% to 10% of the purchase price, though some Buyers push for higher or no cap at all.

p_61.description: Verify if the Buyer's liability should also be capped here. Usually, Buyer's liability is limited to the Earnest Money Deposit as liquidated damages. Ensure this cap doesn't conflict with or expand the Buyer's liability beyond the deposit.
p_61.title: Mutual Cap Applicability
p_61.user_recommendation: Verify if the Buyer's liability should also be capped here. Usually, Buyer's liability is limited to the Earnest Money Deposit as liquidated damages. Ensure this cap doesn't conflict with or expand the Buyer's liability beyond the deposit.

p_63.description: Ensure the Buyer entity is properly formed and in good standing in its home state and the state where the property is located before signing.
p_63.title: Entity Authority
p_63.user_recommendation: Ensure the Buyer entity is properly formed and in good standing in its home state and the state where the property is located before signing.

p_64.description: Confirm that entering into this Agreement does not violate any of Buyer's existing loan documents or joint venture agreements.
p_64.title: Conflict Check
p_64.user_recommendation: Confirm that entering into this Agreement does not violate any of Buyer's existing loan documents or joint venture agreements.

p_65.description: A six-month survival period is relatively short for commercial real estate. Latent issues (such as tax liabilities or undisclosed litigation) often take longer than six months to surface after the closing date.
p_65.problematic_text: survive for a period of six (6) months from the Closing Date
p_65.title: Short Survival Period
p_65.user_recommendation: Change 'six (6) months' to 'nine (9) months' or 'twelve (12) months' to allow for a full operating cycle and tax year to pass.

p_65.description: The clause requires the Buyer to actually commence litigation within the Survival Period to preserve a claim. This is overly aggressive; typically, providing written notice of a claim within the period is sufficient to preserve it.
p_65.problematic_text: any cause of action resulting from a breach thereof not then in litigation
p_65.title: Requirement to Commence Litigation
p_65.user_recommendation: Change to: 'any cause of action resulting from a breach thereof for which Buyer has not provided Seller with written notice of a claim prior to the expiration of the Survival Period'.

p_65.description: Verify that Sections 7.1 and 7.2 (referenced in p_65) and Sections 7(a) and (b) (referenced later in the same paragraph) are consistent and cover all critical Seller representations. The discrepancy in numbering (7.1 vs 7(a)) suggests a potential drafting error.
p_65.title: Cross-Reference Verification
p_65.user_recommendation: Verify that Sections 7.1 and 7.2 (referenced in p_65) and Sections 7(a) and (b) (referenced later in the same paragraph) are consistent and cover all critical Seller representations. The discrepancy in numbering (7.1 vs 7(a)) suggests a potential drafting error.

p_66.description: If a representation becomes untrue before closing, the Buyer's only remedy is to terminate the agreement. This prevents the Buyer from closing and seeking damages (indemnification) even if the Seller caused the breach or if the Buyer still wants the property but needs to be made whole for the diminished value.
p_66.problematic_text: Buyer’s termination of this Agreement shall be Buyer’s sole remedy against Seller in the circumstances described in this paragraph.
p_66.title: Sole Remedy Limitation for Rep Breaches
p_66.user_recommendation: Revise to allow Buyer to seek damages if the change in representation resulted from a voluntary act or omission by Seller, or allow for a purchase price reduction.

p_66.description: The Buyer can only terminate if the change has a 'material adverse impact' in Buyer's 'reasonable judgment.' This is a high bar and could lead to disputes over what constitutes 'material' if the Buyer wants to walk away from a tainted deal.
p_66.problematic_text: if in Buyer’s reasonable judgment such change in condition or new information has a material adverse impact on the Property or on the Buyer
p_66.title: Subjective Materiality Threshold
p_66.user_recommendation: Remove 'material adverse impact' and replace with 'if such change is unacceptable to Buyer in its sole but reasonable discretion' or define a specific dollar threshold for materiality.

p_68.description: A 5-day window for Buyer to object to new leases or modifications is extremely short. If the Buyer fails to respond within this window, they are 'conclusively deemed' to have approved the lease, which could include unfavorable terms or high tenant improvement costs.
p_68.problematic_text: Buyer's consent shall conclusively be deemed granted if Buyer does not object... within five (5) days
p_68.title: Short Deemed Approval Period for Leases
p_68.user_recommendation: Increase the response period to 'ten (10) business days'.

p_68.description: The clause makes Buyer responsible for all leasing commissions and TI costs for leases approved after the DD period. This should be contingent on the Closing actually occurring.
p_68.problematic_text: from and after Closing Buyer shall be responsible for all leasing commissions, tenant improvements and other costs payable by the Landlord thereunder.
p_68.title: Unconditional Buyer Liability for New Lease Costs
p_68.user_recommendation: Clarify that Buyer is only responsible for costs 'to the extent first arising or payable after the Closing Date' and ensure Seller remains liable for any costs related to leases signed prior to the end of the Due Diligence Period.

p_68.description: Confirm that the property management agreement can be terminated 'as of Closing' without penalty to the Buyer, and that Seller is responsible for any termination fees.
p_68.title: Property Management Termination
p_68.user_recommendation: Confirm that the property management agreement can be terminated 'as of Closing' without penalty to the Buyer, and that Seller is responsible for any termination fees.

p_69.description: Seller is not obligated to terminate Service Contracts if it creates 'additional cost or liability.' This could force the Buyer to assume contracts they explicitly rejected during Due Diligence if those contracts have termination fees.
p_69.problematic_text: provided that Seller shall not be obligated to terminate any Service Contract if such termination will create any additional cost or liability for Seller.
p_69.title: Seller's Refusal to Terminate Contracts
p_69.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'Seller shall terminate all Service Contracts not assumed by Buyer at Seller's sole cost and expense, including any termination fees or penalties.'

p_82.description: The defined terms specify a 'special warranty deed.' In Washington, this only warrants against defects arising during the Seller's period of ownership. A Buyer typically prefers a 'Statutory Warranty Deed,' which provides broader protection against title defects regardless of when they arose.
p_82.problematic_text: The Deed conveying to Buyer the Real Property
p_82.title: Limited Title Warranty (Special Warranty Deed)
p_82.user_recommendation: Change 'special warranty deed' in the Defined Terms to 'statutory warranty deed' and ensure p_82 reflects the conveyance via Statutory Warranty Deed.

p_82.description: Verify that the agreement requires both Buyer and Seller to execute the Real Estate Excise Tax (REET) Affidavit, as Washington law generally requires both signatures for processing.
p_82.title: REET Affidavit Execution
p_82.user_recommendation: Verify that the agreement requires both Buyer and Seller to execute the Real Estate Excise Tax (REET) Affidavit, as Washington law generally requires both signatures for processing.

p_83.description: Review Exhibit C (Bill of Sale) to ensure it includes a warranty of title for personal property and explicitly includes all 'Improvements' and 'Personal Property' defined in the agreement.
p_83.title: Bill of Sale Scope
p_83.user_recommendation: Review Exhibit C (Bill of Sale) to ensure it includes a warranty of title for personal property and explicitly includes all 'Improvements' and 'Personal Property' defined in the agreement.

p_84.description: The paragraph mentions assigning interest in the Leases but does not explicitly mention the transfer of or credit for tenant security deposits. Without explicit language, there may be a dispute over whether the cash for deposits is transferred at closing.
p_84.problematic_text: assigning and conveying to Buyer the Seller's interest in, to and under the Leases
p_84.title: Security Deposit Transfer
p_84.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'assigning and conveying to Buyer the Seller's interest in, to and under the Leases, including all tenant security deposits and prepaid rents held by Seller.'

p_85.description: Delivering original leases 'outside of Escrow' means the Escrow Agent cannot verify delivery before releasing funds. If Seller fails to hand over the physical files at the property, Buyer has little leverage post-closing.
p_85.problematic_text: to be delivered outside of Escrow
p_85.title: Delivery Outside of Escrow
p_85.user_recommendation: Change to: 'to be delivered to Buyer at the Real Property on the Closing Date, with confirmation of receipt provided to Escrow as a condition to Closing.'

p_85.description: The qualifier 'in Seller's possession or control' allows Seller to avoid providing leases they may have lost or misplaced. Buyer needs all original leases to enforce rights against tenants.
p_85.title: Possession or Control Limitation
p_85.user_recommendation: Add: '...in Seller's possession or control; provided, however, if any originals are missing, Seller shall provide a lost lease affidavit in a form reasonably acceptable to Buyer.'

p_85.description: Ensure Exhibit F (Certificate of Rent Roll) requires the Seller to certify the rent roll as of the actual Closing Date, not the date the PSA was signed.
p_85.title: Rent Roll Currency
p_85.user_recommendation: Ensure Exhibit F (Certificate of Rent Roll) requires the Seller to certify the rent roll as of the actual Closing Date, not the date the PSA was signed.

p_86.description: The phrase 'to be continued by Buyer' implies a selection process that may not be clearly defined elsewhere. If the list of assumed contracts isn't finalized before closing, Buyer might inadvertently assume unwanted liabilities.
p_86.problematic_text: Service Contracts to be continued by Buyer after the Closing
p_86.title: Ambiguity in Assumed Contracts
p_86.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'Service Contracts which Buyer has elected to assume pursuant to Section [Insert Section Number regarding Contract Election] of this Agreement.'

p_86.description: Verify if any Service Contracts require third-party consent to assign and ensure Seller is obligated to obtain those consents prior to Closing.
p_86.title: Contract Consents
p_86.user_recommendation: Verify if any Service Contracts require third-party consent to assign and ensure Seller is obligated to obtain those consents prior to Closing.

p_87.description: The phrase 'to be continued by Buyer' is ambiguous. It could be interpreted as a requirement that the Buyer must assume all existing contracts in the Seller's possession, rather than only those the Buyer specifically elects to assume during the due diligence period. This could force the Buyer into unfavorable vendor relationships.
p_87.problematic_text: to be continued by Buyer after the Closing
p_87.title: Ambiguity Regarding Assumption of Service Contracts
p_87.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'which Buyer has expressly elected to assume pursuant to the terms of this Agreement.'

p_87.description: Verify that the 'outside of Escrow' delivery mechanism includes a requirement for a signed receipt or confirmation, as Escrow will not be tracking these documents.
p_87.title: Verification of Contract Delivery
p_87.user_recommendation: Verify that the 'outside of Escrow' delivery mechanism includes a requirement for a signed receipt or confirmation, as Escrow will not be tracking these documents.

p_88.description: Allowing the form to be 'reasonably required by the Escrow Holder' may not sufficiently protect the Buyer. As the withholding agent under FIRPTA, the Buyer bears the risk if the affidavit does not strictly comply with IRS Section 1445 requirements. The Buyer should ensure the form meets statutory standards to qualify for the 'Reduced Withholding' or 'Exemption' safe harbor.
p_88.problematic_text: in the form reasonably required by the Escrow Holder
p_88.title: FIRPTA Compliance Form Control
p_88.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'in the form required by Section 1445 of the Internal Revenue Code and the regulations thereunder, and otherwise reasonably acceptable to Buyer and Escrow Holder.'

p_89.description: Confirm that the Seller is obligated to provide 'Seller-Affidavits' or 'Gap Indemnities' if required by the Title Company to issue the specific endorsements requested by Buyer.
p_89.title: Title Endorsement Requirements
p_89.user_recommendation: Confirm that the Seller is obligated to provide 'Seller-Affidavits' or 'Gap Indemnities' if required by the Title Company to issue the specific endorsements requested by Buyer.

p_90.description: The paragraph explicitly requires the closing statement to be approved in writing by the Seller, but is silent on the Buyer's approval. Both parties must approve the final settlement of prorations, credits, and expenses to prevent unilateral changes by the Seller or Escrow Holder.
p_90.title: Missing Buyer Approval of Closing Statement
p_90.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'approved in writing by Seller and Buyer'

p_91.description: A simple 'notice of sale' is insufficient for post-closing operations. To ensure a smooth transition and protect the Buyer's cash flow, the notice must explicitly direct tenants to pay rent to the new owner/manager and acknowledge the transfer of security deposits to the Buyer (to prevent tenants from seeking refunds from the Seller).
p_91.problematic_text: notifying the tenants under the Leases of the sale of the property
p_91.title: Insufficient Detail in Tenant Notice
p_91.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'notifying the tenants under the Leases of the sale of the Property, the transfer of security deposits to Buyer, and providing direction for the payment of rent and other charges following the Closing, in a form reasonably approved by Buyer.'

p_92.description: The phrase 'or otherwise' is overly broad and could be interpreted to allow the Seller or a third party to demand additional, unspecified documents or 'correspondence' as a condition to closing, creating potential delays or administrative burdens.
p_92.problematic_text: or otherwise to close the Escrow and consummate the purchase of the Property
p_92.title: Vague Catch-all for Closing Documents
p_92.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'or as reasonably required by Escrow Holder or the Title Company to close the Escrow and consummate the purchase of the Property...'

p_92.description: Verify if there is any specific 'correspondence' intended to be delivered at closing (e.g., notices to tenants). If not, 'correspondence' should be deleted from this paragraph to avoid confusion.
p_92.title: Verification of Required Correspondence
p_92.user_recommendation: Verify if there is any specific 'correspondence' intended to be delivered at closing (e.g., notices to tenants). If not, 'correspondence' should be deleted from this paragraph to avoid confusion.

p_93.description: Allowing deliveries 'on' the Closing Date can lead to failed closings or 'dry' closings if the Escrow Holder does not receive funds and documents early enough to record and disburse. If 'time is of the essence' applies to the Closing Date, the Buyer risks default if a wire is delayed.
p_93.problematic_text: On or before the Closing Date
p_93.title: Timing of Buyer Deliveries
p_93.user_recommendation: Change to: 'At least one (1) Business Day prior to the Closing Date (or such earlier timeframe as may be required by Escrow Holder)'

p_94.description: Confirm that the 'Closing Payment' definition or the general payment section specifies 'immediately available wire transfer funds' to ensure the Buyer is not penalized for check clearing times.
p_94.title: Payment Method Confirmation
p_94.user_recommendation: Confirm that the 'Closing Payment' definition or the general payment section specifies 'immediately available wire transfer funds' to ensure the Buyer is not penalized for check clearing times.

p_95.description: Verify which party is responsible for paying the Real Estate Excise Tax (REET). While both parties usually sign the affidavit, the Seller typically pays the tax in most jurisdictions. Ensure the 'Prorations' section aligns with this delivery requirement.
p_95.title: Excise Tax Responsibility
p_95.user_recommendation: Verify which party is responsible for paying the Real Estate Excise Tax (REET). While both parties usually sign the affidavit, the Seller typically pays the tax in most jurisdictions. Ensure the 'Prorations' section aligns with this delivery requirement.

p_96.description: The requirement to execute an 'Assignment and Assumption' of leases implies the Buyer is taking on contractual obligations. Without specific limiting language, the Buyer might inadvertently assume liabilities or defaults created by the Seller prior to the Closing Date.
p_96.problematic_text: Assignment and Assumption of Leases duly executed by Buyer
p_96.title: Assumption of Pre-Closing Lease Liabilities
p_96.user_recommendation: Add: '...provided that such Assignment and Assumption of Leases shall limit Buyer's assumption of obligations to those arising and accruing from and after the Closing Date.'

p_96.description: Review Exhibit D (Assignment and Assumption of Leases) to ensure it contains a robust indemnity from Seller for all lease-related liabilities accruing prior to the Closing Date.
p_96.title: Exhibit D Review
p_96.user_recommendation: Review Exhibit D (Assignment and Assumption of Leases) to ensure it contains a robust indemnity from Seller for all lease-related liabilities accruing prior to the Closing Date.
