p_97.description: Verify that the form of Assignment of Contracts and Intangibles in Exhibit E includes appropriate representations from Seller regarding the validity and status of the contracts being assigned, and that Buyer is only assuming obligations arising after the Closing Date.
p_97.title: Review Exhibit E (Assignment of Contracts)
p_97.user_recommendation: Verify that the form of Assignment of Contracts and Intangibles in Exhibit E includes appropriate representations from Seller regarding the validity and status of the contracts being assigned, and that Buyer is only assuming obligations arising after the Closing Date.

p_98.description: Confirm with tax counsel or a local CPA whether a consumer use tax return is required for this specific jurisdiction and whether the Buyer or Seller is responsible for the actual calculation of the tax due on Personal Property.
p_98.title: Local Use Tax Compliance
p_98.user_recommendation: Confirm with tax counsel or a local CPA whether a consumer use tax return is required for this specific jurisdiction and whether the Buyer or Seller is responsible for the actual calculation of the tax due on Personal Property.

risk_inventory.description: The term 'delivered' is not defined. In a dispute, it may be unclear whether delivery occurs upon hitting 'send' on an email, physical receipt by a party, or receipt by their respective legal counsel. Since the Effective Date triggers all contingency periods (due diligence, financing, etc.), any ambiguity can lead to missed deadlines.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: executed and delivered by the last of Buyer and Seller
risk_inventory.title: Ambiguity in 'Delivery' for Effective Date
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'executed and delivered (including delivery by electronic transmission/email) by the last of Buyer and Seller'

risk_inventory.description: The preamble identifies a specific 'Buyer' without mentioning 'and/or assigns.' While assignment is often covered in a later boilerplate section, failing to establish the right to assign to a related entity (e.g., an LLC formed for the purchase) at the outset can create friction if the Seller later claims the specific identity of the Buyer was a material term of the contract.
risk_inventory.title: Lack of Assignment Flexibility in Preamble
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: '____________________________, and/or its assigns (“Buyer”)'

risk_inventory.description: Verify that the legal name of the Seller matches the name on the current vesting deed/title report to ensure the party has the legal authority to sell.
risk_inventory.title: Entity Verification
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that the legal name of the Seller matches the name on the current vesting deed/title report to ensure the party has the legal authority to sell.

risk_inventory.description: The clause states the Seller will 'sell and convey' but does not specify the quality of the deed. In Washington, a Buyer should specifically require a 'Statutory Warranty Deed' to ensure the Seller warrants against all defects in title. Without this specification, the Seller might attempt to provide a Bargain and Sale Deed or a Quitclaim Deed, which offer significantly less protection.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller agrees to sell and convey to Buyer
risk_inventory.title: Failure to Specify Deed Type
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Seller agrees to sell and convey to Buyer by Statutory Warranty Deed'

risk_inventory.description: The definition is limited to the land described in Exhibit A. It fails to explicitly include appurtenances, easements, water rights, and mineral rights that may be associated with the land. A Buyer should ensure the definition is broad enough to capture all rights 'running with the land.'
risk_inventory.problematic_text: All that certain real property located at ______________________________________, Washington, as more particularly described in Exhibit A attached hereto (the “Real Property”);
risk_inventory.title: Narrow Definition of Real Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'All that certain real property located at ______________________________________, Washington, as more particularly described in Exhibit A attached hereto, together with all rights, privileges, easements, and appurtenances thereto (the “Real Property”);'

risk_inventory.description: Confirm that Exhibit A is attached and that the legal description (metes and bounds or lot/block) is identical to the description in the preliminary title report.
risk_inventory.title: Exhibit A Verification
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm that Exhibit A is attached and that the legal description (metes and bounds or lot/block) is identical to the description in the preliminary title report.

risk_inventory.description: Verify via title report that all necessary easements for access, utilities, and drainage are indeed appurtenant to the land and not personal to the current owner.
risk_inventory.title: Verification of Appurtenant Rights
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify via title report that all necessary easements for access, utilities, and drainage are indeed appurtenant to the land and not personal to the current owner.

risk_inventory.description: The definition excludes fixtures leased by Seller or owned by tenants without requiring a specific list. This creates a risk that essential operating equipment (e.g., HVAC units, solar panels, or specialized lighting) might be removed or reclaimed by third parties after closing without the Buyer's prior knowledge.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: excluding any fixtures owned by tenants or leased by Seller from third parties
risk_inventory.title: Ambiguity in Excluded Fixtures
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'excluding only those fixtures owned by tenants or leased by Seller from third parties as specifically identified in Schedule [X] attached hereto'

risk_inventory.description: Request a list of all third-party leased equipment and fixtures to ensure no critical infrastructure is excluded from the sale.
risk_inventory.title: Fixture Ownership Audit
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Request a list of all third-party leased equipment and fixtures to ensure no critical infrastructure is excluded from the sale.

risk_inventory.description: By limiting the definition to property 'owned by Seller,' the buyer may lose out on property used in operations that is being financed or held under a capital lease where title hasn't technically passed, even if the buyer is expected to assume the obligation.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: personal property owned by Seller
risk_inventory.title: Ownership Limitation on Personal Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'personal property owned by Seller (or in which Seller has a leasehold or possessory interest)'

risk_inventory.description: Ensure the bracketed exclusion list is completed and that a full inventory of included personal property (FF&E) is attached as an exhibit.
risk_inventory.title: Personal Property Inventory
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure the bracketed exclusion list is completed and that a full inventory of included personal property (FF&E) is attached as an exhibit.

risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'to the extent transferable' is self-executing and does not obligate the Seller to actually attempt to transfer the property or obtain necessary consents from third parties (like software licensors or permit issuers).
risk_inventory.problematic_text: to the extent transferable by Seller
risk_inventory.title: Passive Transfer Obligation
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add: 'Seller shall use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain any required consents for the transfer of such Intangible Property at no cost to Buyer.'

risk_inventory.description: The exclusion of all claims against third parties relating to the period prior to closing is dangerous. If there is a latent construction defect, a warranty claim for a roof installed a year ago, or an unpaid insurance claim for recent damage, the Buyer needs these claims to be assigned so they can recover costs for repairs they will eventually have to make.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: but excluding any present or future claims of Seller against any third parties that relate to any period of time prior to the Closing
risk_inventory.title: Broad Exclusion of Pre-Closing Claims
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'but excluding any present or future claims of Seller against any third parties that relate to any period of time prior to the Closing, except for (i) warranty claims related to the Improvements, (ii) claims for damages to the Property that have not been repaired as of Closing, and (iii) claims against tenants for unpaid rent or other charges for which Buyer is not credited at Closing.'

risk_inventory.description: Review all 'Service Contracts' to determine which are terminable and which must be assumed, as this definition automatically includes them in the purchase.
risk_inventory.title: Service Contract Review
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Review all 'Service Contracts' to determine which are terminable and which must be assumed, as this definition automatically includes them in the purchase.

risk_inventory.description: While 'Leases' includes the agreements, it does not explicitly mention the transfer of the Seller's interest in security deposits, letters of credit, or prepaid rents. While often handled in prorations, explicitly including them in the asset definition ensures they are legally transferred via the Bill of Sale/Assignment of Leases.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: all leases and other agreements to occupy the Real Property
risk_inventory.title: Omission of Security Deposits
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'all leases and other agreements to occupy the Real Property... together with all security deposits, letters of credit, and other credit enhancements held by Seller in connection therewith.'

risk_inventory.description: Cross-reference this definition with the actual Rent Roll to ensure all licenses or 'agreements to occupy' (like cell tower leases or kiosk licenses) are captured.
risk_inventory.title: Rent Roll Verification
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Cross-reference this definition with the actual Rent Roll to ensure all licenses or 'agreements to occupy' (like cell tower leases or kiosk licenses) are captured.

risk_inventory.description: The Seller is reserving the right to pursue claims against contractors, designers, and warrantors even after the sale. This could create a conflict where both Buyer and Seller are pursuing the same third party, or where the Seller settles a claim that affects the Buyer's ability to recover for defects discovered post-closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller reserves and retains the right, on a non-exclusive basis with Buyer, to assert all claims, defenses, counter claims, and cross claims of Seller against any third parties under any warranties, guaranties, and agreements related to design, construction or performance of the Property
risk_inventory.title: Seller Retention of Third-Party Claims
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to clarify that Seller's reserved rights are limited to claims arising from liabilities incurred by Seller prior to the Closing Date and that such reservation does not diminish the warranties assigned to Buyer. Add: 'provided, however, that Seller’s reservation of rights shall not impair Buyer’s rights under any warranties assigned to Buyer at Closing.'

risk_inventory.description: Verify that the numerical and written dollar amounts match the agreed-upon Letter of Intent (LOI).
risk_inventory.title: Purchase Price Verification
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that the numerical and written dollar amounts match the agreed-upon Letter of Intent (LOI).

risk_inventory.description: The bracketed language directs the Escrow Holder to pay the Initial Deposit directly to the Seller upon receipt. This is 'hard money' from day one. If the Seller goes bankrupt or refuses to return the money after a valid termination, the Buyer has no security and must sue the Seller to recover funds.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: [Upon receipt, Escrow Holder shall promptly pay the Initial Deposit to Seller.]
risk_inventory.title: Immediate Release of Deposit to Seller
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete the bracketed sentence. The deposit should be held in escrow by the Title Company until Closing or termination of the Agreement.

risk_inventory.description: The clause states the deposit is non-refundable upon receipt. This contradicts the purpose of a Due Diligence Period. The Buyer should be able to get the deposit back if they terminate during the inspection period.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The Initial Deposit will become non-refundable upon Escrow Holder's receipt except in case of Seller's default hereunder.
risk_inventory.title: Premature Non-Refundability
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'The Initial Deposit shall be refundable to Buyer if Buyer terminates this Agreement prior to the expiration of the Due Diligence Period. Thereafter, the Deposit shall be non-refundable except as otherwise provided in this Agreement.'

risk_inventory.description: Confirm the Title Insurance Company is a reputable national provider and that the 'business days' for delivery align with the Buyer's banking capabilities.
risk_inventory.title: Escrow Holder Identity
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm the Title Insurance Company is a reputable national provider and that the 'business days' for delivery align with the Buyer's banking capabilities.

risk_inventory.description: Similar to the Initial Deposit, the bracketed language allows the Seller to take possession of the Additional Deposit immediately. This removes the protection of an independent escrow holder.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: [Upon receipt, Escrow Holder shall promptly pay the Additional Deposit to Seller.]
risk_inventory.title: Immediate Release of Additional Deposit
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete the bracketed sentence to ensure the Additional Deposit remains in escrow.

risk_inventory.description: The text limits refundability only to 'Seller's default.' It should also be refundable if conditions precedent (like title clearance, casualty, or condemnation) are not met, even if those don't technically constitute a 'default' by Seller.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The Additional Deposit is nonrefundable, except in case of Seller's default hereunder, and as otherwise expressly provided in this Agreement.
risk_inventory.title: Narrow Refundability Scope
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'The Deposit shall be non-refundable except in the event of a Seller default, the failure of a condition precedent to Buyer's obligation to close, or as otherwise expressly provided herein.'

risk_inventory.description: The term 'paid in cash' is archaic and technically implies physical currency. In commercial transactions, this should be clarified to ensure wire transfers of immediately available funds are required and accepted.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: shall be paid in cash on the Closing Date
risk_inventory.title: Ambiguous Payment Method
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change 'paid in cash' to 'paid by wire transfer of immediately available United States funds'.

risk_inventory.description: The bracketed language '[plus accrued interest thereon]' suggests that whether the Buyer receives credit for interest earned on the Deposit is still a point of negotiation. As the Buyer, you want to ensure all interest earned on your capital is applied toward the Purchase Price.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: [plus accrued interest thereon]
risk_inventory.title: Uncertainty Regarding Interest Credit
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Remove the brackets and confirm the language: 'plus all accrued interest thereon'.

risk_inventory.description: The allocation of the Purchase Price between personal and real property has significant depreciation and transfer tax implications. If the dollar amount is left blank or filled in without professional tax advice, the Buyer may lose significant tax benefits or face challenges from the IRS/Department of Revenue.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The sum of $____________ of the Purchase Price shall be allocated to the Personal Property
risk_inventory.title: Arbitrary Tax Allocation
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure the blank is filled with a value supported by a qualified appraisal or tax professional. Add: 'Seller and Buyer agree to report the transaction for federal and state tax purposes in accordance with such allocation.'

risk_inventory.description: Consult with a tax advisor to determine the optimal allocation for depreciation purposes before finalizing this amount.
risk_inventory.title: Verify Personal Property Value
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consult with a tax advisor to determine the optimal allocation for depreciation purposes before finalizing this amount.

risk_inventory.description: The paragraph mentions 'following items' but the subsequent paragraph [p_24] only explicitly lists the Survey. It does not explicitly list the Title Commitment or underlying exception documents in the delivery obligation, which could delay the due diligence clock.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall deliver the following items to Buyer within seven (7) days
risk_inventory.title: Limited Scope of Deliverables
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'Seller shall deliver the following items (collectively, the "Due Diligence Documents") to Buyer...'

risk_inventory.description: Verify that 7 days is sufficient for the Buyer's title officer to receive and review these documents, or ensure the 'Feasibility Period' does not start until these are received.
risk_inventory.title: Confirm Delivery Timeline
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that 7 days is sufficient for the Buyer's title officer to receive and review these documents, or ensure the 'Feasibility Period' does not start until these are received.

risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'in the possession of Seller' is too narrow. The Seller may have surveys held by their attorneys, engineers, or lenders that are not physically in their 'possession' but are under their 'control.'
risk_inventory.problematic_text: in the possession of Seller
risk_inventory.title: Limited Search Obligation for Survey
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to 'in the possession or reasonable control of Seller, including any surveys held by Seller’s attorneys, consultants, or lenders.'

risk_inventory.description: The Seller is providing the 'Existing Survey' without any obligation to disclose if they know it is inaccurate (e.g., if new improvements were made after the survey date).
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The most recent survey of the Property, if any (“Existing Survey”) in the possession of Seller.
risk_inventory.title: Lack of Seller Representation on Survey Accuracy
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add: 'To Seller's knowledge, there have been no material changes to the Property since the date of the Existing Survey that would render it inaccurate.'

risk_inventory.description: The definition of Title Documents is tied to the 'Commitment' and 'Exceptions,' but the review period in [p_26] starts from the 'Effective Date' rather than the date Buyer actually receives these documents. If the Title Company or Seller is slow to deliver the documents, the Buyer's 10-day review window is effectively shortened.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: ten (10) days from the Effective Date (the “Title Review Period”)
risk_inventory.title: Title Review Clock Starts Prematurely
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change 'ten (10) days from the Effective Date' to 'ten (10) days after Buyer’s receipt of the Title Documents'.

risk_inventory.description: The clause specifies that failure to notify Seller of objections within 10 days constitutes 'approval of all exceptions.' This is a 'silent waiver' that can result in the Buyer being forced to take title subject to severe encumbrances (e.g., easements that prevent development) if a deadline is missed by even one day.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer's failure to timely notify Seller... shall constitute approval of all exceptions and of the condition of title to the Property.
risk_inventory.title: Deemed Approval of Title Exceptions
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to state that if Buyer fails to provide notice, the condition is deemed 'not satisfied' or 'disapproved,' or at minimum, require Seller to provide a second notice before a waiver is deemed to occur.

risk_inventory.description: The current language makes all title cures optional for the Seller ('Seller elects not to remove'). Standard commercial practice requires the Seller to remove 'Mandatory Cure Items' (e.g., mortgages, deeds of trust, mechanic's liens, and delinquent taxes) regardless of whether the Buyer objects.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall have ten (10) days... to give Buyer... (ii) notice that Seller elects not to remove or cure such Title Objection.
risk_inventory.title: Lack of Mandatory Cure Items
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add: 'Notwithstanding the foregoing, Seller shall be obligated to remove at or prior to Closing all monetary liens, delinquent taxes, and any encumbrances created by or through Seller after the Effective Date (collectively, "Mandatory Cure Items").'

risk_inventory.description: Verify that the 'Due Diligence Period' mentioned here (which allows termination) extends beyond the Seller's 10-day response period. If the DD period ends before the Seller responds, the Buyer loses their termination right.
risk_inventory.title: Due Diligence Period Alignment
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that the 'Due Diligence Period' mentioned here (which allows termination) extends beyond the Seller's 10-day response period. If the DD period ends before the Seller responds, the Buyer loses their termination right.

risk_inventory.description: The clause prevents the extension of the Closing Date for title review. If a supplemental report reveals a major defect (e.g., a new lien or lis pendens) shortly before closing, the Buyer may be forced to choose between terminating the deal or closing on a defective title without sufficient time for the cure process.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: in no event shall title review extend the Closing Date.
risk_inventory.title: Prohibition on Closing Extensions for Title Issues
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'If a supplemental report is issued within ten (10) days of the scheduled Closing Date, the Closing Date shall be extended as necessary to provide Buyer and Seller the full review and cure periods set forth herein.'

risk_inventory.description: The Seller is conveying title via a 'special warranty deed.' While common in commercial transactions, this only warrants against defects created during the Seller's ownership. A 'general warranty deed' would provide broader protection for the Buyer against all prior defects.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: special warranty deed in the form of attached Exhibit B
risk_inventory.title: Special Warranty Deed Limitation
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: If the Buyer has significant leverage, request a 'General Warranty Deed.' If not, ensure Exhibit B is reviewed to ensure the 'special' warranties are not overly diluted.

risk_inventory.description: Review Exhibit B (the Deed form) to ensure it matches the 'special warranty' description and does not contain additional 'as-is' disclaimers that undermine the warranty.
risk_inventory.title: Exhibit B Review
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Review Exhibit B (the Deed form) to ensure it matches the 'special warranty' description and does not contain additional 'as-is' disclaimers that undermine the warranty.

risk_inventory.description: The paragraph limits requested endorsements to those 'agreed to by Title Company during the Due Diligence Period.' This prevents the Buyer from requesting necessary endorsements for new issues discovered via supplemental reports after the DD period has expired.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: requested by Buyer and agreed to by Title Company during the Due Diligence Period
risk_inventory.title: Endorsement Request Limitation
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'requested by Buyer and agreed to by Title Company prior to Closing; provided that any endorsements related to the initial Commitment shall be requested during the Due Diligence Period.'

risk_inventory.description: The paragraph mentions 'payment of its normal premium' but does not specify which party pays for the 'extended coverage' vs. 'standard coverage' or the endorsements. In many jurisdictions, the Seller pays for standard and the Buyer pays the 'extended' uplift.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: upon payment of its normal premium
risk_inventory.title: Ambiguity in Title Policy Costs
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify: 'Seller shall pay the cost of a standard ALTA owner's policy, and Buyer shall pay the additional cost for extended coverage and any endorsements requested by Buyer.'

risk_inventory.description: The Due Diligence Period is tied to a specific calendar date rather than a duration following the delivery of Due Diligence Documents. If the Seller delays delivery of the documents (allowed up to 3 business days or potentially longer if they breach), the Buyer's actual time to review those documents is reduced.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: on or before 5 p.m. Pacific time on ____________________ (the period from the Effective Date through such date and time is referred to herein as the “Due Diligence Period”)
risk_inventory.title: Fixed Due Diligence Expiration Date
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to a floating duration: 'on or before 5 p.m. Pacific time on the date that is [e.g., 30] days following the date Seller has delivered all Due Diligence Documents to Buyer.'

risk_inventory.description: Review 'Schedule 1' immediately to ensure it includes all critical items: environmental reports, rent rolls, service contracts, utility bills, and historical maintenance records.
risk_inventory.title: Verify Schedule 1 Completeness
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Review 'Schedule 1' immediately to ensure it includes all critical items: environmental reports, rent rolls, service contracts, utility bills, and historical maintenance records.

risk_inventory.description: The Seller is disclaiming all responsibility for the accuracy or completeness of the documents provided. If the Seller provides an outdated or incorrect environmental report or rent roll, the Buyer may have no recourse for relying on that information unless it is specifically covered in Section 7.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: without representation or warranty as to the accuracy or completeness of such materials
risk_inventory.title: Disclaimer of Document Accuracy
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to: '...without representation or warranty as to the accuracy or completeness of such materials, except that Seller represents and warrants that (i) the Due Diligence Documents provided constitute all material records regarding the Property in Seller's possession or control, and (ii) to Seller's knowledge, the documents provided are true, correct, and complete copies of the originals.'

risk_inventory.description: Verify that Section 7 contains robust representations regarding the financial and physical status of the property to offset this disclaimer.
risk_inventory.title: Cross-Reference Section 7
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that Section 7 contains robust representations regarding the financial and physical status of the property to offset this disclaimer.

risk_inventory.description: Limiting inspections to 'nonintrusive' prevents the Buyer from conducting Phase II environmental testing (e.g., soil borings) or invasive structural/roofing tests if the initial 'nonintrusive' inspection reveals a potential issue.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: conduct such nonintrusive inspections, tests and studies
risk_inventory.title: Restriction to Nonintrusive Inspections
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add: '...provided, however, that if Buyer's initial inspections recommend further testing, Buyer may conduct intrusive testing subject to Seller's prior written consent, which shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed.'

risk_inventory.description: The right of entry is restricted to the 'Due Diligence Period.' The Buyer may need access after this period for insurance appraisals, contractor estimates for planned improvements, or a final walk-through prior to Closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: During the Due Diligence Period, Seller shall provide Buyer with reasonable access
risk_inventory.title: Access Limited to Due Diligence Period
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change 'During the Due Diligence Period' to 'From the Effective Date through the Closing Date'.

risk_inventory.description: Fill the blank for advance notice. Recommend 24 or 48 hours to ensure the Buyer can move quickly during a short DD period.
risk_inventory.title: Define Notice Period
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Fill the blank for advance notice. Recommend 24 or 48 hours to ensure the Buyer can move quickly during a short DD period.

risk_inventory.description: The term 'reasonable advance notice' is subjective and could lead to disputes if the Seller believes notice was insufficient, potentially delaying inspections.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall give Seller reasonable advance notice of such entry
risk_inventory.title: Vague Notice Requirement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change 'reasonable advance notice' to 'at least twenty-four (24) hours’ prior notice (which may be given via email to Seller or Seller’s agent).'

risk_inventory.description: Verify if there are any existing 'agreements' (e.g., complex tenant leases or property management contracts) that impose specific restrictions on entry that the Buyer must follow.
risk_inventory.title: Compliance with 'Agreements'
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify if there are any existing 'agreements' (e.g., complex tenant leases or property management contracts) that impose specific restrictions on entry that the Buyer must follow.

risk_inventory.description: Requiring the Buyer to restore the property to its 'prior condition' is an impossibly high standard for invasive testing (like soil borings or Phase II ESAs). It should be 'substantially the same' condition.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: restore the Property to its prior condition
risk_inventory.title: Strict Restoration Obligation
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to 'restore the Property to substantially the same condition as existed immediately prior to such inspections and tests.'

risk_inventory.description: Confirm that the carve-out for 'non-negligent aggravation' is acceptable to Buyer's insurance carrier, as this is a favorable but specific protection for the Buyer.
risk_inventory.title: Indemnity Carve-out Strength
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm that the carve-out for 'non-negligent aggravation' is acceptable to Buyer's insurance carrier, as this is a favorable but specific protection for the Buyer.

risk_inventory.description: Allowing insurance to be 'reasonably satisfactory to Seller' gives the Seller a potential 'back-door' way to delay inspections by rejecting the Buyer's insurance certificates.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: with insurance limits and coverage reasonably satisfactory to Seller
risk_inventory.title: Subjective Insurance Approval
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete 'reasonably satisfactory to Seller' and rely on the specific $2,000,000 limit mentioned, or specify the exact types of coverage required (e.g., Workers Comp, Auto).

risk_inventory.description: The indemnity survives termination indefinitely. This creates a long-tail liability for the Buyer.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The terms of this Section 5.2 shall survive termination of this Agreement.
risk_inventory.title: Indefinite Survival of Indemnity
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add a time limit: 'The terms of this Section 5.2 shall survive termination of this Agreement for a period of nine (9) months.'

risk_inventory.description: If the Buyer fails to send a notice by the deadline (due to administrative error or oversight), they are 'deemed' to have approved the property, making the deposit non-refundable. This is a 'hard' contingency.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: If Buyer fails to deliver the Termination Notice to Seller on or before the expiration of the Due Diligence Period, Buyer shall be deemed to have timely provided an Approval Notice.
risk_inventory.title: Deemed Approval (Silent Waiver)
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change 'deemed to have timely provided an Approval Notice' to 'deemed to have timely provided a Termination Notice.' This ensures that if the Buyer is silent, the deal dies and the deposit is protected.

risk_inventory.description: The requirement to 'diligently and in good faith pursue' due diligence is a subjective standard that a Seller could use to claim a breach of contract if the Buyer decides to terminate for a reason the Seller dislikes.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall promptly commence, and shall diligently and in good faith pursue, its due diligence reviews hereunder
risk_inventory.title: Subjective Performance Standard
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete 'and shall diligently and in good faith pursue'. The Buyer's right to terminate is already stated as being in its 'sole and absolute discretion,' which is the stronger and preferred standard.

risk_inventory.description: The Buyer is required to give the Seller all third-party reports (which the Buyer paid for) upon termination. This provides a windfall to the Seller at the Buyer's expense.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: upon Seller's written request, Buyer shall deliver to Seller copies of all third party reports, studies and test results regarding the Property procured or obtained by Buyer.
risk_inventory.title: Uncompensated Delivery of Reports
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add: '...provided that Seller shall reimburse Buyer for fifty percent (50%) of the actual, out-of-pocket cost of such reports.' Also, add that reports are delivered 'without representation or warranty and subject to the rights of the preparers.'

risk_inventory.description: Confirm that 'sole and absolute discretion' is retained in the final version, as this is the most protective language for a Buyer's right to walk away.
risk_inventory.title: Sole Discretion Standard
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm that 'sole and absolute discretion' is retained in the final version, as this is the most protective language for a Buyer's right to walk away.

risk_inventory.description: The condition only requires that items be 'delivered.' It does not specify that they must be executed, acknowledged (where necessary), or in a form and substance reasonably satisfactory to the Buyer. This could allow a Seller to technically satisfy the condition by delivering non-conforming or poorly drafted documents.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall have delivered those items described in Section 11.3 hereof
risk_inventory.title: Vague Delivery Standard
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Seller shall have executed and delivered those items described in Section 11.3 hereof, in form and substance reasonably satisfactory to Buyer and, where applicable, in recordable form;'

risk_inventory.description: Verify that Section 11.3 (referenced in p_41) and Section 8.1 (referenced in p_81) are consistent and include all necessary closing documents (Deed, Bill of Sale, Assignment of Leases, FIRPTA, etc.).
risk_inventory.title: Cross-Reference Check
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that Section 11.3 (referenced in p_41) and Section 8.1 (referenced in p_81) are consistent and include all necessary closing documents (Deed, Bill of Sale, Assignment of Leases, FIRPTA, etc.).

risk_inventory.description: While the definition of 'Title Policy' includes endorsements, this condition should explicitly state that the commitment includes the specific endorsements requested during the Due Diligence Period. Furthermore, it should specify that the commitment is at standard rates to prevent the Title Company from demanding extraordinary premiums to cover risks that should be Seller's responsibility to clear.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Title Company shall be irrevocably committed to issue the Title Policy pursuant to Section 4 hereof
risk_inventory.title: Omission of Endorsements and Premium Terms
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Title Company shall be irrevocably committed to issue the Title Policy (including all endorsements requested by Buyer pursuant to Section 4) at standard premium rates;'

risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'in all material respects' creates a 'double materiality' hurdle if the underlying representations in Section 5.2 already contain materiality qualifiers (e.g., 'Seller has no material knowledge of...'). This makes it significantly harder for a Buyer to claim a condition has failed because they must prove the breach itself was material on top of the existing qualifier.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: true, accurate and complete in all material respects
risk_inventory.title: Double Materiality Qualifier
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'true, accurate and complete in all respects (provided that any representation or warranty already qualified by materiality shall be true and correct in all respects);'

risk_inventory.description: The paragraph makes the truth of reps a condition, but it does not explicitly require the Seller to deliver a 'Bring-Down Certificate' at closing. Without a formal certificate, the Buyer may lack a clear document to sue upon if reps are later found to be false as of the Closing Date.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Each representation and warranty made by Seller in this Agreement shall be true, accurate and complete
risk_inventory.title: Lack of 'Bring-Down' Certificate Requirement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add: '...and Seller shall have delivered a certificate to Buyer at Closing, dated as of the Closing Date, certifying the same.'

risk_inventory.description: The condition only requires that estoppels be 'substantially in the form of Exhibit H.' It does not require that the estoppels be 'clean' (i.e., that they do not disclose tenant defaults, landlord defaults, or claims of offset). A tenant could return an estoppel in the correct form but disclose a massive landlord default, and the Seller would technically satisfy this condition.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall have delivered the Minimum Tenant Estoppels, each substantially in the form of Exhibit H attached hereto.
risk_inventory.title: Lack of 'Clean' Estoppel Requirement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Seller shall have delivered the Minimum Tenant Estoppels, each substantially in the form of Exhibit H, and none of which shall disclose any material default by landlord or tenant, any claim of offset, or any other information materially inconsistent with the Leases or Seller’s representations.'

risk_inventory.description: The lead-in paragraph [p_40] says conditions must be met 'at or prior to Closing.' If the Seller delivers the Minimum Tenant Estoppels five minutes before Closing, the Buyer has no time to review them or verify the information with tenants. This creates significant operational and financial risk.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: at or prior to the Closing
risk_inventory.title: Timing of Estoppel Delivery
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add to p_44: '...which Estoppels shall be delivered to Buyer no later than five (5) business days prior to the Closing Date.'

risk_inventory.description: The defined term 'Minimum Tenant Estoppels' contains blanks for percentages and square footage. Ensure these are filled with high thresholds (e.g., 75-100% of square footage and all 'Major Tenants').
risk_inventory.title: Verify Estoppel Thresholds
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: The defined term 'Minimum Tenant Estoppels' contains blanks for percentages and square footage. Ensure these are filled with high thresholds (e.g., 75-100% of square footage and all 'Major Tenants').

risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'In addition to all other conditions' creates uncertainty by suggesting there are hidden or unlisted conditions elsewhere in the agreement that could allow the Seller to refuse to close. Conditions precedent should be exhaustive to ensure certainty of closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: In addition to all other conditions to Seller's obligations in this Agreement
risk_inventory.title: Open-Ended Conditions Precedent
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to 'Subject only to the satisfaction or waiver by Seller of the following conditions...'

risk_inventory.description: Requiring representations to be 'complete' is a higher and more subjective standard than 'true and correct.' A representation could be accurate but deemed 'incomplete' by a Seller looking for an excuse to terminate. This creates a 'backdoor' termination right.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: true, accurate and complete in all material respects
risk_inventory.title: Overly Broad Standard for Representations
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to 'true and correct in all material respects'

risk_inventory.description: The paragraph allows for termination if conditions are not met but fails to specify that the Deposit must be returned to the Buyer if the termination is due to a failure of a condition (rather than a default). Without this, the Seller might attempt to retain the Deposit after terminating.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: this Agreement may be terminated by the party benefiting from such condition by written notice to the other party.
risk_inventory.title: Lack of Deposit Return Clarity
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Append the following: 'In the event of such termination, the Deposit shall be immediately returned to Buyer, and except for those provisions which expressly survive termination, neither party shall have any further rights or obligations hereunder.'

risk_inventory.description: The paragraph refers to 'Sections 5.1 through 5.4' and 'Section 5.5'. Based on the provided text, [p_45] appears to be Section 5.5. If the numbering in the final document does not align perfectly, the waiver and termination rights may be legally unenforceable or applied to the wrong sections.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The conditions set forth in Sections 5.1 through 5.4are for the exclusive benefit of Buyer and the conditions set forth in Section 5.5 are for the exclusive benefit of Seller.
risk_inventory.title: Potential Internal Reference Mismatch
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that [p_45] through [p_48] are indeed contained within Section 5.5 and that Sections 5.1-5.4 refer to Buyer's conditions (e.g., due diligence, financing).

risk_inventory.description: Confirm that the paragraph numbers in the final execution version match the 'Section 5.x' references in [p_49].
risk_inventory.title: Verify Section Numbering
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm that the paragraph numbers in the final execution version match the 'Section 5.x' references in [p_49].

risk_inventory.description: The clause requires the Buyer to pay half of the escrow cancellation fees regardless of why the agreement is terminated (unless under Section 13). If the Seller defaults or a condition precedent fails through no fault of the Buyer, the Buyer should not be penalized with these costs.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: the parties shall equally share any cancellation fee of the Escrow Holder.
risk_inventory.title: Unfair Allocation of Cancellation Fees
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'the parties shall equally share any cancellation fee of the Escrow Holder; provided, however, that if this Agreement is terminated due to a Seller default, Seller shall pay all such cancellation fees.'

risk_inventory.description: Verify that Section 13 (referenced in p_50) adequately covers Seller Default and provides for the return of the Deposit to the Buyer.
risk_inventory.title: Cross-reference Section 13
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that Section 13 (referenced in p_50) adequately covers Seller Default and provides for the return of the Deposit to the Buyer.

risk_inventory.description: While the paragraph states the agreement doesn't violate contracts, it does not explicitly state that no third-party or governmental consents are required for the Seller to complete the sale. This could lead to delays or legal challenges if a lender or partner consent is missing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: do not, and at the time of Closing, will not, violate any provisions of any contract or judicial order to which Seller is a party or to which Seller is subject.
risk_inventory.title: Missing Representation on Consents
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add: 'and no consent, waiver, approval or authorization of, or filing with, any person or governmental authority is required in connection with the execution and delivery of this Agreement by Seller.'

risk_inventory.description: There is no representation that the Seller is not currently involved in bankruptcy proceedings or is not insolvent. This is a standard protection for Buyers to ensure the transaction isn't voidable as a fraudulent transfer.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: [Entire Paragraph 53]
risk_inventory.title: Lack of Anti-Insolvency Representation
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add: 'Seller has not (i) made a general assignment for the benefit of creditors, (ii) filed any voluntary petition in bankruptcy, or (iii) received notice of any involuntary petition in bankruptcy filed against it.'

risk_inventory.description: The Rent Roll is the primary basis for property valuation. Qualifying this representation with 'Seller's Actual Knowledge'—especially when the defined term 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' explicitly disclaims any duty to investigate—is highly risky for the Buyer. The Seller should be able to warrant the accuracy of their own financial records absolutely.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: To Seller's Actual Knowledge, the rent roll identified in the Due Diligence Documents (the “Rent Roll”) is true and correct in all material respects.
risk_inventory.title: Weak Knowledge Qualifier for Rent Roll
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Remove 'To Seller's Actual Knowledge,' or at a minimum, revise the definition of 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' to include a duty of reasonable inquiry of the property manager.

risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'in all material respects' is subjective. In a large multi-tenant property, small errors across many leases can aggregate into a significant financial discrepancy that the Seller might argue is not 'material' to the whole deal.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: is true and correct in all material respects.
risk_inventory.title: Vague Materiality Standard
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'is true, correct, and complete.' If materiality must remain, define it (e.g., 'material' means any discrepancy exceeding $X,XXX in annual aggregate rent).

risk_inventory.description: The definition of 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' contains a blank space for a name. Ensure a specific individual (e.g., the Asset Manager or Principal) is named and that they are the person most likely to have knowledge of the property's operations.
risk_inventory.title: Identify Knowledge Party
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: The definition of 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' contains a blank space for a name. Ensure a specific individual (e.g., the Asset Manager or Principal) is named and that they are the person most likely to have knowledge of the property's operations.

risk_inventory.description: The representation regarding governmental violations is qualified by 'Seller's Actual Knowledge,' which, as defined in [p_59], excludes any duty to investigate. This allows the Seller to remain willfully ignorant of violations that would be discovered by a simple review of property records or inquiry with the property manager.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: To Seller's Actual Knowledge
risk_inventory.title: Knowledge-Qualified Violation Rep
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to 'To Seller's knowledge, after due inquiry of the property manager and a review of Seller's property files...'

risk_inventory.description: The representation only covers litigation against the 'Seller' entity. It does not explicitly cover litigation against the 'Property' itself (e.g., in rem actions) or litigation against the Seller that specifically relates to the Property.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: there is no litigation pending or threatened against Seller.
risk_inventory.title: Narrow Scope of Litigation Rep
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to 'there is no litigation pending or threatened against Seller or the Property, or which would affect Seller's ability to perform its obligations under this Agreement.'

risk_inventory.description: Verify through independent title search and zoning report, as the 'Actual Knowledge' qualifier limits the Seller's liability if they haven't checked recent municipal filings.
risk_inventory.title: Condemnation Verification
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify through independent title search and zoning report, as the 'Actual Knowledge' qualifier limits the Seller's liability if they haven't checked recent municipal filings.

risk_inventory.description: This paragraph uses 'To the best of Seller’s knowledge,' whereas other paragraphs use 'To Seller's Actual Knowledge.' Since 'Actual Knowledge' is specifically defined in [p_59] to limit liability, the use of a different, undefined term here creates ambiguity. Seller may argue it means the same as the restricted definition, while Buyer may argue it implies a duty to investigate.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: To the best of Seller’s knowledge
risk_inventory.title: Inconsistent Knowledge Standard
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Standardize the knowledge qualifier throughout the agreement. If using the defined term, ensure the definition in [p_59] is expanded to include due inquiry.

risk_inventory.description: The representation that lease copies are 'true, correct and complete' is qualified by 'in all material respects.' This allows the Seller to omit minor amendments or side letters that they unilaterally deem non-material, which could impact Buyer's underwriting.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: true, correct and complete in all material respects.
risk_inventory.title: Materiality Qualifier in Lease Accuracy
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to 'true, correct and complete in all respects.'

risk_inventory.description: Cross-reference the representations in this paragraph with the Tenant Estoppel Certificates obtained during due diligence to ensure no discrepancies exist regarding concessions or defaults.
risk_inventory.title: Tenant Estoppel Comparison
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Cross-reference the representations in this paragraph with the Tenant Estoppel Certificates obtained during due diligence to ensure no discrepancies exist regarding concessions or defaults.

risk_inventory.description: The definition of 'Actual Knowledge' explicitly states it is 'without such person undertaking any investigation.' This is highly problematic for a Buyer as it protects a Seller who deliberately avoids checking their own files or speaking to their property manager to avoid 'actual' knowledge of a defect.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: without such person undertaking any investigation.
risk_inventory.title: Ostrich Clause (No Investigation)
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Replace with 'after due inquiry of the property manager and a review of Seller's records related to the Property.'

risk_inventory.description: This clause states that if any Due Diligence Materials (which could be thousands of pages in a data room) contain information inconsistent with the Seller's representations, the representations are 'deemed modified.' This effectively shifts the entire burden of discovery to the Buyer and allows the Seller to make false representations as long as the truth is buried somewhere in the data room.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: To the extent the Due Diligence Materials... contains express provisions or information that are inconsistent with the foregoing representations and warranties, such representations and warranties shall be deemed modified
risk_inventory.title: Knowledge Override / Anti-Sandbagging
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete this entire sentence. The Seller should stand behind its representations regardless of what is in the data room, unless specifically disclosed in a Disclosure Schedule.

risk_inventory.description: While it is standard to limit liability to the entity, the broad covenant that Buyer will bring 'no action of any kind' against the named individuals could potentially bar claims for fraud or intentional misrepresentation by those individuals.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer covenants that it will bring no action of any kind against any such individuals
risk_inventory.title: Covenant Not to Sue Individuals
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add: '...except in the case of fraud or intentional misrepresentation by such individuals.'

risk_inventory.description: Ensure the blank space for the named individual is filled with the person most likely to have day-to-day operational knowledge of the property (e.g., the Asset Manager or Lead Portfolio Manager).
risk_inventory.title: Identify Knowledge Individual
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure the blank space for the named individual is filled with the person most likely to have day-to-day operational knowledge of the property (e.g., the Asset Manager or Lead Portfolio Manager).

risk_inventory.description: The 'deemed to have known' provision creates an imputed knowledge standard. It allows the Seller to escape liability for a false representation if the truth was buried anywhere in the 'Property Information' (data room, reports, etc.), even if the Buyer did not actually see it. This effectively shifts the burden of the Seller's honesty onto the Buyer's diligence team.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall be “deemed to have known” that a representation or warranty was untrue, inaccurate or incorrect at the time of the Closing if any Property Information furnished or made available to or otherwise obtained by Buyer contains express information which is inconsistent with such representation or warranty.
risk_inventory.title: Constructive Knowledge/Anti-Sandbagging Clause
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete the 'deemed to have known' sentence entirely. If Seller insists on a knowledge waiver, limit it to the 'Actual Knowledge' of specific named individuals on the Buyer's team, and exclude information merely 'made available' in a data room.

risk_inventory.description: The $50,000 floor is a 'basket' that prevents the Buyer from recovering for any breaches that don't meet this high dollar amount. Depending on the purchase price, $50,000 may be too high, allowing the Seller to make multiple 'small' misrepresentations with impunity.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer’s damages as a result of such representations or warranties being untrue, inaccurate or incorrect are, in the aggregate, less than $50,000
risk_inventory.title: High Minimum Claim Threshold (Basket)
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Lower the threshold to a more reasonable amount (e.g., $10,000 or $25,000) and clarify that once the threshold is met, the Buyer is entitled to recover from the first dollar (a 'tipping basket') rather than just the excess.

risk_inventory.description: Cross-reference the definition of 'Property Information' in Section 1. If it is defined broadly to include all documents provided by Seller, the risk in B12_R1 is significantly amplified.
risk_inventory.title: Definition of Property Information
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Cross-reference the definition of 'Property Information' in Section 1. If it is defined broadly to include all documents provided by Seller, the risk in B12_R1 is significantly amplified.

risk_inventory.description: The cap applies not just to representations and warranties, but also to 'covenants and other obligations.' This is dangerous for a Buyer. If the Seller fails to perform a post-closing covenant (like a tax proration or a repair obligation), their liability should not be capped. Furthermore, there is no exception for fraud or intentional misrepresentation.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: the aggregate liability of either party arising pursuant to or in connection with the representations, warranties, covenants and other obligations (whether express or implied) of such party in this Agreement... shall not exceed $___________
risk_inventory.title: Overly Broad Liability Cap
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'the aggregate liability of Seller for breaches of representations and warranties shall not exceed [Amount]... provided, however, that this cap shall not apply to (i) Seller's breach of any covenants, (ii) Seller's fraud or intentional misrepresentation, or (iii) Seller's indemnity obligations regarding [specific items like brokers or taxes].'

risk_inventory.description: The liability cap is currently blank. Without a negotiated amount, the Buyer's potential recovery is undefined, and the Seller will likely push for a very low percentage of the purchase price.
risk_inventory.title: Undefined Liability Cap Amount
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Insert a specific dollar amount or percentage. For a Buyer, a typical cap ranges from 5% to 10% of the purchase price, though some Buyers push for higher or no cap at all.

risk_inventory.description: Verify if the Buyer's liability should also be capped here. Usually, Buyer's liability is limited to the Earnest Money Deposit as liquidated damages. Ensure this cap doesn't conflict with or expand the Buyer's liability beyond the deposit.
risk_inventory.title: Mutual Cap Applicability
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify if the Buyer's liability should also be capped here. Usually, Buyer's liability is limited to the Earnest Money Deposit as liquidated damages. Ensure this cap doesn't conflict with or expand the Buyer's liability beyond the deposit.

risk_inventory.description: Ensure the Buyer entity is properly formed and in good standing in its home state and the state where the property is located before signing.
risk_inventory.title: Entity Authority
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure the Buyer entity is properly formed and in good standing in its home state and the state where the property is located before signing.

risk_inventory.description: Confirm that entering into this Agreement does not violate any of Buyer's existing loan documents or joint venture agreements.
risk_inventory.title: Conflict Check
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm that entering into this Agreement does not violate any of Buyer's existing loan documents or joint venture agreements.

risk_inventory.description: A six-month survival period is relatively short for commercial real estate. Latent issues (such as tax liabilities or undisclosed litigation) often take longer than six months to surface after the closing date.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: survive for a period of six (6) months from the Closing Date
risk_inventory.title: Short Survival Period
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change 'six (6) months' to 'nine (9) months' or 'twelve (12) months' to allow for a full operating cycle and tax year to pass.

risk_inventory.description: The clause requires the Buyer to actually commence litigation within the Survival Period to preserve a claim. This is overly aggressive; typically, providing written notice of a claim within the period is sufficient to preserve it.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: any cause of action resulting from a breach thereof not then in litigation
risk_inventory.title: Requirement to Commence Litigation
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'any cause of action resulting from a breach thereof for which Buyer has not provided Seller with written notice of a claim prior to the expiration of the Survival Period'.

risk_inventory.description: Verify that Sections 7.1 and 7.2 (referenced in p_65) and Sections 7(a) and (b) (referenced later in the same paragraph) are consistent and cover all critical Seller representations. The discrepancy in numbering (7.1 vs 7(a)) suggests a potential drafting error.
risk_inventory.title: Cross-Reference Verification
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that Sections 7.1 and 7.2 (referenced in p_65) and Sections 7(a) and (b) (referenced later in the same paragraph) are consistent and cover all critical Seller representations. The discrepancy in numbering (7.1 vs 7(a)) suggests a potential drafting error.

risk_inventory.description: If a representation becomes untrue before closing, the Buyer's only remedy is to terminate the agreement. This prevents the Buyer from closing and seeking damages (indemnification) even if the Seller caused the breach or if the Buyer still wants the property but needs to be made whole for the diminished value.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer’s termination of this Agreement shall be Buyer’s sole remedy against Seller in the circumstances described in this paragraph.
risk_inventory.title: Sole Remedy Limitation for Rep Breaches
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to allow Buyer to seek damages if the change in representation resulted from a voluntary act or omission by Seller, or allow for a purchase price reduction.

risk_inventory.description: The Buyer can only terminate if the change has a 'material adverse impact' in Buyer's 'reasonable judgment.' This is a high bar and could lead to disputes over what constitutes 'material' if the Buyer wants to walk away from a tainted deal.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: if in Buyer’s reasonable judgment such change in condition or new information has a material adverse impact on the Property or on the Buyer
risk_inventory.title: Subjective Materiality Threshold
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Remove 'material adverse impact' and replace with 'if such change is unacceptable to Buyer in its sole but reasonable discretion' or define a specific dollar threshold for materiality.

risk_inventory.description: A 5-day window for Buyer to object to new leases or modifications is extremely short. If the Buyer fails to respond within this window, they are 'conclusively deemed' to have approved the lease, which could include unfavorable terms or high tenant improvement costs.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer's consent shall conclusively be deemed granted if Buyer does not object... within five (5) days
risk_inventory.title: Short Deemed Approval Period for Leases
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Increase the response period to 'ten (10) business days'.

risk_inventory.description: The clause makes Buyer responsible for all leasing commissions and TI costs for leases approved after the DD period. This should be contingent on the Closing actually occurring.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: from and after Closing Buyer shall be responsible for all leasing commissions, tenant improvements and other costs payable by the Landlord thereunder.
risk_inventory.title: Unconditional Buyer Liability for New Lease Costs
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify that Buyer is only responsible for costs 'to the extent first arising or payable after the Closing Date' and ensure Seller remains liable for any costs related to leases signed prior to the end of the Due Diligence Period.

risk_inventory.description: Confirm that the property management agreement can be terminated 'as of Closing' without penalty to the Buyer, and that Seller is responsible for any termination fees.
risk_inventory.title: Property Management Termination
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm that the property management agreement can be terminated 'as of Closing' without penalty to the Buyer, and that Seller is responsible for any termination fees.

risk_inventory.description: Seller is not obligated to terminate Service Contracts if it creates 'additional cost or liability.' This could force the Buyer to assume contracts they explicitly rejected during Due Diligence if those contracts have termination fees.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: provided that Seller shall not be obligated to terminate any Service Contract if such termination will create any additional cost or liability for Seller.
risk_inventory.title: Seller's Refusal to Terminate Contracts
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'Seller shall terminate all Service Contracts not assumed by Buyer at Seller's sole cost and expense, including any termination fees or penalties.'

risk_inventory.description: The clause requires Seller to maintain insurance 'currently in force.' If the Seller's current coverage is inadequate or expires during the escrow period, the Buyer has no protection requiring the Seller to maintain industry-standard coverage or specific limits.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall maintain all casualty and liability insurance currently in force with respect to the Property.
risk_inventory.title: Vague Insurance Maintenance Standard
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Seller shall maintain all casualty and liability insurance currently in force with respect to the Property, and shall not reduce or cancel such coverage prior to Closing.'

risk_inventory.description: The percentage and square footage requirements for the 'Minimum Tenant Estoppels' are blank. Without these numbers, the condition is unenforceable or provides the Buyer with no guaranteed level of tenant verification.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: represent not less that _______ percent (__%) of the net rentable square footage of the Property, including Tenant Estoppels from all tenants who lease more than _____ rentable square feet
risk_inventory.title: Unspecified Minimum Estoppel Threshold
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Fill in the blanks with protective numbers, e.g., '75 percent' and 'all tenants who lease more than 5,000 rentable square feet' (or 'Major Tenants' as defined elsewhere).

risk_inventory.description: The Seller's Lease Certificate (used when a tenant fails to provide an estoppel) is limited to 'Seller's knowledge.' This shifts the risk of lease disputes to the Buyer if the Seller claims they 'didn't know' about a tenant's side agreement or default.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: certifying, to Seller’s knowledge, those matters included in the attached form of Tenant Estoppel
risk_inventory.title: Weak Seller Lease Certificate Standard
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Remove 'to Seller's knowledge' or add: 'provided, however, that if a tenant subsequently asserts a claim or defense contrary to the Seller’s Lease Certificate, such certificate shall be treated as a representation and warranty of Seller that survives Closing.'

risk_inventory.description: The Seller explicitly disclaims any obligation to obtain subordination agreements, which may be a requirement for the Buyer's lender.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall have no obligation to obtain and deliver any such subordination agreements to Buyer.
risk_inventory.title: No Obligation for Subordination Agreements
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Seller shall use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain and deliver such subordination agreements, provided that Seller shall not be required to expend any out-of-pocket funds or commence litigation in connection therewith.'

risk_inventory.description: Verify that Exhibit G (the Estoppel form) contains all necessary lender-required language, including confirmation of rent, security deposits, and no landlord defaults.
risk_inventory.title: Exhibit G Review
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that Exhibit G (the Estoppel form) contains all necessary lender-required language, including confirmation of rent, security deposits, and no landlord defaults.

risk_inventory.description: The Buyer is required to release all third-party sources and preparers of information (e.g., environmental consultants, surveyors, engineers) retained by the Seller. This prevents the Buyer from seeking recourse against a professional who may have committed malpractice in a report the Buyer relied upon.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: BUYER AGREES TO FULLY AND IRREVOCABLY RELEASE ALL SUCH SOURCES OF INFORMATION AND PREPARERS OF INFORMATION AND DOCUMENTATION AFFECTING THE PROPERTY WHICH WERE RETAINED BY SELLER
risk_inventory.title: Broad Release of Third-Party Information Providers
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete this release or add: 'except to the extent Buyer is named as an authorized user or third-party beneficiary of such reports or documentation.'

risk_inventory.description: Seller disclaims the accuracy or completeness of all due diligence materials. While common in 'As-Is' sales, this can be problematic if the Seller provides misleading or incomplete records intentionally.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: SELLER MAKES NO REPRESENTATIONS AS TO THE ACCURACY OR COMPLETENESS OF SUCH INFORMATION.
risk_inventory.title: Disclaimer of Accuracy of Due Diligence Materials
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add: 'except that Seller represents that it has not intentionally withheld or misrepresented any material information in the Due Diligence Materials.'

risk_inventory.description: Confirm that Section 7 (referenced as the exception to the AS-IS clause) contains robust representations regarding environmental, zoning, and physical condition to balance this broad disclaimer.
risk_inventory.title: Section 7 Cross-Reference
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm that Section 7 (referenced as the exception to the AS-IS clause) contains robust representations regarding environmental, zoning, and physical condition to balance this broad disclaimer.

risk_inventory.description: The release is so broad ('any and all losses... arising out of or in any way connected with the Property') that it could be interpreted to release the Seller from a breach of the representations and warranties in Section 7 immediately upon Closing, rendering the survival period useless.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: forever release Seller... of and from any and all losses, liabilities, damages, claims, demands, causes of action, costs and expenses, whether known or unknown, arising out of or in any way connected with the Property
risk_inventory.title: Release Extinguishes Seller's Reps and Warranties
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add a carve-out: '...except for (i) the warranties of Seller contained in the Deed, (ii) the representations and warranties of Seller in Section 7 which survive Closing, and (iii) any other obligations of Seller under this Agreement which expressly survive Closing.'

risk_inventory.description: The environmental release only carves out claims for hazardous substances 'caused by Seller.' It is often difficult to prove the Seller 'caused' a release versus merely owning the property while it existed. This could prevent the Buyer from seeking contribution for pre-existing conditions.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: regarding the release of any hazardous substances on the Property caused by Seller.
risk_inventory.title: Narrow Environmental Carve-out
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'regarding the release of any hazardous substances on the Property existing as of the Closing Date or caused by Seller or its agents.'

risk_inventory.description: The release of the Seller is broad and only carves out specific representations in Section 7.1 and post-closing obligations. It fails to carve out fraud, intentional misrepresentation, or breaches of the purchase agreement itself occurring prior to closing that are discovered later.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The foregoing release shall not, however, affect Seller’s liability for or under (a) any representations and warranties made specifically by Seller in Section 7.1 above to the extent same survive Closing as provided therein; or (b) any other obligations of Seller identified herein which are to be performed after Closing.
risk_inventory.title: Narrow Carve-outs from Release
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'The foregoing release shall not, however, affect Seller’s liability for or under (a) any representations and warranties made specifically by Seller in Section 7.1 above to the extent same survive Closing as provided therein; (b) any other obligations of Seller identified herein which are to be performed after Closing; or (c) any claims arising from fraud or intentional misrepresentation by Seller.'

risk_inventory.description: The current language only applies 50% of the second extension fee toward the Purchase Price. This effectively increases the cost of the property if the Buyer needs the full extension period, penalizing the Buyer for using a right they are paying for.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: one-half (1/2) of the Extension Fee paid by Buyer, if any, for the second extension shall be applicable to the Purchase Price.
risk_inventory.title: Partial Application of Extension Fee
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change 'one-half (1/2) of the Extension Fee' to 'the full amount of the Extension Fee'.

risk_inventory.description: The extension fee is only refundable in the event of a Seller default. If the contract terminates due to other reasons where the Buyer is typically entitled to a refund of the Deposit (e.g., failure of a condition precedent, title defects, casualty, or condemnation), the Buyer would lose the Extension Fee.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The Extension Fee shall be nonrefundable, except in case of Seller's default.
risk_inventory.title: Limited Refundability of Extension Fees
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'The Extension Fee shall be nonrefundable, except in the case of Seller's default or as otherwise expressly provided in this Agreement for the return of the Deposit to Buyer (including, without limitation, termination due to casualty, condemnation, or the failure of a condition precedent for Buyer's benefit).'

risk_inventory.description: Ensure the number of business days required for notice (currently blank) provides enough time for the Buyer to evaluate the need for an extension without being so long that it creates a 'dead zone' before closing.
risk_inventory.title: Verify Extension Notice Period
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure the number of business days required for notice (currently blank) provides enough time for the Buyer to evaluate the need for an extension without being so long that it creates a 'dead zone' before closing.

risk_inventory.description: The language grants possession subject to 'rights of tenants in possession under Leases.' If 'Leases' is not strictly defined to only include those disclosed to and approved by Buyer, the Buyer could be forced to accept undisclosed occupants or 'squatters' claiming leasehold rights.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: subject to the rights of tenants in possession under Leases.
risk_inventory.title: Possession Subject to Undisclosed Leases
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'subject to the rights of tenants in possession under the Leases specifically disclosed to and approved by Buyer in writing.'

risk_inventory.description: Allowing Seller to deliver documents 'on' the Closing Date can lead to delays in funding and recording, especially if the Escrow Holder requires time to review documents or if the wire transfer cut-off times are early in the day.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: On or before the Closing Date
risk_inventory.title: Late Delivery of Closing Documents
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'At least one (1) business day prior to the Closing Date'

risk_inventory.description: The list of documents following [p_81] (in the next batch) must be reviewed to ensure all necessary transfer tax forms, affidavits of non-foreign status, and tenant notices are included.
risk_inventory.title: Review Seller's Delivery List
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: The list of documents following [p_81] (in the next batch) must be reviewed to ensure all necessary transfer tax forms, affidavits of non-foreign status, and tenant notices are included.

risk_inventory.description: The defined terms specify a 'special warranty deed.' In Washington, this only warrants against defects arising during the Seller's period of ownership. A Buyer typically prefers a 'Statutory Warranty Deed,' which provides broader protection against title defects regardless of when they arose.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The Deed conveying to Buyer the Real Property
risk_inventory.title: Limited Title Warranty (Special Warranty Deed)
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change 'special warranty deed' in the Defined Terms to 'statutory warranty deed' and ensure p_82 reflects the conveyance via Statutory Warranty Deed.

risk_inventory.description: Verify that the agreement requires both Buyer and Seller to execute the Real Estate Excise Tax (REET) Affidavit, as Washington law generally requires both signatures for processing.
risk_inventory.title: REET Affidavit Execution
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that the agreement requires both Buyer and Seller to execute the Real Estate Excise Tax (REET) Affidavit, as Washington law generally requires both signatures for processing.

risk_inventory.description: Review Exhibit C (Bill of Sale) to ensure it includes a warranty of title for personal property and explicitly includes all 'Improvements' and 'Personal Property' defined in the agreement.
risk_inventory.title: Bill of Sale Scope
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Review Exhibit C (Bill of Sale) to ensure it includes a warranty of title for personal property and explicitly includes all 'Improvements' and 'Personal Property' defined in the agreement.

risk_inventory.description: The paragraph mentions assigning interest in the Leases but does not explicitly mention the transfer of or credit for tenant security deposits. Without explicit language, there may be a dispute over whether the cash for deposits is transferred at closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: assigning and conveying to Buyer the Seller's interest in, to and under the Leases
risk_inventory.title: Security Deposit Transfer
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'assigning and conveying to Buyer the Seller's interest in, to and under the Leases, including all tenant security deposits and prepaid rents held by Seller.'

risk_inventory.description: Delivering original leases 'outside of Escrow' means the Escrow Agent cannot verify delivery before releasing funds. If Seller fails to hand over the physical files at the property, Buyer has little leverage post-closing.
