risk_inventory.problematic_text: to be delivered outside of Escrow
risk_inventory.title: Delivery Outside of Escrow
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'to be delivered to Buyer at the Real Property on the Closing Date, with confirmation of receipt provided to Escrow as a condition to Closing.'

risk_inventory.description: The qualifier 'in Seller's possession or control' allows Seller to avoid providing leases they may have lost or misplaced. Buyer needs all original leases to enforce rights against tenants.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: in Seller's possession or control
risk_inventory.title: Possession or Control Limitation
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add: '...in Seller's possession or control; provided, however, if any originals are missing, Seller shall provide a lost lease affidavit in a form reasonably acceptable to Buyer.'

risk_inventory.description: Ensure Exhibit F (Certificate of Rent Roll) requires the Seller to certify the rent roll as of the actual Closing Date, not the date the PSA was signed.
risk_inventory.title: Rent Roll Currency
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure Exhibit F (Certificate of Rent Roll) requires the Seller to certify the rent roll as of the actual Closing Date, not the date the PSA was signed.

risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'to be continued by Buyer' implies a selection process that may not be clearly defined elsewhere. If the list of assumed contracts isn't finalized before closing, Buyer might inadvertently assume unwanted liabilities.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Service Contracts to be continued by Buyer after the Closing
risk_inventory.title: Ambiguity in Assumed Contracts
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'Service Contracts which Buyer has elected to assume pursuant to Section [Insert Section Number regarding Contract Election] of this Agreement.'

risk_inventory.description: Verify if any Service Contracts require third-party consent to assign and ensure Seller is obligated to obtain those consents prior to Closing.
risk_inventory.title: Contract Consents
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify if any Service Contracts require third-party consent to assign and ensure Seller is obligated to obtain those consents prior to Closing.

risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'to be continued by Buyer' is ambiguous. It could be interpreted as a requirement that the Buyer must assume all existing contracts in the Seller's possession, rather than only those the Buyer specifically elects to assume during the due diligence period. This could force the Buyer into unfavorable vendor relationships.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: to be continued by Buyer after the Closing
risk_inventory.title: Ambiguity Regarding Assumption of Service Contracts
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'which Buyer has expressly elected to assume pursuant to the terms of this Agreement.'

risk_inventory.description: Verify that the 'outside of Escrow' delivery mechanism includes a requirement for a signed receipt or confirmation, as Escrow will not be tracking these documents.
risk_inventory.title: Verification of Contract Delivery
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that the 'outside of Escrow' delivery mechanism includes a requirement for a signed receipt or confirmation, as Escrow will not be tracking these documents.

risk_inventory.description: Allowing the form to be 'reasonably required by the Escrow Holder' may not sufficiently protect the Buyer. As the withholding agent under FIRPTA, the Buyer bears the risk if the affidavit does not strictly comply with IRS Section 1445 requirements. The Buyer should ensure the form meets statutory standards to qualify for the 'Reduced Withholding' or 'Exemption' safe harbor.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: in the form reasonably required by the Escrow Holder
risk_inventory.title: FIRPTA Compliance Form Control
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'in the form required by Section 1445 of the Internal Revenue Code and the regulations thereunder, and otherwise reasonably acceptable to Buyer and Escrow Holder.'

risk_inventory.description: Confirm that the Seller is obligated to provide 'Seller-Affidavits' or 'Gap Indemnities' if required by the Title Company to issue the specific endorsements requested by Buyer.
risk_inventory.title: Title Endorsement Requirements
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm that the Seller is obligated to provide 'Seller-Affidavits' or 'Gap Indemnities' if required by the Title Company to issue the specific endorsements requested by Buyer.

risk_inventory.description: The paragraph explicitly requires the closing statement to be approved in writing by the Seller, but is silent on the Buyer's approval. Both parties must approve the final settlement of prorations, credits, and expenses to prevent unilateral changes by the Seller or Escrow Holder.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: approved in writing by Seller
risk_inventory.title: Missing Buyer Approval of Closing Statement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'approved in writing by Seller and Buyer'

risk_inventory.description: A simple 'notice of sale' is insufficient for post-closing operations. To ensure a smooth transition and protect the Buyer's cash flow, the notice must explicitly direct tenants to pay rent to the new owner/manager and acknowledge the transfer of security deposits to the Buyer (to prevent tenants from seeking refunds from the Seller).
risk_inventory.problematic_text: notifying the tenants under the Leases of the sale of the property
risk_inventory.title: Insufficient Detail in Tenant Notice
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'notifying the tenants under the Leases of the sale of the Property, the transfer of security deposits to Buyer, and providing direction for the payment of rent and other charges following the Closing, in a form reasonably approved by Buyer.'

risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'or otherwise' is overly broad and could be interpreted to allow the Seller or a third party to demand additional, unspecified documents or 'correspondence' as a condition to closing, creating potential delays or administrative burdens.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: or otherwise to close the Escrow and consummate the purchase of the Property
risk_inventory.title: Vague Catch-all for Closing Documents
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'or as reasonably required by Escrow Holder or the Title Company to close the Escrow and consummate the purchase of the Property...'

risk_inventory.description: Verify if there is any specific 'correspondence' intended to be delivered at closing (e.g., notices to tenants). If not, 'correspondence' should be deleted from this paragraph to avoid confusion.
risk_inventory.title: Verification of Required Correspondence
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify if there is any specific 'correspondence' intended to be delivered at closing (e.g., notices to tenants). If not, 'correspondence' should be deleted from this paragraph to avoid confusion.

risk_inventory.description: Allowing deliveries 'on' the Closing Date can lead to failed closings or 'dry' closings if the Escrow Holder does not receive funds and documents early enough to record and disburse. If 'time is of the essence' applies to the Closing Date, the Buyer risks default if a wire is delayed.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: On or before the Closing Date
risk_inventory.title: Timing of Buyer Deliveries
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'At least one (1) Business Day prior to the Closing Date (or such earlier timeframe as may be required by Escrow Holder)'

risk_inventory.description: Confirm that the 'Closing Payment' definition or the general payment section specifies 'immediately available wire transfer funds' to ensure the Buyer is not penalized for check clearing times.
risk_inventory.title: Payment Method Confirmation
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm that the 'Closing Payment' definition or the general payment section specifies 'immediately available wire transfer funds' to ensure the Buyer is not penalized for check clearing times.

risk_inventory.description: Verify which party is responsible for paying the Real Estate Excise Tax (REET). While both parties usually sign the affidavit, the Seller typically pays the tax in most jurisdictions. Ensure the 'Prorations' section aligns with this delivery requirement.
risk_inventory.title: Excise Tax Responsibility
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify which party is responsible for paying the Real Estate Excise Tax (REET). While both parties usually sign the affidavit, the Seller typically pays the tax in most jurisdictions. Ensure the 'Prorations' section aligns with this delivery requirement.

risk_inventory.description: The requirement to execute an 'Assignment and Assumption' of leases implies the Buyer is taking on contractual obligations. Without specific limiting language, the Buyer might inadvertently assume liabilities or defaults created by the Seller prior to the Closing Date.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Assignment and Assumption of Leases duly executed by Buyer
risk_inventory.title: Assumption of Pre-Closing Lease Liabilities
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add: '...provided that such Assignment and Assumption of Leases shall limit Buyer's assumption of obligations to those arising and accruing from and after the Closing Date.'

risk_inventory.description: Review Exhibit D (Assignment and Assumption of Leases) to ensure it contains a robust indemnity from Seller for all lease-related liabilities accruing prior to the Closing Date.
risk_inventory.title: Exhibit D Review
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Review Exhibit D (Assignment and Assumption of Leases) to ensure it contains a robust indemnity from Seller for all lease-related liabilities accruing prior to the Closing Date.

risk_inventory.description: Verify that the form of Assignment of Contracts and Intangibles in Exhibit E includes appropriate representations from Seller regarding the validity and status of the contracts being assigned, and that Buyer is only assuming obligations arising after the Closing Date.
risk_inventory.title: Review Exhibit E (Assignment of Contracts)
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that the form of Assignment of Contracts and Intangibles in Exhibit E includes appropriate representations from Seller regarding the validity and status of the contracts being assigned, and that Buyer is only assuming obligations arising after the Closing Date.

risk_inventory.description: Confirm with tax counsel or a local CPA whether a consumer use tax return is required for this specific jurisdiction and whether the Buyer or Seller is responsible for the actual calculation of the tax due on Personal Property.
risk_inventory.title: Local Use Tax Compliance
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm with tax counsel or a local CPA whether a consumer use tax return is required for this specific jurisdiction and whether the Buyer or Seller is responsible for the actual calculation of the tax due on Personal Property.

risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'or otherwise' is overly broad and could be used to demand that the Buyer produce documents or enter into agreements not previously contemplated or agreed upon in the PSA.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: or otherwise to close the Escrow
risk_inventory.title: Vague Catch-all for Closing Documents
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to 'or as reasonably required by Escrow Holder to close the Escrow'

risk_inventory.description: The defined term 'Title Policy' specifies an 'extended coverage owner's policy.' However, this paragraph shifts the cost of the 'extended' portion of that premium to the Buyer. In many commercial transactions, it is customary for the Seller to pay the full premium for the Owner's Policy (including extended coverage), while the Buyer pays for endorsements and lender-related costs.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller shall pay the premium for the portion of the Title Policy attributable to “standard” coverage. Buyer shall pay the incremental premium to obtain “extended” coverage
risk_inventory.title: Buyer Responsible for Extended Title Coverage Premium
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Seller shall pay the full premium for the Title Policy (including the cost of “extended” coverage).'

risk_inventory.description: Relying on 'county custom' for recording fees can lead to uncertainty and minor disputes at closing, as customs can vary or be interpreted differently by escrow officers.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: paid in the manner customary for the county in which the Property is located
risk_inventory.title: Ambiguous Allocation of Recording Fees
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Recording fees shall be split equally between Buyer and Seller.' (Or specify that Seller pays for recording releases and Buyer pays for recording the Deed).

risk_inventory.description: Since Buyer is responsible for all endorsement costs, ensure that the Due Diligence period allows enough time to receive a title commitment and quote for necessary endorsements (e.g., zoning, survey, access) to budget accordingly.
risk_inventory.title: Endorsement Cost Verification
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Since Buyer is responsible for all endorsement costs, ensure that the Due Diligence period allows enough time to receive a title commitment and quote for necessary endorsements (e.g., zoning, survey, access) to budget accordingly.

risk_inventory.description: The clause excludes deposits 'credited or refunded to tenants as disclosed on the Rent Roll.' If a Seller has applied a security deposit to a tenant's past-due rent prior to closing, the Buyer inherits a lease with no security. The Buyer should require the Seller to replenish any security deposits applied to defaults during the escrow period.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: except for deposits which have been credited or refunded to tenants as disclosed on the Rent Roll
risk_inventory.title: Exclusion of Applied Security Deposits
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'except for deposits which have been refunded to tenants in the ordinary course of business and in accordance with the terms of the Leases, provided that if any deposits have been applied by Seller against a tenant default prior to Closing, Seller shall credit Buyer an amount equal to the deposit so applied.'

risk_inventory.description: While the paragraph allows for post-closing tax adjustments, it does not set a 'cut-off' date. This can lead to indefinite accounting liabilities for the Buyer.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: any difference in ad valorem taxes for the year of sale actually paid by Buyer shall be adjusted between the parties upon receipt of written evidence of the payment thereof.
risk_inventory.title: Lack of Time Limit on Tax Re-Proration
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add: 'The provisions of this Section shall survive the Closing for a period of twelve (12) months, after which time all prorations shall be deemed final.'

risk_inventory.description: Cross-reference the Rent Roll against actual bank statements for security deposit accounts to ensure all 'non-refundable' or 'credited' deposits are legitimate and documented.
risk_inventory.title: Security Deposit Verification
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Cross-reference the Rent Roll against actual bank statements for security deposit accounts to ensure all 'non-refundable' or 'credited' deposits are legitimate and documented.

risk_inventory.description: Seller reserves the right to collect delinquent rents post-closing. While they cannot evict, they could still sue a tenant. This could damage the Buyer's relationship with a key tenant or trigger a tenant to stop paying current rent to the Buyer in retaliation.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller reserves the right after Closing to collect delinquent rents from tenants for periods prior to the Closing Date
risk_inventory.title: Seller's Unrestricted Right to Sue Tenants
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add: '...provided, however, Seller shall not be permitted to commence any legal action or proceeding against any tenant that remains in possession of its premises at the Property without Buyer's prior written consent, which may be withheld in Buyer's sole discretion.'

risk_inventory.description: Review the aged accounts receivable report 5 days before closing to identify which tenants are delinquent and estimate the potential for Seller interference post-closing.
risk_inventory.title: Delinquency Audit
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Review the aged accounts receivable report 5 days before closing to identify which tenants are delinquent and estimate the potential for Seller interference post-closing.

risk_inventory.description: The Buyer is made responsible for repaying tenants for over-collections made by the Seller. If the credit received at closing is based on an inaccurate estimate, the Buyer may end up out-of-pocket when the final reconciliation occurs.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: In either event, Buyer shall be responsible for crediting or repaying those amounts to the appropriate tenants.
risk_inventory.title: Buyer Liability for Seller's Over-Collections
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add: '...provided that Seller shall indemnify and hold Buyer harmless from any claims by tenants for Operating Expense Pass-throughs attributable to Seller’s period of ownership to the extent such amounts exceed the credits provided to Buyer at Closing.'

risk_inventory.description: The clause suggests the Buyer must pay the Seller for under-collections only after 'receipt from said tenants.' This is generally safe, but the Buyer should ensure they are not obligated to use 'best efforts' or incur costs to collect the Seller's money.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: an adjustment will be made between the parties after year-end billing to and receipt from said tenants.
risk_inventory.title: Buyer as Seller's Collection Agent
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add: 'Buyer shall have no obligation to institute legal proceedings or incur any costs to collect such under-collected amounts for the benefit of Seller.'

risk_inventory.description: Verify the 'base year' determinations mentioned in the text. If the Seller has incorrectly calculated the base year, the reconciliation will be flawed, potentially leading to tenant disputes.
risk_inventory.title: Base Year Verification
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify the 'base year' determinations mentioned in the text. If the Seller has incorrectly calculated the base year, the reconciliation will be flawed, potentially leading to tenant disputes.

risk_inventory.description: The Buyer is asked to indemnify the Seller for 'all claims' related to In-Process TI Work. This could include claims arising from the Seller's own negligence, pre-closing contract breaches, or injuries that occurred before the Buyer took title.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall defend, indemnify and hold Seller harmless from all claims, losses, liabilities and expenses (including attorneys' fees and costs) incurred by or asserted against Seller and related to the In Process TI Work.
risk_inventory.title: Overbroad Indemnity for TI Work
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Buyer shall defend, indemnify and hold Seller harmless from all claims... to the extent arising from Buyer's acts or omissions after the Closing Date. Seller shall remain liable for and shall indemnify Buyer against any claims arising from work performed or contracts entered into by Seller prior to the Closing Date.'

risk_inventory.description: If the escrowed funds are insufficient to cover the TI work, the Seller is supposed to reimburse the Buyer. However, if the Seller is a Single Purpose Entity (SPE), 'demand' for reimbursement may be worthless after the Seller has distributed the sale proceeds.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: if the amount in escrow is insufficient for such purpose, Seller shall reimburse Buyer for such deficiency upon demand.
risk_inventory.title: Unsecured Seller Reimbursement for TI Deficiencies
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add: 'Seller's obligation to reimburse Buyer for such deficiency shall survive the Closing for [e.g., 12-24] months and shall be backed by [a parent guaranty/a holdback of proceeds].'

risk_inventory.description: During Due Diligence, obtain a certified list of all 'In Process TI Work,' copies of all contracts, and lien waivers for work completed to date.
risk_inventory.title: TI Status Audit
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: During Due Diligence, obtain a certified list of all 'In Process TI Work,' copies of all contracts, and lien waivers for work completed to date.

risk_inventory.description: The paragraph limits the conditions for closing to only the delivery of funds/documents and title readiness. It fails to include the satisfaction of Seller's representations, warranties, and covenants as a prerequisite for the Escrow Holder to close.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: when and only when each of the following conditions have been satisfied:
risk_inventory.title: Incomplete Conditions to Closing
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'when and only when each of the following conditions have been satisfied or waived in writing by the party for whose benefit the condition exists:' and add a condition: '(iii) Seller has performed all obligations and complied with all covenants required by this Agreement, and all of Seller’s representations and warranties remain true and correct as of the Closing Date.'

risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'All funds and documents' is non-specific. It does not explicitly reference the specific closing deliveries required of the Seller (e.g., FIRPTA affidavit, Bill of Sale, Assignment of Leases).
risk_inventory.problematic_text: All funds and documents have been delivered to Escrow Holder
risk_inventory.title: Vague Document Delivery Requirement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'All funds and documents required to be delivered by Seller and Buyer pursuant to [Insert Section Numbers for Seller/Buyer Deliveries] of this Agreement have been delivered to Escrow Holder;'

risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'prepared to deliver' is legally ambiguous. The standard for closing is that the Title Company must be 'irrevocably committed' to issue the policy in the specific form (including endorsements) agreed upon during due diligence.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Title Company is prepared to deliver the Title Policy.
risk_inventory.title: Weak Title Policy Condition
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Title Company is irrevocably committed to issue the Title Policy to Buyer, in the form and with the endorsements approved by Buyer during the Due Diligence Period, upon the recording of the Deed and the payment of the applicable premium.'

risk_inventory.description: The provision grants interest to the Seller for sums due 'after the Closing.' If the closing is delayed due to the Seller's default or failure to perform, the Seller should not benefit from interest accruing on the purchase price during that delay.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Interest accruing on all sums due Seller after the Closing shall be for the account of Seller.
risk_inventory.title: Ambiguity Regarding Interest on Delayed Closing
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add: '; provided, however, that if Closing is delayed due to a default by Seller, all interest accruing on the Deposit and Closing Payment during such delay shall be for the account of Buyer.'

risk_inventory.description: Verify if the Buyer has specific preferences for the type of 'interest bearing accounts' (e.g., government-backed, money market) to ensure principal protection.
risk_inventory.title: Investment Instructions
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify if the Buyer has specific preferences for the type of 'interest bearing accounts' (e.g., government-backed, money market) to ensure principal protection.

risk_inventory.description: Allowing the Escrow Holder to disburse funds 'as Seller may otherwise direct' creates risks regarding FIRPTA withholding compliance and potential fraudulent transfers. Buyer needs to ensure funds go to the titled owner or a legally authorized agent to avoid tax liability or title challenges.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: or as Seller may otherwise direct.
risk_inventory.title: Unrestricted Third-Party Disbursement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'or as Seller may otherwise direct in writing, provided that any such direction to a third party is subject to Buyer's reasonable approval and compliance with applicable tax withholding requirements, including FIRPTA.'

risk_inventory.description: Confirm with the Escrow Holder that the Deed will be recorded immediately upon Closing and that the 'delivery' to Buyer includes a copy of the recorded instrument with the recorder's stamp.
risk_inventory.title: Verification of Recording Sequence
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm with the Escrow Holder that the Deed will be recorded immediately upon Closing and that the 'delivery' to Buyer includes a copy of the recorded instrument with the recorder's stamp.

risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'party entitled thereto or benefited thereby' is subjective and lacks a specific mechanism for determination. This could lead to disputes at closing regarding the distribution of original documents, keys, or prorated funds if the closing statement is not perfectly aligned with this clause.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: to the party entitled thereto or benefited thereby
risk_inventory.title: Ambiguity in Escrow Item Distribution
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to 'to the party entitled thereto pursuant to the terms of this Agreement and the final Closing Statement approved by Buyer and Seller.'

risk_inventory.description: The provision instructs the Escrow Holder to deliver the Deposit to the Seller upon a default without requiring mutual consent or a judicial determination. This allows a Seller to unilaterally declare a default and demand the funds, potentially forcing the Buyer to sue to recover a Deposit that was wrongfully taken.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: THE ESCROW HOLDER IS HEREBY INSTRUCTED BY SELLER AND BUYER TO DELIVER THE DEPOSIT TO SELLER IN SUCH EVENT
risk_inventory.title: Unilateral Instruction for Deposit Release
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to 'THE ESCROW HOLDER IS HEREBY INSTRUCTED BY SELLER AND BUYER TO DELIVER THE DEPOSIT TO SELLER IN SUCH EVENT ONLY UPON RECEIPT OF JOINT WRITTEN INSTRUCTIONS FROM BUYER AND SELLER OR A FINAL, NON-APPEALABLE ORDER FROM A COURT OF COMPETENT JURISDICTION.'

risk_inventory.description: The liquidated damages are intended to be the 'sole and exclusive remedy.' However, the carve-out for 'indemnification' is dangerously broad. If the general indemnity clause in the agreement (often found in p_15 or similar) includes 'breach of contract,' the Seller could bypass the liquidated damages cap by suing under an indemnity theory.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: THE FOREGOING LIMITATION OF REMEDY SHALL NOT APPLY TO BUYER'S INDEMNIFICATION OR REPAIR AND RESTORATION OBLIGATIONS
risk_inventory.title: Broad Indemnity Carve-out to Liquidated Damages
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to 'THE FOREGOING LIMITATION OF REMEDY SHALL NOT APPLY TO BUYER'S INDEMNIFICATION OBLIGATIONS ARISING OUT OF THIRD-PARTY CLAIMS, OR BUYER'S REPAIR AND RESTORATION OBLIGATIONS...'

risk_inventory.description: Verify local state law requirements for liquidated damages formatting.
risk_inventory.title: Statutory Compliance for Liquidated Damages
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify local state law requirements for liquidated damages formatting.

risk_inventory.description: Ensure both parties actually initial the spaces in p_118. In many jurisdictions, failure to initial the liquidated damages clause specifically renders it void, potentially exposing the Buyer to unlimited damages or specific performance.
risk_inventory.title: Execution Requirement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure both parties actually initial the spaces in p_118. In many jurisdictions, failure to initial the liquidated damages clause specifically renders it void, potentially exposing the Buyer to unlimited damages or specific performance.

risk_inventory.description: The clause explicitly waives the Buyer's right to seek specific performance. In real estate, where properties are unique, the ability to force the Seller to convey the property is the Buyer's most powerful leverage. Without it, a Seller can 'walk' from the deal if they get a better offer, simply by paying a capped amount of costs.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer expressly waives its right to specific performance, and any other damage claims.
risk_inventory.title: Waiver of Specific Performance
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete the waiver of specific performance. Revise to: 'Buyer shall have the right to either (i) terminate this Agreement and receive a refund of the Deposit and the reimbursement of costs described above, or (ii) seek specific performance of this Agreement.'

risk_inventory.description: There is a significant clerical error ('Fifty Hundred Thousand' vs '$50,000'). Furthermore, capping the Buyer's recovery of out-of-pocket costs to $50,000 may be insufficient to cover due diligence, legal fees, and financing costs for a commercial transaction.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: in no event to exceed Fifty Hundred Thousand Dollars ($50,000)
risk_inventory.title: Ambiguous and Capped Cost Reimbursement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Clarify the amount and increase the cap to a more realistic figure (e.g., $100,000 or $250,000 depending on deal size). Change to: 'in no event to exceed One Hundred Thousand Dollars ($100,000).'

risk_inventory.description: The Buyer's right to a remedy is conditioned on 'all other conditions to Seller's obligations... have been satisfied.' This could allow a Seller to intentionally block a condition from being satisfied to avoid being in 'default' and thus avoid paying the Buyer's costs.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: and if all other conditions to Seller's obligations to consummate the sale of the Property to be satisfied as of the date of such default or failure of condition have been satisfied at the time of such default or failure
risk_inventory.title: Conditional Default Remedy
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add: '...satisfied (or waived by Seller, or would have been satisfied but for Seller's default or interference).'

risk_inventory.description: If the Buyer elects to proceed after a casualty, they receive an assignment of insurance proceeds. However, the Seller is not required to credit the Buyer for the amount of the deductible. This effectively increases the Purchase Price for the Buyer by the amount of the deductible.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer shall receive an assignment of the proceeds of any casualty insurance otherwise payable to Seller
risk_inventory.title: Missing Insurance Deductible Credit
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add: '...plus a credit against the Purchase Price in the amount of any deductible under Seller's insurance policy.'

risk_inventory.description: The threshold for what constitutes 'material' damage is left blank. This creates uncertainty regarding when the Buyer has the right to terminate the agreement.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: damage is material if the reasonable estimated cost of repair exceeds $_________
risk_inventory.title: Undefined Materiality Threshold
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Insert a specific dollar amount or a percentage of the Purchase Price (e.g., 5% of the Purchase Price).

risk_inventory.description: Verify Seller's current insurance coverage limits and deductibles to ensure the 'assignment of proceeds' is actually valuable.
risk_inventory.title: Insurance Policy Review
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify Seller's current insurance coverage limits and deductibles to ensure the 'assignment of proceeds' is actually valuable.

risk_inventory.description: While the clause is generally fair, it does not explicitly state that fees incurred in appeals or bankruptcy proceedings are covered, which can be a significant expense.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: reasonable attorney fees, and all other reasonable litigation expenses
risk_inventory.title: Narrow Prevailing Party Definition
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'reasonable attorney fees (including those incurred in connection with any appeals or post-judgment collection proceedings), and all other reasonable litigation expenses...'

risk_inventory.description: The clause allows for email notice but relies on 'electronic confirmation of such delivery.' This can be ambiguous (e.g., does an automated 'delivered' receipt count if the recipient didn't see it?).
risk_inventory.problematic_text: as evidenced by the notifying party's receipt of written or electronic confirmation of such delivery or refusal
risk_inventory.title: Electronic Notice Verification
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add: 'provided that any notice sent by email shall also be sent by overnight courier on the same day to be effective.'

risk_inventory.description: Ensure all addresses, email addresses, and fax numbers for Buyer, Seller, and Sample Law Firm LLP are fully populated in the final execution version.
risk_inventory.title: Missing Contact Information
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure all addresses, email addresses, and fax numbers for Buyer, Seller, and Sample Law Firm LLP are fully populated in the final execution version.

risk_inventory.description: Verify that Section 16 (referenced in p_150) contains specific protocols for email delivery, such as a requirement for a read receipt or a 'deemed received' timeframe, to avoid disputes over whether a notice was actually delivered.
risk_inventory.title: Email Notice Protocol
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that Section 16 (referenced in p_150) contains specific protocols for email delivery, such as a requirement for a read receipt or a 'deemed received' timeframe, to avoid disputes over whether a notice was actually delivered.

risk_inventory.description: This 'Entire Agreement' or merger clause prevents the buyer from relying on any verbal promises, marketing materials, or emails exchanged during negotiations. If the seller made specific claims about the property's condition, income, or zoning that are not explicitly written in this document, the buyer cannot sue for breach based on those claims.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: The parties agree that there are no oral agreements, understandings, representations or warranties that are not expressly set forth herein.
risk_inventory.title: Exclusion of Extrinsic Representations
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Buyer should ensure that all material representations relied upon during due diligence (e.g., rent rolls, environmental reports, or specific seller promises) are explicitly incorporated into the 'Representations and Warranties' section or attached as Exhibits.

risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'where permitted by this Agreement' indicates that the buyer's ability to transfer the contract to a successor or affiliate is restricted elsewhere in the document. For a buyer, the ability to assign the contract to a single-purpose entity (SPE) or an affiliate for financing and liability purposes is critical.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: where permitted by this Agreement.
risk_inventory.title: Conditional Binding Effect on Assigns
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Cross-reference this with the 'Assignment' section of the contract. If the Assignment section requires Seller's consent for all transfers, revise it to allow 'assignment to any entity controlled by, or under common control with, Buyer' without Seller's consent.

risk_inventory.description: The current language requires Seller's consent for assignment but does not require that consent to be reasonably withheld. This allows the Seller to arbitrarily block a legitimate transfer or demand a 'consent fee' to approve a transfer to a third party.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer may not assign its interest under this Agreement without Seller's prior written consent
risk_inventory.title: Unfettered Seller Discretion on Assignment
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Buyer may not assign its interest under this Agreement without Seller's prior written consent, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed.'

risk_inventory.description: The definition of 'control' requires both majority ownership AND managerial control. This may be too restrictive for institutional buyers, private equity funds, or joint ventures where the Buyer entity might be managed by an affiliate that holds a minority stake or where the ownership is split 50/50.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: “control” and similar terms mean ownership of a majority of the beneficial interest in, and managerial control over the assignee entity
risk_inventory.title: Restrictive Definition of Control
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: '“control” and similar terms mean (i) the direct or indirect ownership of more than fifty percent (50%) of the voting and/or beneficial interest in the assignee entity, or (ii) the power to direct the management and policies of such entity.'

risk_inventory.description: Verify if the Buyer intends to remain liable after assignment. The clause is silent on whether the assignor is released. Usually, Sellers insist on the original Buyer remaining liable; if the Buyer wants a 'clean break' upon assignment to a well-capitalized affiliate, language must be added to release the original Buyer.
risk_inventory.title: Original Buyer Liability
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify if the Buyer intends to remain liable after assignment. The clause is silent on whether the assignor is released. Usually, Sellers insist on the original Buyer remaining liable; if the Buyer wants a 'clean break' upon assignment to a well-capitalized affiliate, language must be added to release the original Buyer.

risk_inventory.description: To effect a 1031 exchange, the Buyer must typically assign its rights to a Qualified Intermediary (QI). While the clause mentions cooperation, it should explicitly state that assignment to a QI is permitted without Seller's consent to avoid conflict with the restrictive assignment language in p_154.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: both parties will cooperate to facilitate such an exchange
risk_inventory.title: Lack of Qualified Intermediary Assignment Language
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add: 'Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this Agreement, either party may assign its rights (but not its obligations) under this Agreement to a qualified intermediary for the purpose of effecting a tax-deferred exchange without the other party's consent.'

risk_inventory.description: Cooperating in another party's 1031 exchange can expose the cooperating party to potential tax liabilities or legal costs if the exchange is challenged. The Buyer should be indemnified if the Seller's exchange causes issues.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: neither party shall incur additional cost or expense on the other party's behalf
risk_inventory.title: Missing 1031 Indemnity
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add: 'The party requesting the exchange shall indemnify, defend, and hold the other party harmless from and against any and all liability, claims, or costs (including reasonable attorneys' fees) arising out of or in connection with the requesting party's 1031 exchange.'

risk_inventory.description: The county for venue is left blank. This creates ambiguity and potential for jurisdictional disputes if a lawsuit is filed.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Venue for any dispute under this Agreement shall be in _________ County, Washington.
risk_inventory.title: Missing Venue Designation
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Fill the blank with the county where the Property is located to ensure local jurisdiction.

risk_inventory.description: Consider adding the word 'exclusive' before 'venue' to prevent the parties from attempting to move the case to federal court or another jurisdiction if they have diversity of citizenship.
risk_inventory.title: Exclusive Venue
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Consider adding the word 'exclusive' before 'venue' to prevent the parties from attempting to move the case to federal court or another jurisdiction if they have diversity of citizenship.

risk_inventory.description: Ensure all referenced exhibits (e.g., Legal Description, Bill of Sale form, Assignment of Leases form) are actually attached to the final execution version and have been reviewed for consistency with the main body of the PSA.
risk_inventory.title: Exhibit Completeness
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure all referenced exhibits (e.g., Legal Description, Bill of Sale form, Assignment of Leases form) are actually attached to the final execution version and have been reviewed for consistency with the main body of the PSA.

risk_inventory.description: Verify that all critical dates in the agreement (Closing, Due Diligence expiration, etc.) are realistic and provide sufficient buffer, as 'Time is of the Essence' allows the Seller to terminate for even minor delays.
risk_inventory.title: Strict Deadline Enforcement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that all critical dates in the agreement (Closing, Due Diligence expiration, etc.) are realistic and provide sufficient buffer, as 'Time is of the Essence' allows the Seller to terminate for even minor delays.

risk_inventory.description: This clause allows the Seller to continue marketing the property and negotiating with other buyers even after the contract is signed, up until the end of the Due Diligence Period. This effectively turns the PSA into an 'option' for the Seller and puts the Buyer at risk of being 'gazumped' after spending significant money on inspections and legal fees.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer understands and agrees that Seller shall have the right to continue to market the Property and/or to negotiate with other potential Buyers of the Property until the expiration of the Due Diligence Period and the satisfaction or waiver in writing of all conditions to the obligations of Buyer under this Agreement.
risk_inventory.title: Lack of Exclusivity / Seller's Right to Market
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete the final sentence of p_161 in its entirety to ensure the Buyer has exclusive rights to the property upon execution.

risk_inventory.description: The confidentiality clause does not include an exception for disclosures required by law, subpoena, or government regulation. This could put the Buyer in breach if they are legally compelled to disclose the contract terms (e.g., for tax filings, SEC requirements, or litigation).
risk_inventory.problematic_text: provided that each party may disclose the terms of this Agreement to its lenders, partners, consultants and professional advisors as necessary or convenient for the completion of this transaction.
risk_inventory.title: Narrow Confidentiality Exceptions
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise the proviso to read: 'provided that each party may disclose the terms of this Agreement (i) to its lenders, partners, affiliates, potential investors, consultants and professional advisors as necessary or convenient for the completion of this transaction, or (ii) as may be required by law, court order, or applicable government or securities regulations.'

risk_inventory.description: Verify that any 'further instruments' requested do not expand the Buyer's financial obligations or liabilities beyond those expressly stated in the Agreement.
risk_inventory.title: Scope of Further Assurances
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that any 'further instruments' requested do not expand the Buyer's financial obligations or liabilities beyond those expressly stated in the Agreement.

risk_inventory.description: While mutual, the indemnity requires the Buyer to pay for legal defense and costs if any person claims a commission 'by, through or under' the Buyer. If the Buyer had casual conversations with multiple brokers, this could trigger a duty to defend the Seller.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: each agrees to and does hereby indemnify and hold the other harmless against the payment of any commission to any person or entity claiming by, through or under Seller or Buyer, as applicable.
risk_inventory.title: Broad Mutual Brokerage Indemnity
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure the Buyer has a definitive list of all brokers consulted and specifically excludes them or confirms no agreements exist. No change to text needed if Buyer is certain of their broker relationships.

risk_inventory.description: Ensure the blank spaces for the Broker's name and the 'separate agreement' details are filled and reviewed before execution to ensure the Buyer is not inadvertently responsible for the Broker's Fee.
risk_inventory.title: Incomplete Broker Information
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure the blank spaces for the Broker's name and the 'separate agreement' details are filled and reviewed before execution to ensure the Buyer is not inadvertently responsible for the Broker's Fee.

risk_inventory.description: The Buyer is waiving the right to receive the Washington State Seller Disclosure Statement (Form 17). This statement covers critical items like title, water, sewer, structural, systems, and HOA issues. Waiving this shifts the entire burden of discovery to the Buyer's inspection, with no baseline representation from the Seller.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: BUYER HEREBY WAIVES ITS RIGHT TO RECEIVE THE SELLER DISCLOSURE STATEMENT REFERRED TO THEREIN.
risk_inventory.title: Waiver of Statutory Disclosure Statement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Seller shall provide the Seller Disclosure Statement to Buyer within five (5) days of the Effective Date; provided, however, that Buyer's sole remedy for inaccuracies therein shall be the right to terminate this Agreement during the Review Period.'

risk_inventory.description: The clause appears to force the Buyer to waive the statutory right to rescind the agreement upon receipt of the Environmental disclosure. Under RCW 64.06, a buyer usually has 3 days to rescind after receiving the disclosure. By waiving this 'by executing this Agreement,' the Buyer loses the ability to walk away if the Environmental section reveals contamination or underground tanks.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: by executing this Agreement, Buyer waive [sic]
risk_inventory.title: Waiver of Right to Rescind (Incomplete Clause)
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'Seller shall provide the "Environmental" section of the Seller Disclosure Statement within three (3) days of the Effective Date. Buyer shall have three (3) business days from receipt of such section to rescind this Agreement and receive a full refund of the Earnest Money if the contents are unsatisfactory to Buyer in Buyer's sole discretion.'

risk_inventory.description: The text of p_168 is cut off. Obtain the full text to ensure no additional waivers of liability or rights are hidden in the missing portion.
risk_inventory.title: Incomplete Sentence/Paragraph
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: The text of p_168 is cut off. Obtain the full text to ensure no additional waivers of liability or rights are hidden in the missing portion.

risk_inventory.description: The fragment suggests the Buyer is waiving the right to receive the 'balance' of a completed disclosure. This prevents the Buyer from having a full understanding of known property defects or history before proceeding.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: s its right to receive the balance of the completed Seller Disclosure Statement.
risk_inventory.title: Waiver of Right to Complete Disclosure
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to ensure Buyer receives a fully completed Seller Disclosure Statement: 'Seller shall deliver a fully completed Seller Disclosure Statement within [X] days of the Effective Date.'

risk_inventory.description: The clause exempts the Seller from updating the Disclosure Statement even if new material defects are discovered. This allows the Seller to remain silent about newly discovered issues (e.g., environmental leaks, structural failures) that occur between the initial disclosure and closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Buyer further agrees that any information discovered by Buyer concerning the Property shall not obligate Seller to prepare and deliver to Buyer a revised or updated Seller Disclosure Statement. Buyer hereby waives any right to receive an updated or revised Seller Disclosure Statement, regardless of the source of any new information.
risk_inventory.title: Waiver of Updated Disclosures
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Seller shall be obligated to provide Buyer with an updated Seller Disclosure Statement within three (3) business days of Seller becoming aware of any material change in the condition of the Property or any information that makes the prior disclosure inaccurate.'

risk_inventory.description: The Buyer is forced to warrant they are not relying on the Seller's Disclosure Statement. This 'non-reliance' clause is designed to defeat future claims of fraud or negligent misrepresentation, as the Buyer is contractually agreeing that the Seller's statements did not influence their decision to buy.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: will acquire the Property solely on the basis of and in reliance upon such examinations and not on any information provided in any Seller Disclosure Statement
risk_inventory.title: Disclaimer of Reliance on Disclosures
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'Buyer shall be entitled to rely on the accuracy of the information provided by Seller in the Seller Disclosure Statement, subject to the results of Buyer's independent inspections.'

risk_inventory.description: Verify if the Buyer meets the legal definition of a 'sophisticated buyer' in the relevant jurisdiction, as this status is used here to justify the waiver of standard consumer/buyer protections.
risk_inventory.title: Sophisticated Buyer Status
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify if the Buyer meets the legal definition of a 'sophisticated buyer' in the relevant jurisdiction, as this status is used here to justify the waiver of standard consumer/buyer protections.

risk_inventory.description: In Washington State, RCW 64.06 provides buyers with a statutory right to rescind the agreement if the Seller Disclosure Statement is not provided or contains material errors. This clause waives that protection entirely, even for future updates.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: BUYER HEREBY WAIVES, TO THE FULLEST EXTENT PERMISSIBLE BY LAW, THE RIGHT TO RESCIND THIS AGREEMENT PURSUANT TO ANY PROVISION OF RCW 64.06... THIS WAIVER OF THE RIGHT TO RESCIND APPLIES TO THE SELLER DISCLOSURE STATEMENT PROVIDED TO BUYER DURING THE REVIEW PERIOD AND APPLIES PROSPECTIVELY TO ANY UPDATED OR REVISED SELLER DISCLOSURE STATEMENTS
risk_inventory.title: Waiver of Statutory Rescission Rights (RCW 64.06)
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete this paragraph in its entirety to preserve statutory rescission rights, or at minimum, add: '...provided, however, that Buyer does not waive the right to rescind in the event of intentional misrepresentation or fraud by Seller.'

risk_inventory.description: Confirm if the property type (e.g., commercial vs. residential) triggers RCW 64.06. If the property is strictly commercial, the statute may not apply by default, but the inclusion of this waiver suggests the Seller is attempting to preempt any argument that it does.
risk_inventory.title: Applicability of RCW 64.06
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm if the property type (e.g., commercial vs. residential) triggers RCW 64.06. If the property is strictly commercial, the statute may not apply by default, but the inclusion of this waiver suggests the Seller is attempting to preempt any argument that it does.

risk_inventory.description: Ensure the execution date is filled in accurately at the time of signing to establish the 'Effective Date' if the agreement relies on this for timeline calculations.
risk_inventory.title: Execution Date
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure the execution date is filled in accurately at the time of signing to establish the 'Effective Date' if the agreement relies on this for timeline calculations.

risk_inventory.description: Verify that the individual signing has the legal authority to bind the Buyer entity.
risk_inventory.title: Authorized Signatory
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that the individual signing has the legal authority to bind the Buyer entity.

risk_inventory.description: If the individual signing on behalf of the Seller does not have the legal authority to bind the entity, the contract may be voidable. For a Buyer, this creates significant risk if the Seller attempts to back out of the deal by claiming the signatory lacked corporate authority.
risk_inventory.title: Unverified Signatory Authority
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure the signature block is preceded by the full legal name of the Seller entity and that the signatory is signing in their capacity as an authorized officer (e.g., 'SELLER: [Entity Name], a [State] [Entity Type], By: [Name], Its: [Title]').

risk_inventory.description: Verify that the name entered here matches exactly with the 'Seller' defined in the preamble and the name registered with the Secretary of State.
risk_inventory.title: Entity Name Consistency
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that the name entered here matches exactly with the 'Seller' defined in the preamble and the name registered with the Secretary of State.

risk_inventory.description: Purchase agreements often calculate critical deadlines (Due Diligence Period, Earnest Money Deposit) from the 'Effective Date.' If the execution date is left blank or if there is a gap between the Seller's execution and the Buyer's execution, the timeline for performance becomes ambiguous.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: EXECUTED by Seller on _________________, 20___.
risk_inventory.title: Ambiguous Effective Date Trigger
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add a specific 'Effective Date' provision stating: 'The Effective Date of this Agreement shall be the date upon which the last of the Buyer or Seller has executed this Agreement and delivered a fully executed copy to the other party.'

risk_inventory.description: Confirm whether the Seller or Buyer is expected to sign last, as the final signature date usually dictates the start of the contingency periods.
risk_inventory.title: Execution Sequence
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm whether the Seller or Buyer is expected to sign last, as the final signature date usually dictates the start of the contingency periods.

risk_inventory.description: Similar to the Seller's block, if the Buyer is an entity (LLC/Corp), the signature must reflect that the individual is signing on behalf of the entity to avoid personal liability for the individual and to ensure the entity is properly bound.
risk_inventory.title: Signatory Capacity for Buyer
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure the Buyer's signature block includes the entity name and the word 'By:' before the name line to clarify the representative capacity.

risk_inventory.description: If the Buyer is using a Special Purpose Entity (SPE) for the acquisition, ensure the signatory has been granted authority via a corporate resolution.
risk_inventory.title: Authorized Signatory Verification
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: If the Buyer is using a Special Purpose Entity (SPE) for the acquisition, ensure the signatory has been granted authority via a corporate resolution.

risk_inventory.description: Verify that the legal description inserted here matches the 'Exhibit A' attached to the PSA and, more importantly, matches the legal description provided in the Title Commitment/Preliminary Report.
risk_inventory.title: Legal Description Verification
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that the legal description inserted here matches the 'Exhibit A' attached to the PSA and, more importantly, matches the legal description provided in the Title Commitment/Preliminary Report.

risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'all of its right, title and interest in' is characteristic of a quitclaim deed rather than a warranty deed. A warranty deed should convey the real property itself, not merely whatever interest the Grantor might happen to have. Using 'right, title and interest' can weaken the buyer's ability to claim a breach of the covenant of seisin if the seller actually owns less than a fee simple interest.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: grants, bargains, and conveys, unto the said Grantee all of its right, title and interest in that certain real property
risk_inventory.title: Quitclaim-Style Granting Language
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'grants, bargains, and conveys, unto the said Grantee that certain real property'

risk_inventory.description: While not strictly prohibited, including the assignment of leases within the recorded Special Warranty Deed is unconventional. Leases are typically assigned via a separate 'Assignment and Assumption of Leases.' Including them in the deed makes the leasehold transfer a matter of public record and may complicate the chain of title or lead to requests for lease disclosures from the county assessor.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: and the lessor's or landlord's interest in all space leases or occupancy agreements covering all or any portion of such real property
risk_inventory.title: Inclusion of Leases in Recorded Deed
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Remove the reference to leases from the Deed and ensure they are covered exclusively in a separate Assignment and Assumption of Leases agreement.

risk_inventory.description: Ensure the Grantor name matches the 'Seller' name in the PSA and the 'Vested Owner' in the Title Report. Ensure the Grantee name matches the 'Buyer' (or its designated assignee).
risk_inventory.title: Entity Accuracy
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure the Grantor name matches the 'Seller' name in the PSA and the 'Vested Owner' in the Title Report. Ensure the Grantee name matches the 'Buyer' (or its designated assignee).

risk_inventory.description: The deed is made subject to 'matters set forth in Exhibit B.' If Exhibit B is not strictly limited to the 'Permitted Exceptions' agreed upon during the title review period, the Seller could unilaterally include title defects or encumbrances that the Buyer did not approve, effectively exempting those items from the special warranty of title.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: expressly subject to the matters set forth in Exhibit B attached hereto
risk_inventory.title: Undefined Scope of Exceptions
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'expressly subject only to those Permitted Exceptions set forth in Exhibit B attached hereto, which Permitted Exceptions are defined in that certain Purchase and Sale Agreement between Grantor and Grantee dated [Date].'

risk_inventory.description: The clause expressly excludes all covenants arising by 'statutory or other implication.' In many jurisdictions, statutes provide implied covenants (such as the covenant against encumbrances) that protect the buyer. While this is a Special Warranty Deed, a blanket exclusion of all statutory protections can leave the buyer with less protection than is standard for a special warranty, particularly regarding the grantor's own acts.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: excludes all covenants arising or to arise by statutory or other implication
risk_inventory.title: Broad Exclusion of Statutory Warranties
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'excludes all covenants arising or to arise by statutory or other implication, except to the extent such covenants are consistent with the limited warranty of title expressly set forth herein.'

risk_inventory.description: Verify that the signature block for the Deed includes the correct notary acknowledgment form required by the state where the Real Property is located to ensure the deed is recordable.
risk_inventory.title: Notary/Acknowledgment Requirement
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that the signature block for the Deed includes the correct notary acknowledgment form required by the state where the Real Property is located to ensure the deed is recordable.

risk_inventory.description: Confirm that the 'Attach Legal Description' placeholder is filled with the exact legal description from the Title Commitment and that it matches the Survey.
risk_inventory.title: Legal Description Accuracy
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm that the 'Attach Legal Description' placeholder is filled with the exact legal description from the Title Commitment and that it matches the Survey.

risk_inventory.description: Ensure the list of Permitted Exceptions attached here matches the final list approved by Buyer during the Title/Survey review period.
risk_inventory.title: Permitted Exceptions Consistency
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure the list of Permitted Exceptions attached here matches the final list approved by Buyer during the Title/Survey review period.

risk_inventory.description: The Bill of Sale 'sells, transfers and conveys' the property but does not explicitly state that the Seller owns the property free and clear of liens or that the Seller warrants title to the personal property. Without this, the Buyer may inadvertently take personal property subject to undisclosed security interests or third-party claims.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: does hereby sell, transfer and convey to... all personal property owned by Seller
risk_inventory.title: Lack of Title Warranty for Personal Property
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'does hereby sell, transfer, and convey to Buyer, and warrants title to, all personal property owned by Seller... free and clear of all liens, security interests, and encumbrances.'

risk_inventory.description: The Bill of Sale refers to 'all personal property owned by Seller and located on or in or used in connection with the Property.' If there are specific high-value items (e.g., specialized equipment, vehicles, or proprietary software systems), relying on a general description without a detailed Schedule I can lead to disputes over what was 'used in connection with' the property.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: including, without limitation, those items described in Schedule I
risk_inventory.title: Ambiguity in Personal Property Scope
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure Schedule I is populated with a comprehensive inventory of all significant personal property, including serial numbers or specific identifiers where applicable.

risk_inventory.description: While the seller warrants ownership, the provision lacks an explicit survival period and an indemnity clause. If a third-party lienholder (e.g., an equipment lessor or secured creditor) emerges after closing, the buyer may have limited recourse without a survival clause that extends beyond the deed recording.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Seller hereby represents and warrants to Buyer that Seller is the lawful owner of such personal property, and that such personal property is free and clear of all liens, encumbrances, conditional sales contracts, security interests and claims.
risk_inventory.title: Lack of Survival and Indemnity for Personal Property Title
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Append the following: 'This representation and warranty shall survive the Closing for a period of [e.g., 12-24] months, and Seller shall indemnify, defend, and hold Buyer harmless from any claims, losses, or damages arising from a breach of this representation.'

risk_inventory.description: Verify that a comprehensive, itemized list of all critical equipment, furniture, and fixtures is attached to this exhibit. Ensure serial numbers are included for high-value items to prevent 'swapping' prior to closing.
risk_inventory.title: Inventory Verification
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that a comprehensive, itemized list of all critical equipment, furniture, and fixtures is attached to this exhibit. Ensure serial numbers are included for high-value items to prevent 'swapping' prior to closing.

risk_inventory.description: The title 'Assignment and Assumption' combined with a general preamble often leads to the Buyer (Assignee) inadvertently assuming all liabilities under the leases, including those that accrued prior to the closing date (e.g., unpaid tenant improvements, security deposit disputes, or landlord defaults).
risk_inventory.problematic_text: THIS ASSIGNMENT AND ASSUMPTION OF LEASES (this “Assignment”)... is between [Assignor] and [Assignee].
risk_inventory.title: Unrestricted Assumption of Lease Liabilities
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure the body of this Assignment includes a 'Cut-Off' provision: 'Assignee assumes only those obligations under the Leases that arise and are performable from and after the Closing Date. Assignor shall remain solely liable for all obligations, defaults, and liabilities arising under the Leases prior to the Closing Date, and shall indemnify Assignee against the same.'

risk_inventory.description: Confirm that the 'Assignor' entity is exactly the same legal entity as the 'Seller' in the main PSA, and that the 'Assignee' is the intended taking entity (or its permitted assignee).
risk_inventory.title: Entity Consistency Check
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm that the 'Assignor' entity is exactly the same legal entity as the 'Seller' in the main PSA, and that the 'Assignee' is the intended taking entity (or its permitted assignee).

risk_inventory.description: The definition of 'Leases' is limited to those specifically described in Schedule I. If a lease, amendment, or letter of intent is inadvertently omitted from the schedule, the Buyer may lack the formal assignment of rights needed to enforce that lease or collect rent, despite owning the underlying property.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: which leases are described in Schedule I attached hereto (the “Leases”)
risk_inventory.title: Restrictive Definition of Leases
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'which leases are described in Schedule I attached hereto, together with all amendments, modifications, renewals, or extensions thereof, and all guaranties related thereto (collectively, the “Leases”).'

risk_inventory.description: Cross-reference Schedule I of this Assignment against the certified Rent Roll and the Diligence Materials to ensure every active tenant and license agreement is listed.
risk_inventory.title: Schedule I Reconciliation
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Cross-reference Schedule I of this Assignment against the certified Rent Roll and the Diligence Materials to ensure every active tenant and license agreement is listed.

risk_inventory.description: Ensure the 'dated effective as of' date matches the final execution date of the Purchase and Sale Agreement to avoid incorporation by reference errors.
risk_inventory.title: Consistency of Effective Date
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure the 'dated effective as of' date matches the final execution date of the Purchase and Sale Agreement to avoid incorporation by reference errors.

risk_inventory.description: The assignment transfers 'right, title and interest' in the Leases but does not explicitly mention the transfer of physical security deposits, letters of credit, or prepaid rents. Without explicit language, the Buyer may face claims from tenants for the return of deposits that the Seller failed to actually credit or transfer at closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Assignor hereby assigns to Assignee all of its right, title and interest in and to the Leases
risk_inventory.title: Omission of Security Deposits and Prepaid Rents
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'Assignor hereby assigns to Assignee all of its right, title and interest in and to the Leases, including, without limitation, all security deposits, letters of credit, and prepaid rents held by Assignor in connection with the Leases.'

risk_inventory.description: The paragraph assigns the leases but fails to allocate liability for breaches occurring before the Conveyance Date. The Buyer could be held liable by tenants for the Seller's prior defaults (e.g., failure to maintain the premises or overcharging CAM) without a clear indemnity from the Seller.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Assignor hereby assigns to Assignee all of its right, title and interest in and to the Leases;
risk_inventory.title: Lack of Liability Allocation (Pre-Closing vs. Post-Closing)
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add the following: 'Assignor shall indemnify and hold Assignee harmless from any claims or liabilities arising under the Leases prior to the Conveyance Date. Assignee shall indemnify and hold Assignor harmless from any claims or liabilities arising under the Leases from and after the Conveyance Date.'

risk_inventory.description: Verify if any tenant security deposits are held as Letters of Credit. If so, ensure the assignment includes language requiring the Seller to cooperate in the formal transfer of the LC beneficiary rights with the issuing bank.
risk_inventory.title: Letter of Credit Transfer Requirements
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify if any tenant security deposits are held as Letters of Credit. If so, ensure the assignment includes language requiring the Seller to cooperate in the formal transfer of the LC beneficiary rights with the issuing bank.

risk_inventory.description: The indemnity is limited to 'obligations under the Leases.' This may not cover liabilities arising from the Seller's tortious acts, omissions, or negligence that occurred on the property prior to closing but are not strictly 'obligations' defined within the lease document itself.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: arising out of the Assignor's obligations under the Leases
risk_inventory.title: Narrow Scope of Seller Indemnity
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'arising out of the Assignor's ownership of the Leases or the Assignor's acts or omissions related thereto occurring prior to the Conveyance Date.'

risk_inventory.description: Verify that the survival period for this indemnity matches the general survival period for representations and warranties in the main Purchase and Sale Agreement (PSA).
risk_inventory.title: Survival Period Alignment
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that the survival period for this indemnity matches the general survival period for representations and warranties in the main Purchase and Sale Agreement (PSA).

risk_inventory.description: The current language has the Buyer assuming 'all' obligations. Without qualifying that these are obligations 'to be performed after' the closing, the Buyer could inadvertently assume liability for the Seller's past breaches or unperformed maintenance that should have been completed prior to the Conveyance Date.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Assignee hereby assumes all of Assignor's obligations under the Leases
risk_inventory.title: Broad Assumption of Past Obligations
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Assignee hereby assumes all of Assignor's obligations under the Leases first arising and required to be performed from and after the Conveyance Date.'

risk_inventory.description: Ensure this 'prevailing party' clause does not conflict with the dispute resolution or arbitration sections in the main PSA (e.g., if the PSA requires mediation before fee-shifting applies).
risk_inventory.title: Consistency with PSA Dispute Resolution
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure this 'prevailing party' clause does not conflict with the dispute resolution or arbitration sections in the main PSA (e.g., if the PSA requires mediation before fee-shifting applies).

risk_inventory.description: The paragraph uses 'Assignor' and 'Assignee', whereas the defined terms for the 'Agreement' typically refer to 'Seller' and 'Buyer'. If this paragraph is intended to be the signature block for the main Purchase and Sale Agreement, the terminology is inconsistent. If it is part of an Exhibit (Assignment form), it should clearly distinguish itself from the 'Agreement' defined in the preamble.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Assignor and Assignee have executed this Agreement
risk_inventory.title: Inconsistent Party Naming
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change 'Assignor and Assignee' to 'Seller and Buyer' if this is the PSA signature page. If this is an Exhibit, change 'this Agreement' to 'this Assignment'.

risk_inventory.description: Linking the execution to the 'day and year first written above' can be problematic for assignment documents. Assignments should generally be effective as of the 'Closing Date' to ensure a clean break in liability and right to income. If the date 'first written above' is the date of the PSA (the reference date), the assignment might technically pre-date the actual transfer of title.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: as of the day and year first written above.
risk_inventory.title: Effective Date Ambiguity
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to 'as of the Closing Date' or 'as of the date of the Closing' to ensure the transfer of leases and contracts aligns with the transfer of the Real Property.

risk_inventory.description: The defined term 'Rent Roll' refers to the version identified in the 'Due Diligence Documents'. For the purpose of the Assignment and Assumption of Leases, the Buyer needs the most current version. Relying on an old Rent Roll from the DD period may exclude new leases or amendments executed during the escrow period.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: (List of Leases – Rent Roll)
risk_inventory.title: Static Rent Roll Reference
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise the placeholder to require: 'The Rent Roll as of the Closing Date, certified by Seller as true, correct, and complete, and attached hereto as Exhibit A-1.'

risk_inventory.description: Ensure that the final version of this schedule includes not just the Rent Roll, but all active lease amendments, letter agreements, and guarantees to ensure all 'Leases' (as defined) are legally transferred.
risk_inventory.title: Verify Lease Schedule Completeness
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure that the final version of this schedule includes not just the Rent Roll, but all active lease amendments, letter agreements, and guarantees to ensure all 'Leases' (as defined) are legally transferred.

risk_inventory.description: The paragraph is a header for the 'Assignment and Assumption of Contracts and Intangibles'. As a Buyer, it is critical that the actual form of this assignment (usually an Exhibit) contains a 'further assurances' clause and a clear indemnity where the Seller remains liable for all obligations arising prior to the Closing Date.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Assignment and Assumption of Contracts and Intangibles
risk_inventory.title: Missing Form of Assignment Protections
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure the form of assignment includes: 'Assignor shall indemnify and hold Assignee harmless from any claims arising from the Contracts and Intangibles prior to the Closing Date, and Assignee shall indemnify Assignor for claims arising on or after the Closing Date.'

risk_inventory.description: Verify if any of the 'Contracts' being assigned require third-party consent. The Assignment form should include a representation that all necessary consents have been obtained.
risk_inventory.title: Contract Consent Review
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify if any of the 'Contracts' being assigned require third-party consent. The Assignment form should include a representation that all necessary consents have been obtained.

risk_inventory.description: Ensure the date of this Assignment is the actual Closing Date of the transaction to avoid gaps in liability or operational authority.
risk_inventory.title: Effective Date Alignment
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure the date of this Assignment is the actual Closing Date of the transaction to avoid gaps in liability or operational authority.

risk_inventory.description: The definition of 'Contracts' is limited strictly to those listed on Schedule I. If a critical service contract is inadvertently omitted from the schedule, the Buyer may lack the legal standing to enforce it or benefit from its terms post-closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: which service contracts are described in Schedule I attached hereto (the “Contracts”)
risk_inventory.title: Restrictive Definition of Contracts
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'which service contracts are described in Schedule I attached hereto, and all other service contracts affecting the Property which Assignee has agreed to assume in writing (collectively, the “Contracts”).'

risk_inventory.description: Cross-reference Schedule I against the list of Service Contracts approved during the Due Diligence period to ensure no critical utilities or maintenance agreements are missing.
risk_inventory.title: Schedule I Reconciliation
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Cross-reference Schedule I against the list of Service Contracts approved during the Due Diligence period to ensure no critical utilities or maintenance agreements are missing.

risk_inventory.description: Verify that the date and parties of the Purchase and Sale Agreement (PSA) are correctly inserted to ensure the incorporation by reference is legally valid.
risk_inventory.title: PSA Reference Accuracy
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that the date and parties of the Purchase and Sale Agreement (PSA) are correctly inserted to ensure the incorporation by reference is legally valid.

risk_inventory.description: The phrase 'certain intangible personal property' is dangerously vague. It implies a limitation that could exclude critical assets like building warranties, permits, licenses, trade names, or architectural plans. As the Buyer, you want an assignment of *all* intangibles.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: certain intangible personal property with respect to the Property
risk_inventory.title: Vague Definition of Intangibles
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change 'certain intangible personal property' to 'all intangible personal property owned by Assignor and used in connection with the Real Property and Improvements, including, without limitation, all warranties, guarantees, licenses, permits, approvals, certificates of occupancy, and trade names.'

risk_inventory.description: The provision excludes all claims by the Assignor arising from matters before the Conveyance Date. This is problematic if there are outstanding warranty claims, insurance claims for property damage, or causes of action against contractors for defective work performed prior to closing. The Buyer needs these claims to offset the cost of repairs or to enforce warranties.
