risk_inventory.problematic_text: excluding claims by Assignor, if any, arising out of matters occurring before the Conveyance Date
risk_inventory.title: Broad Exclusion of Pre-Closing Claims
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise to: 'excluding claims by Assignor, if any, arising out of matters occurring before the Conveyance Date, except to the extent such claims relate to the physical condition of the Property, warranties for Improvements, or the value of the Intangible Property from and after the Conveyance Date.'

risk_inventory.description: Verify if any of the 'Contracts' or 'Intangible Property' require third-party consents for assignment. If so, ensure the main PSA requires Seller to obtain these consents as a condition to closing.
risk_inventory.title: Contract Assignability
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify if any of the 'Contracts' or 'Intangible Property' require third-party consents for assignment. If so, ensure the main PSA requires Seller to obtain these consents as a condition to closing.

risk_inventory.description: The Seller's indemnity is limited strictly to 'obligations under the Contracts.' It does not cover liabilities arising from the 'Intangible Property' (such as IP infringement or permit violations) or general liabilities related to the ownership/operation of the property prior to the Conveyance Date.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: arising out of Assignor's obligations under the Contracts
risk_inventory.title: Narrow Indemnity Scope
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'arising out of Assignor's ownership or operation of the Property, the Intangible Property, or Assignor's obligations under the Contracts.'

risk_inventory.description: The term 'originating' is ambiguous. It is unclear if it refers to when the underlying act occurred, when the obligation accrued, or when a third party filed a claim. Using 'accruing' or 'occurring' is standard for clarity.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: originating prior to the Conveyance Date
risk_inventory.title: Ambiguous Trigger for Indemnity
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'accruing or arising out of acts or omissions occurring prior to the Conveyance Date'

risk_inventory.description: The Buyer is assuming 'all' obligations under the Contracts. Without a temporal qualifier, the Buyer could be held liable for the Seller's pre-closing breaches or unpaid balances that existed prior to the Conveyance Date. The assumption should be limited to obligations first arising after the transfer.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Assignee hereby assumes all of Assignor's obligations under the Contracts
risk_inventory.title: Unrestricted Assumption of Obligations
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to: 'Assignee hereby assumes all of Assignor's obligations under the Contracts to the extent such obligations first arise and are required to be performed from and after the Conveyance Date.'

risk_inventory.description: Ensure the 'Conveyance Date' in this assignment matches the 'Closing Date' or 'Proration Date' in the main PSA to prevent gaps in liability coverage.
risk_inventory.title: Proration Alignment
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure the 'Conveyance Date' in this assignment matches the 'Closing Date' or 'Proration Date' in the main PSA to prevent gaps in liability coverage.

risk_inventory.description: While the clause allows for counterparts, it does not explicitly authorize the delivery of signature pages via electronic means (PDF/DocuSign). In modern transactions, relying solely on 'originals' can cause delays or disputes regarding the validity of the execution if wet-ink originals are not immediately exchanged.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: This Assignment may be executed in any number of counterparts, each of which shall be deemed an original, but all of which taken together shall constitute one and the same instrument.
risk_inventory.title: Ambiguity Regarding Electronic Signatures
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add the following: 'Delivery of an executed counterpart of this Assignment by facsimile or other electronic transmission (including .pdf or electronic signature) shall be equally as effective as delivery of a manually executed counterpart.'

risk_inventory.description: The title 'Assignment and Assumption' suggests the Buyer will take on all obligations under the Service Contracts. Without specific 'cut-off' language in the actual form of this schedule, the Buyer risks assuming liabilities for Seller's pre-closing defaults or unpaid invoices.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Assignment and Assumption of Contracts and Intangible Property
risk_inventory.title: Risk of Unfiltered Assumption of Liabilities
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure the form of Assignment associated with this Schedule explicitly states: 'Assignee assumes only those obligations under the Service Contracts arising from and after the Closing Date, and Assignor shall remain liable for all obligations and liabilities arising prior to the Closing Date.'

risk_inventory.description: Verify that the Buyer has the right to designate which Service Contracts are being assumed and which must be terminated by the Seller prior to closing, rather than a blanket assumption of all 'Intangible Property' as defined.
risk_inventory.title: Verify Contract Termination Rights
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that the Buyer has the right to designate which Service Contracts are being assumed and which must be terminated by the Seller prior to closing, rather than a blanket assumption of all 'Intangible Property' as defined.

risk_inventory.description: A 'Certificate of Rent Roll' is only as valuable as the standard of accuracy it guarantees. If the certificate is qualified by 'to the best of Seller's knowledge' or lacks a survival period, the Buyer has limited recourse if the rent, security deposits, or lease terms are discovered to be inaccurate post-closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: Certificate of Rent Roll
risk_inventory.title: Inadequate Rent Roll Certification
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure the form of Certificate requires the Seller to certify that the Rent Roll is 'true, correct, and complete in all material respects' and that this certification survives the closing for the same period as the general Representations and Warranties.

risk_inventory.description: Compare the data in the Rent Roll Certificate against Tenant Estoppel Certificates to identify discrepancies in security deposits or lease expiration dates.
risk_inventory.title: Cross-Reference Rent Roll with Estoppels
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Compare the data in the Rent Roll Certificate against Tenant Estoppel Certificates to identify discrepancies in security deposits or lease expiration dates.

risk_inventory.description: The Seller is qualifying the accuracy of the Rent Roll to 'actual knowledge, without investigating.' This 'head-in-the-sand' standard allows the Seller to avoid liability for inaccuracies that could have been discovered through a simple review of their own records. For a Buyer, the Rent Roll is a fundamental valuation document; its accuracy should be absolute or at least based on a diligent review of the leases.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: to its actual knowledge, without investigating
risk_inventory.title: Weak Knowledge Qualifier in Rent Roll Certification
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Delete 'to its actual knowledge, without investigating' and replace with 'Seller represents and warrants that...'

risk_inventory.description: The use of 'in all material respects' regarding a Rent Roll is problematic. Specific financial figures such as security deposit amounts, monthly rent, and arrearages should be precise. A 'materiality' threshold allows for small discrepancies across many units that can aggregate into a significant financial shortfall for the Buyer post-closing.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: true and correct in all material respects
risk_inventory.title: Materiality Qualifier on Financial Data
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Change to 'true, correct, and complete.' If a materiality qualifier must remain, define it as a specific dollar threshold (e.g., 'in all respects except for variances not exceeding $500 in the aggregate').

risk_inventory.description: Ensure that the 'attached Rent Roll' referenced in this certificate is the final, updated version provided at the end of the due diligence period, and not an outdated version from the initial offering.
risk_inventory.title: Verification of Rent Roll Attachment
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Ensure that the 'attached Rent Roll' referenced in this certificate is the final, updated version provided at the end of the due diligence period, and not an outdated version from the initial offering.

risk_inventory.description: Verify that the blank date for the certification is required to be as of the Closing Date or no more than 3-5 days prior to Closing to ensure the data is current.
risk_inventory.title: Certification Date
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify that the blank date for the certification is required to be as of the Closing Date or no more than 3-5 days prior to Closing to ensure the data is current.

risk_inventory.description: If the PSA mandates a specific 'Form of Estoppel Certificate' without allowing for lender-requested modifications, the Buyer may find the delivered estoppels insufficient to satisfy financing requirements. Lenders often require specific language regarding offsets, defaults, and subordination that may not be in a generic exhibit form.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: [p_405] Form of Estoppel Certificate
risk_inventory.title: Inflexible Estoppel Form
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Revise the reference to the exhibit in the main body of the PSA to state: '...in the form attached hereto as Exhibit [X], or such other form as may be reasonably required by Buyer’s lender, provided that Seller shall not be required to request a tenant to provide an estoppel in a form more extensive than required under such tenant’s Lease.'

risk_inventory.description: Verify with the Buyer's lender whether the form attached as [p_405] contains the necessary certifications regarding 'no defaults,' 'no prepaid rent,' and 'no landlord obligations for TIs/commissions.'
risk_inventory.title: Lender Requirements
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Verify with the Buyer's lender whether the form attached as [p_405] contains the necessary certifications regarding 'no defaults,' 'no prepaid rent,' and 'no landlord obligations for TIs/commissions.'

risk_inventory.description: A static checklist often omits critical items such as environmental 'Phase I' reports, structural/mechanical surveys, historical utility bills, or unrecorded licenses/permits. If the Seller is only obligated to provide items on this specific list, the Buyer may be deprived of material information during the contingency period.
risk_inventory.problematic_text: [p_411] Due Diligence Checklist
risk_inventory.title: Incomplete Due Diligence Checklist
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Add a 'catch-all' provision to the end of the checklist: '...and any and all other material documents, reports, studies, or correspondence in Seller’s possession or control relating to the ownership, operation, maintenance, or physical condition of the Property.'

risk_inventory.description: Confirm that the 'Due Diligence Period' or 'Inspection Period' does not commence until the Seller has delivered all items listed in [p_411] to the Buyer's data room.
risk_inventory.title: Due Diligence Clock
risk_inventory.user_recommendation: Confirm that the 'Due Diligence Period' or 'Inspection Period' does not commence until the Seller has delivered all items listed in [p_411] to the Buyer's data room.

R1.description: The term 'delivered' is not defined. In a dispute, it may be unclear whether delivery occurs upon hitting 'send' on an email, physical receipt by a party, or receipt by their respective legal counsel. Since the Effective Date triggers all contingency periods (due diligence, financing, etc.), any ambiguity can lead to missed deadlines.
R1.title: Ambiguity in 'Delivery' for Effective Date

R10.description: By limiting the definition to property 'owned by Seller,' the buyer may lose out on property used in operations that is being financed or held under a capital lease where title hasn't technically passed, even if the buyer is expected to assume the obligation.
R10.title: Ownership Limitation on Personal Property

R100.description: The Buyer can only terminate if the change has a 'material adverse impact' in Buyer's 'reasonable judgment.' This is a high bar and could lead to disputes over what constitutes 'material' if the Buyer wants to walk away from a tainted deal.
R100.title: Subjective Materiality Threshold

R101.description: A 5-day window for Buyer to object to new leases or modifications is extremely short. If the Buyer fails to respond within this window, they are 'conclusively deemed' to have approved the lease, which could include unfavorable terms or high tenant improvement costs.
R101.title: Short Deemed Approval Period for Leases

R102.description: The clause makes Buyer responsible for all leasing commissions and TI costs for leases approved after the DD period. This should be contingent on the Closing actually occurring.
R102.title: Unconditional Buyer Liability for New Lease Costs

R103.description: Confirm that the property management agreement can be terminated 'as of Closing' without penalty to the Buyer, and that Seller is responsible for any termination fees.
R103.title: Property Management Termination

R104.description: Seller is not obligated to terminate Service Contracts if it creates 'additional cost or liability.' This could force the Buyer to assume contracts they explicitly rejected during Due Diligence if those contracts have termination fees.
R104.title: Seller's Refusal to Terminate Contracts

R105.description: The clause requires Seller to maintain insurance 'currently in force.' If the Seller's current coverage is inadequate or expires during the escrow period, the Buyer has no protection requiring the Seller to maintain industry-standard coverage or specific limits.
R105.title: Vague Insurance Maintenance Standard

R106.description: The percentage and square footage requirements for the 'Minimum Tenant Estoppels' are blank. Without these numbers, the condition is unenforceable or provides the Buyer with no guaranteed level of tenant verification.
R106.title: Unspecified Minimum Estoppel Threshold

R107.description: The Seller's Lease Certificate (used when a tenant fails to provide an estoppel) is limited to 'Seller's knowledge.' This shifts the risk of lease disputes to the Buyer if the Seller claims they 'didn't know' about a tenant's side agreement or default.
R107.title: Weak Seller Lease Certificate Standard

R108.description: The Seller explicitly disclaims any obligation to obtain subordination agreements, which may be a requirement for the Buyer's lender.
R108.title: No Obligation for Subordination Agreements

R109.description: Verify that Exhibit G (the Estoppel form) contains all necessary lender-required language, including confirmation of rent, security deposits, and no landlord defaults.
R109.title: Exhibit G Review

R11.description: Ensure the bracketed exclusion list is completed and that a full inventory of included personal property (FF&E) is attached as an exhibit.
R11.title: Personal Property Inventory

R110.description: The Buyer is required to release all third-party sources and preparers of information (e.g., environmental consultants, surveyors, engineers) retained by the Seller. This prevents the Buyer from seeking recourse against a professional who may have committed malpractice in a report the Buyer relied upon.
R110.title: Broad Release of Third-Party Information Providers

R111.description: Seller disclaims the accuracy or completeness of all due diligence materials. While common in 'As-Is' sales, this can be problematic if the Seller provides misleading or incomplete records intentionally.
R111.title: Disclaimer of Accuracy of Due Diligence Materials

R112.description: Confirm that Section 7 (referenced as the exception to the AS-IS clause) contains robust representations regarding environmental, zoning, and physical condition to balance this broad disclaimer.
R112.title: Section 7 Cross-Reference

R113.description: The release is so broad ('any and all losses... arising out of or in any way connected with the Property') that it could be interpreted to release the Seller from a breach of the representations and warranties in Section 7 immediately upon Closing, rendering the survival period useless.
R113.title: Release Extinguishes Seller's Reps and Warranties

R114.description: The environmental release only carves out claims for hazardous substances 'caused by Seller.' It is often difficult to prove the Seller 'caused' a release versus merely owning the property while it existed. This could prevent the Buyer from seeking contribution for pre-existing conditions.
R114.title: Narrow Environmental Carve-out

R115.description: The release of the Seller is broad and only carves out specific representations in Section 7.1 and post-closing obligations. It fails to carve out fraud, intentional misrepresentation, or breaches of the purchase agreement itself occurring prior to closing that are discovered later.
R115.title: Narrow Carve-outs from Release

R116.description: The current language only applies 50% of the second extension fee toward the Purchase Price. This effectively increases the cost of the property if the Buyer needs the full extension period, penalizing the Buyer for using a right they are paying for.
R116.title: Partial Application of Extension Fee

R117.description: The extension fee is only refundable in the event of a Seller default. If the contract terminates due to other reasons where the Buyer is typically entitled to a refund of the Deposit (e.g., failure of a condition precedent, title defects, casualty, or condemnation), the Buyer would lose the Extension Fee.
R117.title: Limited Refundability of Extension Fees

R118.description: Ensure the number of business days required for notice (currently blank) provides enough time for the Buyer to evaluate the need for an extension without being so long that it creates a 'dead zone' before closing.
R118.title: Verify Extension Notice Period

R119.description: The language grants possession subject to 'rights of tenants in possession under Leases.' If 'Leases' is not strictly defined to only include those disclosed to and approved by Buyer, the Buyer could be forced to accept undisclosed occupants or 'squatters' claiming leasehold rights.
R119.title: Possession Subject to Undisclosed Leases

R12.description: The phrase 'to the extent transferable' is self-executing and does not obligate the Seller to actually attempt to transfer the property or obtain necessary consents from third parties (like software licensors or permit issuers).
R12.title: Passive Transfer Obligation

R120.description: Allowing Seller to deliver documents 'on' the Closing Date can lead to delays in funding and recording, especially if the Escrow Holder requires time to review documents or if the wire transfer cut-off times are early in the day.
R120.title: Late Delivery of Closing Documents

R121.description: The list of documents following [p_81] (in the next batch) must be reviewed to ensure all necessary transfer tax forms, affidavits of non-foreign status, and tenant notices are included.
R121.title: Review Seller's Delivery List

R122.description: The defined terms specify a 'special warranty deed.' In Washington, this only warrants against defects arising during the Seller's period of ownership. A Buyer typically prefers a 'Statutory Warranty Deed,' which provides broader protection against title defects regardless of when they arose.
R122.title: Limited Title Warranty (Special Warranty Deed)

R123.description: Verify that the agreement requires both Buyer and Seller to execute the Real Estate Excise Tax (REET) Affidavit, as Washington law generally requires both signatures for processing.
R123.title: REET Affidavit Execution

R124.description: Review Exhibit C (Bill of Sale) to ensure it includes a warranty of title for personal property and explicitly includes all 'Improvements' and 'Personal Property' defined in the agreement.
R124.title: Bill of Sale Scope

R125.description: The paragraph mentions assigning interest in the Leases but does not explicitly mention the transfer of or credit for tenant security deposits. Without explicit language, there may be a dispute over whether the cash for deposits is transferred at closing.
R125.title: Security Deposit Transfer

R126.description: Delivering original leases 'outside of Escrow' means the Escrow Agent cannot verify delivery before releasing funds. If Seller fails to hand over the physical files at the property, Buyer has little leverage post-closing.
R126.title: Delivery Outside of Escrow

R127.description: The qualifier 'in Seller's possession or control' allows Seller to avoid providing leases they may have lost or misplaced. Buyer needs all original leases to enforce rights against tenants.
R127.title: Possession or Control Limitation

R128.description: Ensure Exhibit F (Certificate of Rent Roll) requires the Seller to certify the rent roll as of the actual Closing Date, not the date the PSA was signed.
R128.title: Rent Roll Currency

R129.description: The phrase 'to be continued by Buyer' implies a selection process that may not be clearly defined elsewhere. If the list of assumed contracts isn't finalized before closing, Buyer might inadvertently assume unwanted liabilities.
R129.title: Ambiguity in Assumed Contracts

R13.description: The exclusion of all claims against third parties relating to the period prior to closing is dangerous. If there is a latent construction defect, a warranty claim for a roof installed a year ago, or an unpaid insurance claim for recent damage, the Buyer needs these claims to be assigned so they can recover costs for repairs they will eventually have to make.
R13.title: Broad Exclusion of Pre-Closing Claims

R130.description: Verify if any Service Contracts require third-party consent to assign and ensure Seller is obligated to obtain those consents prior to Closing.
R130.title: Contract Consents

R131.description: The phrase 'to be continued by Buyer' is ambiguous. It could be interpreted as a requirement that the Buyer must assume all existing contracts in the Seller's possession, rather than only those the Buyer specifically elects to assume during the due diligence period. This could force the Buyer into unfavorable vendor relationships.
R131.title: Ambiguity Regarding Assumption of Service Contracts

R132.description: Verify that the 'outside of Escrow' delivery mechanism includes a requirement for a signed receipt or confirmation, as Escrow will not be tracking these documents.
R132.title: Verification of Contract Delivery

R133.description: Allowing the form to be 'reasonably required by the Escrow Holder' may not sufficiently protect the Buyer. As the withholding agent under FIRPTA, the Buyer bears the risk if the affidavit does not strictly comply with IRS Section 1445 requirements. The Buyer should ensure the form meets statutory standards to qualify for the 'Reduced Withholding' or 'Exemption' safe harbor.
R133.title: FIRPTA Compliance Form Control

R134.description: Confirm that the Seller is obligated to provide 'Seller-Affidavits' or 'Gap Indemnities' if required by the Title Company to issue the specific endorsements requested by Buyer.
R134.title: Title Endorsement Requirements

R135.description: The paragraph explicitly requires the closing statement to be approved in writing by the Seller, but is silent on the Buyer's approval. Both parties must approve the final settlement of prorations, credits, and expenses to prevent unilateral changes by the Seller or Escrow Holder.
R135.title: Missing Buyer Approval of Closing Statement

R136.description: A simple 'notice of sale' is insufficient for post-closing operations. To ensure a smooth transition and protect the Buyer's cash flow, the notice must explicitly direct tenants to pay rent to the new owner/manager and acknowledge the transfer of security deposits to the Buyer (to prevent tenants from seeking refunds from the Seller).
R136.title: Insufficient Detail in Tenant Notice

R137.description: The phrase 'or otherwise' is overly broad and could be interpreted to allow the Seller or a third party to demand additional, unspecified documents or 'correspondence' as a condition to closing, creating potential delays or administrative burdens.
R137.title: Vague Catch-all for Closing Documents

R138.description: Verify if there is any specific 'correspondence' intended to be delivered at closing (e.g., notices to tenants). If not, 'correspondence' should be deleted from this paragraph to avoid confusion.
R138.title: Verification of Required Correspondence

R139.description: Allowing deliveries 'on' the Closing Date can lead to failed closings or 'dry' closings if the Escrow Holder does not receive funds and documents early enough to record and disburse. If 'time is of the essence' applies to the Closing Date, the Buyer risks default if a wire is delayed.
R139.title: Timing of Buyer Deliveries

R14.description: Review all 'Service Contracts' to determine which are terminable and which must be assumed, as this definition automatically includes them in the purchase.
R14.title: Service Contract Review

R140.description: Confirm that the 'Closing Payment' definition or the general payment section specifies 'immediately available wire transfer funds' to ensure the Buyer is not penalized for check clearing times.
R140.title: Payment Method Confirmation

R141.description: Verify which party is responsible for paying the Real Estate Excise Tax (REET). While both parties usually sign the affidavit, the Seller typically pays the tax in most jurisdictions. Ensure the 'Prorations' section aligns with this delivery requirement.
R141.title: Excise Tax Responsibility

R142.description: The requirement to execute an 'Assignment and Assumption' of leases implies the Buyer is taking on contractual obligations. Without specific limiting language, the Buyer might inadvertently assume liabilities or defaults created by the Seller prior to the Closing Date.
R142.title: Assumption of Pre-Closing Lease Liabilities

R143.description: Review Exhibit D (Assignment and Assumption of Leases) to ensure it contains a robust indemnity from Seller for all lease-related liabilities accruing prior to the Closing Date.
R143.title: Exhibit D Review

R144.description: Verify that the form of Assignment of Contracts and Intangibles in Exhibit E includes appropriate representations from Seller regarding the validity and status of the contracts being assigned, and that Buyer is only assuming obligations arising after the Closing Date.
R144.title: Review Exhibit E (Assignment of Contracts)

R145.description: Confirm with tax counsel or a local CPA whether a consumer use tax return is required for this specific jurisdiction and whether the Buyer or Seller is responsible for the actual calculation of the tax due on Personal Property.
R145.title: Local Use Tax Compliance

R146.description: The phrase 'or otherwise' is overly broad and could be used to demand that the Buyer produce documents or enter into agreements not previously contemplated or agreed upon in the PSA.
R146.title: Vague Catch-all for Closing Documents

R147.description: The defined term 'Title Policy' specifies an 'extended coverage owner's policy.' However, this paragraph shifts the cost of the 'extended' portion of that premium to the Buyer. In many commercial transactions, it is customary for the Seller to pay the full premium for the Owner's Policy (including extended coverage), while the Buyer pays for endorsements and lender-related costs.
R147.title: Buyer Responsible for Extended Title Coverage Premium

R148.description: Relying on 'county custom' for recording fees can lead to uncertainty and minor disputes at closing, as customs can vary or be interpreted differently by escrow officers.
R148.title: Ambiguous Allocation of Recording Fees

R149.description: Since Buyer is responsible for all endorsement costs, ensure that the Due Diligence period allows enough time to receive a title commitment and quote for necessary endorsements (e.g., zoning, survey, access) to budget accordingly.
R149.title: Endorsement Cost Verification

R15.description: While 'Leases' includes the agreements, it does not explicitly mention the transfer of the Seller's interest in security deposits, letters of credit, or prepaid rents. While often handled in prorations, explicitly including them in the asset definition ensures they are legally transferred via the Bill of Sale/Assignment of Leases.
R15.title: Omission of Security Deposits

R150.description: The clause excludes deposits 'credited or refunded to tenants as disclosed on the Rent Roll.' If a Seller has applied a security deposit to a tenant's past-due rent prior to closing, the Buyer inherits a lease with no security. The Buyer should require the Seller to replenish any security deposits applied to defaults during the escrow period.
R150.title: Exclusion of Applied Security Deposits

R151.description: While the paragraph allows for post-closing tax adjustments, it does not set a 'cut-off' date. This can lead to indefinite accounting liabilities for the Buyer.
R151.title: Lack of Time Limit on Tax Re-Proration

R152.description: Cross-reference the Rent Roll against actual bank statements for security deposit accounts to ensure all 'non-refundable' or 'credited' deposits are legitimate and documented.
R152.title: Security Deposit Verification

R153.description: Seller reserves the right to collect delinquent rents post-closing. While they cannot evict, they could still sue a tenant. This could damage the Buyer's relationship with a key tenant or trigger a tenant to stop paying current rent to the Buyer in retaliation.
R153.title: Seller's Unrestricted Right to Sue Tenants

R154.description: Review the aged accounts receivable report 5 days before closing to identify which tenants are delinquent and estimate the potential for Seller interference post-closing.
R154.title: Delinquency Audit

R155.description: The Buyer is made responsible for repaying tenants for over-collections made by the Seller. If the credit received at closing is based on an inaccurate estimate, the Buyer may end up out-of-pocket when the final reconciliation occurs.
R155.title: Buyer Liability for Seller's Over-Collections

R156.description: The clause suggests the Buyer must pay the Seller for under-collections only after 'receipt from said tenants.' This is generally safe, but the Buyer should ensure they are not obligated to use 'best efforts' or incur costs to collect the Seller's money.
R156.title: Buyer as Seller's Collection Agent

R157.description: Verify the 'base year' determinations mentioned in the text. If the Seller has incorrectly calculated the base year, the reconciliation will be flawed, potentially leading to tenant disputes.
R157.title: Base Year Verification

R158.description: The Buyer is asked to indemnify the Seller for 'all claims' related to In-Process TI Work. This could include claims arising from the Seller's own negligence, pre-closing contract breaches, or injuries that occurred before the Buyer took title.
R158.title: Overbroad Indemnity for TI Work

R159.description: If the escrowed funds are insufficient to cover the TI work, the Seller is supposed to reimburse the Buyer. However, if the Seller is a Single Purpose Entity (SPE), 'demand' for reimbursement may be worthless after the Seller has distributed the sale proceeds.
R159.title: Unsecured Seller Reimbursement for TI Deficiencies

R16.description: Cross-reference this definition with the actual Rent Roll to ensure all licenses or 'agreements to occupy' (like cell tower leases or kiosk licenses) are captured.
R16.title: Rent Roll Verification

R160.description: During Due Diligence, obtain a certified list of all 'In Process TI Work,' copies of all contracts, and lien waivers for work completed to date.
R160.title: TI Status Audit

R161.description: The paragraph limits the conditions for closing to only the delivery of funds/documents and title readiness. It fails to include the satisfaction of Seller's representations, warranties, and covenants as a prerequisite for the Escrow Holder to close.
R161.title: Incomplete Conditions to Closing

R162.description: The phrase 'All funds and documents' is non-specific. It does not explicitly reference the specific closing deliveries required of the Seller (e.g., FIRPTA affidavit, Bill of Sale, Assignment of Leases).
R162.title: Vague Document Delivery Requirement

R163.description: The phrase 'prepared to deliver' is legally ambiguous. The standard for closing is that the Title Company must be 'irrevocably committed' to issue the policy in the specific form (including endorsements) agreed upon during due diligence.
R163.title: Weak Title Policy Condition

R164.description: The provision grants interest to the Seller for sums due 'after the Closing.' If the closing is delayed due to the Seller's default or failure to perform, the Seller should not benefit from interest accruing on the purchase price during that delay.
R164.title: Ambiguity Regarding Interest on Delayed Closing

R165.description: Verify if the Buyer has specific preferences for the type of 'interest bearing accounts' (e.g., government-backed, money market) to ensure principal protection.
R165.title: Investment Instructions

R166.description: Allowing the Escrow Holder to disburse funds 'as Seller may otherwise direct' creates risks regarding FIRPTA withholding compliance and potential fraudulent transfers. Buyer needs to ensure funds go to the titled owner or a legally authorized agent to avoid tax liability or title challenges.
R166.title: Unrestricted Third-Party Disbursement

R167.description: Confirm with the Escrow Holder that the Deed will be recorded immediately upon Closing and that the 'delivery' to Buyer includes a copy of the recorded instrument with the recorder's stamp.
R167.title: Verification of Recording Sequence

R168.description: The phrase 'party entitled thereto or benefited thereby' is subjective and lacks a specific mechanism for determination. This could lead to disputes at closing regarding the distribution of original documents, keys, or prorated funds if the closing statement is not perfectly aligned with this clause.
R168.title: Ambiguity in Escrow Item Distribution

R169.description: The provision instructs the Escrow Holder to deliver the Deposit to the Seller upon a default without requiring mutual consent or a judicial determination. This allows a Seller to unilaterally declare a default and demand the funds, potentially forcing the Buyer to sue to recover a Deposit that was wrongfully taken.
R169.title: Unilateral Instruction for Deposit Release

R17.description: The Seller is reserving the right to pursue claims against contractors, designers, and warrantors even after the sale. This could create a conflict where both Buyer and Seller are pursuing the same third party, or where the Seller settles a claim that affects the Buyer's ability to recover for defects discovered post-closing.
R17.title: Seller Retention of Third-Party Claims

R170.description: The liquidated damages are intended to be the 'sole and exclusive remedy.' However, the carve-out for 'indemnification' is dangerously broad. If the general indemnity clause in the agreement (often found in p_15 or similar) includes 'breach of contract,' the Seller could bypass the liquidated damages cap by suing under an indemnity theory.
R170.title: Broad Indemnity Carve-out to Liquidated Damages

R171.description: Verify local state law requirements for liquidated damages formatting.
R171.title: Statutory Compliance for Liquidated Damages

R172.description: Ensure both parties actually initial the spaces in p_118. In many jurisdictions, failure to initial the liquidated damages clause specifically renders it void, potentially exposing the Buyer to unlimited damages or specific performance.
R172.title: Execution Requirement

R173.description: The clause explicitly waives the Buyer's right to seek specific performance. In real estate, where properties are unique, the ability to force the Seller to convey the property is the Buyer's most powerful leverage. Without it, a Seller can 'walk' from the deal if they get a better offer, simply by paying a capped amount of costs.
R173.title: Waiver of Specific Performance

R174.description: There is a significant clerical error ('Fifty Hundred Thousand' vs '$50,000'). Furthermore, capping the Buyer's recovery of out-of-pocket costs to $50,000 may be insufficient to cover due diligence, legal fees, and financing costs for a commercial transaction.
R174.title: Ambiguous and Capped Cost Reimbursement

R175.description: The Buyer's right to a remedy is conditioned on 'all other conditions to Seller's obligations... have been satisfied.' This could allow a Seller to intentionally block a condition from being satisfied to avoid being in 'default' and thus avoid paying the Buyer's costs.
R175.title: Conditional Default Remedy

R176.description: If the Buyer elects to proceed after a casualty, they receive an assignment of insurance proceeds. However, the Seller is not required to credit the Buyer for the amount of the deductible. This effectively increases the Purchase Price for the Buyer by the amount of the deductible.
R176.title: Missing Insurance Deductible Credit

R177.description: The threshold for what constitutes 'material' damage is left blank. This creates uncertainty regarding when the Buyer has the right to terminate the agreement.
R177.title: Undefined Materiality Threshold

R178.description: Verify Seller's current insurance coverage limits and deductibles to ensure the 'assignment of proceeds' is actually valuable.
R178.title: Insurance Policy Review

R179.description: While the clause is generally fair, it does not explicitly state that fees incurred in appeals or bankruptcy proceedings are covered, which can be a significant expense.
R179.title: Narrow Prevailing Party Definition

R18.description: Verify that the numerical and written dollar amounts match the agreed-upon Letter of Intent (LOI).
R18.title: Purchase Price Verification

R180.description: The clause allows for email notice but relies on 'electronic confirmation of such delivery.' This can be ambiguous (e.g., does an automated 'delivered' receipt count if the recipient didn't see it?).
R180.title: Electronic Notice Verification

R181.description: Ensure all addresses, email addresses, and fax numbers for Buyer, Seller, and Sample Law Firm LLP are fully populated in the final execution version.
R181.title: Missing Contact Information

R182.description: Verify that Section 16 (referenced in p_150) contains specific protocols for email delivery, such as a requirement for a read receipt or a 'deemed received' timeframe, to avoid disputes over whether a notice was actually delivered.
R182.title: Email Notice Protocol

R183.description: This 'Entire Agreement' or merger clause prevents the buyer from relying on any verbal promises, marketing materials, or emails exchanged during negotiations. If the seller made specific claims about the property's condition, income, or zoning that are not explicitly written in this document, the buyer cannot sue for breach based on those claims.
R183.title: Exclusion of Extrinsic Representations

R184.description: The phrase 'where permitted by this Agreement' indicates that the buyer's ability to transfer the contract to a successor or affiliate is restricted elsewhere in the document. For a buyer, the ability to assign the contract to a single-purpose entity (SPE) or an affiliate for financing and liability purposes is critical.
R184.title: Conditional Binding Effect on Assigns

R185.description: The current language requires Seller's consent for assignment but does not require that consent to be reasonably withheld. This allows the Seller to arbitrarily block a legitimate transfer or demand a 'consent fee' to approve a transfer to a third party.
R185.title: Unfettered Seller Discretion on Assignment

R186.description: The definition of 'control' requires both majority ownership AND managerial control. This may be too restrictive for institutional buyers, private equity funds, or joint ventures where the Buyer entity might be managed by an affiliate that holds a minority stake or where the ownership is split 50/50.
R186.title: Restrictive Definition of Control

R187.description: Verify if the Buyer intends to remain liable after assignment. The clause is silent on whether the assignor is released. Usually, Sellers insist on the original Buyer remaining liable; if the Buyer wants a 'clean break' upon assignment to a well-capitalized affiliate, language must be added to release the original Buyer.
R187.title: Original Buyer Liability

R188.description: To effect a 1031 exchange, the Buyer must typically assign its rights to a Qualified Intermediary (QI). While the clause mentions cooperation, it should explicitly state that assignment to a QI is permitted without Seller's consent to avoid conflict with the restrictive assignment language in p_154.
R188.title: Lack of Qualified Intermediary Assignment Language

R189.description: Cooperating in another party's 1031 exchange can expose the cooperating party to potential tax liabilities or legal costs if the exchange is challenged. The Buyer should be indemnified if the Seller's exchange causes issues.
R189.title: Missing 1031 Indemnity

R19.description: The bracketed language directs the Escrow Holder to pay the Initial Deposit directly to the Seller upon receipt. This is 'hard money' from day one. If the Seller goes bankrupt or refuses to return the money after a valid termination, the Buyer has no security and must sue the Seller to recover funds.
R19.title: Immediate Release of Deposit to Seller

R190.description: The county for venue is left blank. This creates ambiguity and potential for jurisdictional disputes if a lawsuit is filed.
R190.title: Missing Venue Designation

R191.description: Consider adding the word 'exclusive' before 'venue' to prevent the parties from attempting to move the case to federal court or another jurisdiction if they have diversity of citizenship.
R191.title: Exclusive Venue

R192.description: Ensure all referenced exhibits (e.g., Legal Description, Bill of Sale form, Assignment of Leases form) are actually attached to the final execution version and have been reviewed for consistency with the main body of the PSA.
R192.title: Exhibit Completeness

R193.description: Verify that all critical dates in the agreement (Closing, Due Diligence expiration, etc.) are realistic and provide sufficient buffer, as 'Time is of the Essence' allows the Seller to terminate for even minor delays.
R193.title: Strict Deadline Enforcement

R194.description: This clause allows the Seller to continue marketing the property and negotiating with other buyers even after the contract is signed, up until the end of the Due Diligence Period. This effectively turns the PSA into an 'option' for the Seller and puts the Buyer at risk of being 'gazumped' after spending significant money on inspections and legal fees.
R194.title: Lack of Exclusivity / Seller's Right to Market

R195.description: The confidentiality clause does not include an exception for disclosures required by law, subpoena, or government regulation. This could put the Buyer in breach if they are legally compelled to disclose the contract terms (e.g., for tax filings, SEC requirements, or litigation).
R195.title: Narrow Confidentiality Exceptions

R196.description: Verify that any 'further instruments' requested do not expand the Buyer's financial obligations or liabilities beyond those expressly stated in the Agreement.
R196.title: Scope of Further Assurances

R197.description: While mutual, the indemnity requires the Buyer to pay for legal defense and costs if any person claims a commission 'by, through or under' the Buyer. If the Buyer had casual conversations with multiple brokers, this could trigger a duty to defend the Seller.
R197.title: Broad Mutual Brokerage Indemnity

R198.description: Ensure the blank spaces for the Broker's name and the 'separate agreement' details are filled and reviewed before execution to ensure the Buyer is not inadvertently responsible for the Broker's Fee.
R198.title: Incomplete Broker Information

R199.description: The Buyer is waiving the right to receive the Washington State Seller Disclosure Statement (Form 17). This statement covers critical items like title, water, sewer, structural, systems, and HOA issues. Waiving this shifts the entire burden of discovery to the Buyer's inspection, with no baseline representation from the Seller.
R199.title: Waiver of Statutory Disclosure Statement

R2.description: The preamble identifies a specific 'Buyer' without mentioning 'and/or assigns.' While assignment is often covered in a later boilerplate section, failing to establish the right to assign to a related entity (e.g., an LLC formed for the purchase) at the outset can create friction if the Seller later claims the specific identity of the Buyer was a material term of the contract.
R2.title: Lack of Assignment Flexibility in Preamble

R20.description: The clause states the deposit is non-refundable upon receipt. This contradicts the purpose of a Due Diligence Period. The Buyer should be able to get the deposit back if they terminate during the inspection period.
R20.title: Premature Non-Refundability

R200.description: The clause appears to force the Buyer to waive the statutory right to rescind the agreement upon receipt of the Environmental disclosure. Under RCW 64.06, a buyer usually has 3 days to rescind after receiving the disclosure. By waiving this 'by executing this Agreement,' the Buyer loses the ability to walk away if the Environmental section reveals contamination or underground tanks.
R200.title: Waiver of Right to Rescind (Incomplete Clause)

R201.description: The text of p_168 is cut off. Obtain the full text to ensure no additional waivers of liability or rights are hidden in the missing portion.
R201.title: Incomplete Sentence/Paragraph

R202.description: The fragment suggests the Buyer is waiving the right to receive the 'balance' of a completed disclosure. This prevents the Buyer from having a full understanding of known property defects or history before proceeding.
R202.title: Waiver of Right to Complete Disclosure

R203.description: The clause exempts the Seller from updating the Disclosure Statement even if new material defects are discovered. This allows the Seller to remain silent about newly discovered issues (e.g., environmental leaks, structural failures) that occur between the initial disclosure and closing.
R203.title: Waiver of Updated Disclosures

R204.description: The Buyer is forced to warrant they are not relying on the Seller's Disclosure Statement. This 'non-reliance' clause is designed to defeat future claims of fraud or negligent misrepresentation, as the Buyer is contractually agreeing that the Seller's statements did not influence their decision to buy.
R204.title: Disclaimer of Reliance on Disclosures

R205.description: Verify if the Buyer meets the legal definition of a 'sophisticated buyer' in the relevant jurisdiction, as this status is used here to justify the waiver of standard consumer/buyer protections.
R205.title: Sophisticated Buyer Status

R206.description: In Washington State, RCW 64.06 provides buyers with a statutory right to rescind the agreement if the Seller Disclosure Statement is not provided or contains material errors. This clause waives that protection entirely, even for future updates.
R206.title: Waiver of Statutory Rescission Rights (RCW 64.06)

R207.description: Confirm if the property type (e.g., commercial vs. residential) triggers RCW 64.06. If the property is strictly commercial, the statute may not apply by default, but the inclusion of this waiver suggests the Seller is attempting to preempt any argument that it does.
R207.title: Applicability of RCW 64.06

R208.description: Ensure the execution date is filled in accurately at the time of signing to establish the 'Effective Date' if the agreement relies on this for timeline calculations.
R208.title: Execution Date

R209.description: Verify that the individual signing has the legal authority to bind the Buyer entity.
R209.title: Authorized Signatory

R21.description: Confirm the Title Insurance Company is a reputable national provider and that the 'business days' for delivery align with the Buyer's banking capabilities.
R21.title: Escrow Holder Identity

R210.description: If the individual signing on behalf of the Seller does not have the legal authority to bind the entity, the contract may be voidable. For a Buyer, this creates significant risk if the Seller attempts to back out of the deal by claiming the signatory lacked corporate authority.
R210.title: Unverified Signatory Authority

R211.description: Verify that the name entered here matches exactly with the 'Seller' defined in the preamble and the name registered with the Secretary of State.
R211.title: Entity Name Consistency

R212.description: Purchase agreements often calculate critical deadlines (Due Diligence Period, Earnest Money Deposit) from the 'Effective Date.' If the execution date is left blank or if there is a gap between the Seller's execution and the Buyer's execution, the timeline for performance becomes ambiguous.
R212.title: Ambiguous Effective Date Trigger

R213.description: Confirm whether the Seller or Buyer is expected to sign last, as the final signature date usually dictates the start of the contingency periods.
R213.title: Execution Sequence

R214.description: Similar to the Seller's block, if the Buyer is an entity (LLC/Corp), the signature must reflect that the individual is signing on behalf of the entity to avoid personal liability for the individual and to ensure the entity is properly bound.
R214.title: Signatory Capacity for Buyer

R215.description: If the Buyer is using a Special Purpose Entity (SPE) for the acquisition, ensure the signatory has been granted authority via a corporate resolution.
R215.title: Authorized Signatory Verification

R216.description: Verify that the legal description inserted here matches the 'Exhibit A' attached to the PSA and, more importantly, matches the legal description provided in the Title Commitment/Preliminary Report.
R216.title: Legal Description Verification

R217.description: The phrase 'all of its right, title and interest in' is characteristic of a quitclaim deed rather than a warranty deed. A warranty deed should convey the real property itself, not merely whatever interest the Grantor might happen to have. Using 'right, title and interest' can weaken the buyer's ability to claim a breach of the covenant of seisin if the seller actually owns less than a fee simple interest.
R217.title: Quitclaim-Style Granting Language

R218.description: While not strictly prohibited, including the assignment of leases within the recorded Special Warranty Deed is unconventional. Leases are typically assigned via a separate 'Assignment and Assumption of Leases.' Including them in the deed makes the leasehold transfer a matter of public record and may complicate the chain of title or lead to requests for lease disclosures from the county assessor.
R218.title: Inclusion of Leases in Recorded Deed

R219.description: Ensure the Grantor name matches the 'Seller' name in the PSA and the 'Vested Owner' in the Title Report. Ensure the Grantee name matches the 'Buyer' (or its designated assignee).
R219.title: Entity Accuracy

R22.description: Similar to the Initial Deposit, the bracketed language allows the Seller to take possession of the Additional Deposit immediately. This removes the protection of an independent escrow holder.
R22.title: Immediate Release of Additional Deposit

R220.description: The deed is made subject to 'matters set forth in Exhibit B.' If Exhibit B is not strictly limited to the 'Permitted Exceptions' agreed upon during the title review period, the Seller could unilaterally include title defects or encumbrances that the Buyer did not approve, effectively exempting those items from the special warranty of title.
R220.title: Undefined Scope of Exceptions

R221.description: The clause expressly excludes all covenants arising by 'statutory or other implication.' In many jurisdictions, statutes provide implied covenants (such as the covenant against encumbrances) that protect the buyer. While this is a Special Warranty Deed, a blanket exclusion of all statutory protections can leave the buyer with less protection than is standard for a special warranty, particularly regarding the grantor's own acts.
R221.title: Broad Exclusion of Statutory Warranties

R222.description: Verify that the signature block for the Deed includes the correct notary acknowledgment form required by the state where the Real Property is located to ensure the deed is recordable.
R222.title: Notary/Acknowledgment Requirement

R223.description: Confirm that the 'Attach Legal Description' placeholder is filled with the exact legal description from the Title Commitment and that it matches the Survey.
R223.title: Legal Description Accuracy

R224.description: Ensure the list of Permitted Exceptions attached here matches the final list approved by Buyer during the Title/Survey review period.
R224.title: Permitted Exceptions Consistency

R225.description: The Bill of Sale 'sells, transfers and conveys' the property but does not explicitly state that the Seller owns the property free and clear of liens or that the Seller warrants title to the personal property. Without this, the Buyer may inadvertently take personal property subject to undisclosed security interests or third-party claims.
R225.title: Lack of Title Warranty for Personal Property

R226.description: The Bill of Sale refers to 'all personal property owned by Seller and located on or in or used in connection with the Property.' If there are specific high-value items (e.g., specialized equipment, vehicles, or proprietary software systems), relying on a general description without a detailed Schedule I can lead to disputes over what was 'used in connection with' the property.
R226.title: Ambiguity in Personal Property Scope

R227.description: While the seller warrants ownership, the provision lacks an explicit survival period and an indemnity clause. If a third-party lienholder (e.g., an equipment lessor or secured creditor) emerges after closing, the buyer may have limited recourse without a survival clause that extends beyond the deed recording.
R227.title: Lack of Survival and Indemnity for Personal Property Title

R228.description: Verify that a comprehensive, itemized list of all critical equipment, furniture, and fixtures is attached to this exhibit. Ensure serial numbers are included for high-value items to prevent 'swapping' prior to closing.
R228.title: Inventory Verification

R229.description: The title 'Assignment and Assumption' combined with a general preamble often leads to the Buyer (Assignee) inadvertently assuming all liabilities under the leases, including those that accrued prior to the closing date (e.g., unpaid tenant improvements, security deposit disputes, or landlord defaults).
R229.title: Unrestricted Assumption of Lease Liabilities

R23.description: The text limits refundability only to 'Seller's default.' It should also be refundable if conditions precedent (like title clearance, casualty, or condemnation) are not met, even if those don't technically constitute a 'default' by Seller.
R23.title: Narrow Refundability Scope

R230.description: Confirm that the 'Assignor' entity is exactly the same legal entity as the 'Seller' in the main PSA, and that the 'Assignee' is the intended taking entity (or its permitted assignee).
R230.title: Entity Consistency Check

R231.description: The definition of 'Leases' is limited to those specifically described in Schedule I. If a lease, amendment, or letter of intent is inadvertently omitted from the schedule, the Buyer may lack the formal assignment of rights needed to enforce that lease or collect rent, despite owning the underlying property.
R231.title: Restrictive Definition of Leases

R232.description: Cross-reference Schedule I of this Assignment against the certified Rent Roll and the Diligence Materials to ensure every active tenant and license agreement is listed.
R232.title: Schedule I Reconciliation

R233.description: Ensure the 'dated effective as of' date matches the final execution date of the Purchase and Sale Agreement to avoid incorporation by reference errors.
R233.title: Consistency of Effective Date

R234.description: The assignment transfers 'right, title and interest' in the Leases but does not explicitly mention the transfer of physical security deposits, letters of credit, or prepaid rents. Without explicit language, the Buyer may face claims from tenants for the return of deposits that the Seller failed to actually credit or transfer at closing.
R234.title: Omission of Security Deposits and Prepaid Rents

R235.description: The paragraph assigns the leases but fails to allocate liability for breaches occurring before the Conveyance Date. The Buyer could be held liable by tenants for the Seller's prior defaults (e.g., failure to maintain the premises or overcharging CAM) without a clear indemnity from the Seller.
R235.title: Lack of Liability Allocation (Pre-Closing vs. Post-Closing)

R236.description: Verify if any tenant security deposits are held as Letters of Credit. If so, ensure the assignment includes language requiring the Seller to cooperate in the formal transfer of the LC beneficiary rights with the issuing bank.
R236.title: Letter of Credit Transfer Requirements

R237.description: The indemnity is limited to 'obligations under the Leases.' This may not cover liabilities arising from the Seller's tortious acts, omissions, or negligence that occurred on the property prior to closing but are not strictly 'obligations' defined within the lease document itself.
R237.title: Narrow Scope of Seller Indemnity

R238.description: Verify that the survival period for this indemnity matches the general survival period for representations and warranties in the main Purchase and Sale Agreement (PSA).
R238.title: Survival Period Alignment

R239.description: The current language has the Buyer assuming 'all' obligations. Without qualifying that these are obligations 'to be performed after' the closing, the Buyer could inadvertently assume liability for the Seller's past breaches or unperformed maintenance that should have been completed prior to the Conveyance Date.
R239.title: Broad Assumption of Past Obligations

R24.description: The term 'paid in cash' is archaic and technically implies physical currency. In commercial transactions, this should be clarified to ensure wire transfers of immediately available funds are required and accepted.
R24.title: Ambiguous Payment Method

R240.description: Ensure this 'prevailing party' clause does not conflict with the dispute resolution or arbitration sections in the main PSA (e.g., if the PSA requires mediation before fee-shifting applies).
R240.title: Consistency with PSA Dispute Resolution

R241.description: The paragraph uses 'Assignor' and 'Assignee', whereas the defined terms for the 'Agreement' typically refer to 'Seller' and 'Buyer'. If this paragraph is intended to be the signature block for the main Purchase and Sale Agreement, the terminology is inconsistent. If it is part of an Exhibit (Assignment form), it should clearly distinguish itself from the 'Agreement' defined in the preamble.
R241.title: Inconsistent Party Naming

R242.description: Linking the execution to the 'day and year first written above' can be problematic for assignment documents. Assignments should generally be effective as of the 'Closing Date' to ensure a clean break in liability and right to income. If the date 'first written above' is the date of the PSA (the reference date), the assignment might technically pre-date the actual transfer of title.
R242.title: Effective Date Ambiguity

R243.description: The defined term 'Rent Roll' refers to the version identified in the 'Due Diligence Documents'. For the purpose of the Assignment and Assumption of Leases, the Buyer needs the most current version. Relying on an old Rent Roll from the DD period may exclude new leases or amendments executed during the escrow period.
R243.title: Static Rent Roll Reference

R244.description: Ensure that the final version of this schedule includes not just the Rent Roll, but all active lease amendments, letter agreements, and guarantees to ensure all 'Leases' (as defined) are legally transferred.
R244.title: Verify Lease Schedule Completeness

R245.description: The paragraph is a header for the 'Assignment and Assumption of Contracts and Intangibles'. As a Buyer, it is critical that the actual form of this assignment (usually an Exhibit) contains a 'further assurances' clause and a clear indemnity where the Seller remains liable for all obligations arising prior to the Closing Date.
R245.title: Missing Form of Assignment Protections

R246.description: Verify if any of the 'Contracts' being assigned require third-party consent. The Assignment form should include a representation that all necessary consents have been obtained.
R246.title: Contract Consent Review

R247.description: Ensure the date of this Assignment is the actual Closing Date of the transaction to avoid gaps in liability or operational authority.
R247.title: Effective Date Alignment

R248.description: The definition of 'Contracts' is limited strictly to those listed on Schedule I. If a critical service contract is inadvertently omitted from the schedule, the Buyer may lack the legal standing to enforce it or benefit from its terms post-closing.
R248.title: Restrictive Definition of Contracts

R249.description: Cross-reference Schedule I against the list of Service Contracts approved during the Due Diligence period to ensure no critical utilities or maintenance agreements are missing.
R249.title: Schedule I Reconciliation

R25.description: The bracketed language '[plus accrued interest thereon]' suggests that whether the Buyer receives credit for interest earned on the Deposit is still a point of negotiation. As the Buyer, you want to ensure all interest earned on your capital is applied toward the Purchase Price.
R25.title: Uncertainty Regarding Interest Credit

R250.description: Verify that the date and parties of the Purchase and Sale Agreement (PSA) are correctly inserted to ensure the incorporation by reference is legally valid.
R250.title: PSA Reference Accuracy

R251.description: The phrase 'certain intangible personal property' is dangerously vague. It implies a limitation that could exclude critical assets like building warranties, permits, licenses, trade names, or architectural plans. As the Buyer, you want an assignment of *all* intangibles.
R251.title: Vague Definition of Intangibles

R252.description: The provision excludes all claims by the Assignor arising from matters before the Conveyance Date. This is problematic if there are outstanding warranty claims, insurance claims for property damage, or causes of action against contractors for defective work performed prior to closing. The Buyer needs these claims to offset the cost of repairs or to enforce warranties.
R252.title: Broad Exclusion of Pre-Closing Claims

R253.description: Verify if any of the 'Contracts' or 'Intangible Property' require third-party consents for assignment. If so, ensure the main PSA requires Seller to obtain these consents as a condition to closing.
R253.title: Contract Assignability

R254.description: The Seller's indemnity is limited strictly to 'obligations under the Contracts.' It does not cover liabilities arising from the 'Intangible Property' (such as IP infringement or permit violations) or general liabilities related to the ownership/operation of the property prior to the Conveyance Date.
R254.title: Narrow Indemnity Scope

R255.description: The term 'originating' is ambiguous. It is unclear if it refers to when the underlying act occurred, when the obligation accrued, or when a third party filed a claim. Using 'accruing' or 'occurring' is standard for clarity.
R255.title: Ambiguous Trigger for Indemnity

R256.description: The Buyer is assuming 'all' obligations under the Contracts. Without a temporal qualifier, the Buyer could be held liable for the Seller's pre-closing breaches or unpaid balances that existed prior to the Conveyance Date. The assumption should be limited to obligations first arising after the transfer.
R256.title: Unrestricted Assumption of Obligations

R257.description: Ensure the 'Conveyance Date' in this assignment matches the 'Closing Date' or 'Proration Date' in the main PSA to prevent gaps in liability coverage.
R257.title: Proration Alignment

R258.description: While the clause allows for counterparts, it does not explicitly authorize the delivery of signature pages via electronic means (PDF/DocuSign). In modern transactions, relying solely on 'originals' can cause delays or disputes regarding the validity of the execution if wet-ink originals are not immediately exchanged.
R258.title: Ambiguity Regarding Electronic Signatures

R259.description: The title 'Assignment and Assumption' suggests the Buyer will take on all obligations under the Service Contracts. Without specific 'cut-off' language in the actual form of this schedule, the Buyer risks assuming liabilities for Seller's pre-closing defaults or unpaid invoices.
R259.title: Risk of Unfiltered Assumption of Liabilities

R26.description: The allocation of the Purchase Price between personal and real property has significant depreciation and transfer tax implications. If the dollar amount is left blank or filled in without professional tax advice, the Buyer may lose significant tax benefits or face challenges from the IRS/Department of Revenue.
R26.title: Arbitrary Tax Allocation

R260.description: Verify that the Buyer has the right to designate which Service Contracts are being assumed and which must be terminated by the Seller prior to closing, rather than a blanket assumption of all 'Intangible Property' as defined.
R260.title: Verify Contract Termination Rights

R261.description: A 'Certificate of Rent Roll' is only as valuable as the standard of accuracy it guarantees. If the certificate is qualified by 'to the best of Seller's knowledge' or lacks a survival period, the Buyer has limited recourse if the rent, security deposits, or lease terms are discovered to be inaccurate post-closing.
R261.title: Inadequate Rent Roll Certification

R262.description: Compare the data in the Rent Roll Certificate against Tenant Estoppel Certificates to identify discrepancies in security deposits or lease expiration dates.
R262.title: Cross-Reference Rent Roll with Estoppels

R263.description: The Seller is qualifying the accuracy of the Rent Roll to 'actual knowledge, without investigating.' This 'head-in-the-sand' standard allows the Seller to avoid liability for inaccuracies that could have been discovered through a simple review of their own records. For a Buyer, the Rent Roll is a fundamental valuation document; its accuracy should be absolute or at least based on a diligent review of the leases.
R263.title: Weak Knowledge Qualifier in Rent Roll Certification

R264.description: The use of 'in all material respects' regarding a Rent Roll is problematic. Specific financial figures such as security deposit amounts, monthly rent, and arrearages should be precise. A 'materiality' threshold allows for small discrepancies across many units that can aggregate into a significant financial shortfall for the Buyer post-closing.
R264.title: Materiality Qualifier on Financial Data

R265.description: Ensure that the 'attached Rent Roll' referenced in this certificate is the final, updated version provided at the end of the due diligence period, and not an outdated version from the initial offering.
R265.title: Verification of Rent Roll Attachment

R266.description: Verify that the blank date for the certification is required to be as of the Closing Date or no more than 3-5 days prior to Closing to ensure the data is current.
R266.title: Certification Date

R267.description: If the PSA mandates a specific 'Form of Estoppel Certificate' without allowing for lender-requested modifications, the Buyer may find the delivered estoppels insufficient to satisfy financing requirements. Lenders often require specific language regarding offsets, defaults, and subordination that may not be in a generic exhibit form.
R267.title: Inflexible Estoppel Form

R268.description: Verify with the Buyer's lender whether the form attached as [p_405] contains the necessary certifications regarding 'no defaults,' 'no prepaid rent,' and 'no landlord obligations for TIs/commissions.'
R268.title: Lender Requirements

R269.description: A static checklist often omits critical items such as environmental 'Phase I' reports, structural/mechanical surveys, historical utility bills, or unrecorded licenses/permits. If the Seller is only obligated to provide items on this specific list, the Buyer may be deprived of material information during the contingency period.
R269.title: Incomplete Due Diligence Checklist

R27.description: Consult with a tax advisor to determine the optimal allocation for depreciation purposes before finalizing this amount.
R27.title: Verify Personal Property Value

R270.description: Confirm that the 'Due Diligence Period' or 'Inspection Period' does not commence until the Seller has delivered all items listed in [p_411] to the Buyer's data room.
R270.title: Due Diligence Clock

R28.description: The paragraph mentions 'following items' but the subsequent paragraph [p_24] only explicitly lists the Survey. It does not explicitly list the Title Commitment or underlying exception documents in the delivery obligation, which could delay the due diligence clock.
R28.title: Limited Scope of Deliverables

R29.description: Verify that 7 days is sufficient for the Buyer's title officer to receive and review these documents, or ensure the 'Feasibility Period' does not start until these are received.
R29.title: Confirm Delivery Timeline

R3.description: Verify that the legal name of the Seller matches the name on the current vesting deed/title report to ensure the party has the legal authority to sell.
R3.title: Entity Verification

R30.description: The phrase 'in the possession of Seller' is too narrow. The Seller may have surveys held by their attorneys, engineers, or lenders that are not physically in their 'possession' but are under their 'control.'
R30.title: Limited Search Obligation for Survey

R31.description: The Seller is providing the 'Existing Survey' without any obligation to disclose if they know it is inaccurate (e.g., if new improvements were made after the survey date).
R31.title: Lack of Seller Representation on Survey Accuracy

R32.description: The definition of Title Documents is tied to the 'Commitment' and 'Exceptions,' but the review period in [p_26] starts from the 'Effective Date' rather than the date Buyer actually receives these documents. If the Title Company or Seller is slow to deliver the documents, the Buyer's 10-day review window is effectively shortened.
R32.title: Title Review Clock Starts Prematurely

R33.description: The clause specifies that failure to notify Seller of objections within 10 days constitutes 'approval of all exceptions.' This is a 'silent waiver' that can result in the Buyer being forced to take title subject to severe encumbrances (e.g., easements that prevent development) if a deadline is missed by even one day.
R33.title: Deemed Approval of Title Exceptions

R34.description: The current language makes all title cures optional for the Seller ('Seller elects not to remove'). Standard commercial practice requires the Seller to remove 'Mandatory Cure Items' (e.g., mortgages, deeds of trust, mechanic's liens, and delinquent taxes) regardless of whether the Buyer objects.
R34.title: Lack of Mandatory Cure Items

R35.description: Verify that the 'Due Diligence Period' mentioned here (which allows termination) extends beyond the Seller's 10-day response period. If the DD period ends before the Seller responds, the Buyer loses their termination right.
R35.title: Due Diligence Period Alignment

R36.description: The clause prevents the extension of the Closing Date for title review. If a supplemental report reveals a major defect (e.g., a new lien or lis pendens) shortly before closing, the Buyer may be forced to choose between terminating the deal or closing on a defective title without sufficient time for the cure process.
R36.title: Prohibition on Closing Extensions for Title Issues

R37.description: The Seller is conveying title via a 'special warranty deed.' While common in commercial transactions, this only warrants against defects created during the Seller's ownership. A 'general warranty deed' would provide broader protection for the Buyer against all prior defects.
R37.title: Special Warranty Deed Limitation

R38.description: Review Exhibit B (the Deed form) to ensure it matches the 'special warranty' description and does not contain additional 'as-is' disclaimers that undermine the warranty.
R38.title: Exhibit B Review

R39.description: The paragraph limits requested endorsements to those 'agreed to by Title Company during the Due Diligence Period.' This prevents the Buyer from requesting necessary endorsements for new issues discovered via supplemental reports after the DD period has expired.
R39.title: Endorsement Request Limitation

R4.description: The clause states the Seller will 'sell and convey' but does not specify the quality of the deed. In Washington, a Buyer should specifically require a 'Statutory Warranty Deed' to ensure the Seller warrants against all defects in title. Without this specification, the Seller might attempt to provide a Bargain and Sale Deed or a Quitclaim Deed, which offer significantly less protection.
R4.title: Failure to Specify Deed Type

R40.description: The paragraph mentions 'payment of its normal premium' but does not specify which party pays for the 'extended coverage' vs. 'standard coverage' or the endorsements. In many jurisdictions, the Seller pays for standard and the Buyer pays the 'extended' uplift.
R40.title: Ambiguity in Title Policy Costs

R41.description: The Due Diligence Period is tied to a specific calendar date rather than a duration following the delivery of Due Diligence Documents. If the Seller delays delivery of the documents (allowed up to 3 business days or potentially longer if they breach), the Buyer's actual time to review those documents is reduced.
R41.title: Fixed Due Diligence Expiration Date

R42.description: Review 'Schedule 1' immediately to ensure it includes all critical items: environmental reports, rent rolls, service contracts, utility bills, and historical maintenance records.
R42.title: Verify Schedule 1 Completeness

R43.description: The Seller is disclaiming all responsibility for the accuracy or completeness of the documents provided. If the Seller provides an outdated or incorrect environmental report or rent roll, the Buyer may have no recourse for relying on that information unless it is specifically covered in Section 7.
R43.title: Disclaimer of Document Accuracy

R44.description: Verify that Section 7 contains robust representations regarding the financial and physical status of the property to offset this disclaimer.
R44.title: Cross-Reference Section 7

R45.description: Limiting inspections to 'nonintrusive' prevents the Buyer from conducting Phase II environmental testing (e.g., soil borings) or invasive structural/roofing tests if the initial 'nonintrusive' inspection reveals a potential issue.
R45.title: Restriction to Nonintrusive Inspections

R46.description: The right of entry is restricted to the 'Due Diligence Period.' The Buyer may need access after this period for insurance appraisals, contractor estimates for planned improvements, or a final walk-through prior to Closing.
R46.title: Access Limited to Due Diligence Period

R47.description: Fill the blank for advance notice. Recommend 24 or 48 hours to ensure the Buyer can move quickly during a short DD period.
R47.title: Define Notice Period

R48.description: The term 'reasonable advance notice' is subjective and could lead to disputes if the Seller believes notice was insufficient, potentially delaying inspections.
R48.title: Vague Notice Requirement

R49.description: Verify if there are any existing 'agreements' (e.g., complex tenant leases or property management contracts) that impose specific restrictions on entry that the Buyer must follow.
R49.title: Compliance with 'Agreements'

R5.description: The definition is limited to the land described in Exhibit A. It fails to explicitly include appurtenances, easements, water rights, and mineral rights that may be associated with the land. A Buyer should ensure the definition is broad enough to capture all rights 'running with the land.'
R5.title: Narrow Definition of Real Property

R50.description: Requiring the Buyer to restore the property to its 'prior condition' is an impossibly high standard for invasive testing (like soil borings or Phase II ESAs). It should be 'substantially the same' condition.
R50.title: Strict Restoration Obligation

R51.description: Confirm that the carve-out for 'non-negligent aggravation' is acceptable to Buyer's insurance carrier, as this is a favorable but specific protection for the Buyer.
R51.title: Indemnity Carve-out Strength

R52.description: Allowing insurance to be 'reasonably satisfactory to Seller' gives the Seller a potential 'back-door' way to delay inspections by rejecting the Buyer's insurance certificates.
R52.title: Subjective Insurance Approval

R53.description: The indemnity survives termination indefinitely. This creates a long-tail liability for the Buyer.
R53.title: Indefinite Survival of Indemnity

R54.description: If the Buyer fails to send a notice by the deadline (due to administrative error or oversight), they are 'deemed' to have approved the property, making the deposit non-refundable. This is a 'hard' contingency.
R54.title: Deemed Approval (Silent Waiver)

R55.description: The requirement to 'diligently and in good faith pursue' due diligence is a subjective standard that a Seller could use to claim a breach of contract if the Buyer decides to terminate for a reason the Seller dislikes.
R55.title: Subjective Performance Standard

R56.description: The Buyer is required to give the Seller all third-party reports (which the Buyer paid for) upon termination. This provides a windfall to the Seller at the Buyer's expense.
R56.title: Uncompensated Delivery of Reports

R57.description: Confirm that 'sole and absolute discretion' is retained in the final version, as this is the most protective language for a Buyer's right to walk away.
R57.title: Sole Discretion Standard
