R58.description: The condition only requires that items be 'delivered.' It does not specify that they must be executed, acknowledged (where necessary), or in a form and substance reasonably satisfactory to the Buyer. This could allow a Seller to technically satisfy the condition by delivering non-conforming or poorly drafted documents.
R58.title: Vague Delivery Standard

R59.description: Verify that Section 11.3 (referenced in p_41) and Section 8.1 (referenced in p_81) are consistent and include all necessary closing documents (Deed, Bill of Sale, Assignment of Leases, FIRPTA, etc.).
R59.title: Cross-Reference Check

R6.description: Confirm that Exhibit A is attached and that the legal description (metes and bounds or lot/block) is identical to the description in the preliminary title report.
R6.title: Exhibit A Verification

R60.description: While the definition of 'Title Policy' includes endorsements, this condition should explicitly state that the commitment includes the specific endorsements requested during the Due Diligence Period. Furthermore, it should specify that the commitment is at standard rates to prevent the Title Company from demanding extraordinary premiums to cover risks that should be Seller's responsibility to clear.
R60.title: Omission of Endorsements and Premium Terms

R61.description: The phrase 'in all material respects' creates a 'double materiality' hurdle if the underlying representations in Section 5.2 already contain materiality qualifiers (e.g., 'Seller has no material knowledge of...'). This makes it significantly harder for a Buyer to claim a condition has failed because they must prove the breach itself was material on top of the existing qualifier.
R61.title: Double Materiality Qualifier

R62.description: The paragraph makes the truth of reps a condition, but it does not explicitly require the Seller to deliver a 'Bring-Down Certificate' at closing. Without a formal certificate, the Buyer may lack a clear document to sue upon if reps are later found to be false as of the Closing Date.
R62.title: Lack of 'Bring-Down' Certificate Requirement

R63.description: The condition only requires that estoppels be 'substantially in the form of Exhibit H.' It does not require that the estoppels be 'clean' (i.e., that they do not disclose tenant defaults, landlord defaults, or claims of offset). A tenant could return an estoppel in the correct form but disclose a massive landlord default, and the Seller would technically satisfy this condition.
R63.title: Lack of 'Clean' Estoppel Requirement

R64.description: The lead-in paragraph [p_40] says conditions must be met 'at or prior to Closing.' If the Seller delivers the Minimum Tenant Estoppels five minutes before Closing, the Buyer has no time to review them or verify the information with tenants. This creates significant operational and financial risk.
R64.title: Timing of Estoppel Delivery

R65.description: The defined term 'Minimum Tenant Estoppels' contains blanks for percentages and square footage. Ensure these are filled with high thresholds (e.g., 75-100% of square footage and all 'Major Tenants').
R65.title: Verify Estoppel Thresholds

R66.description: The phrase 'In addition to all other conditions' creates uncertainty by suggesting there are hidden or unlisted conditions elsewhere in the agreement that could allow the Seller to refuse to close. Conditions precedent should be exhaustive to ensure certainty of closing.
R66.title: Open-Ended Conditions Precedent

R67.description: Requiring representations to be 'complete' is a higher and more subjective standard than 'true and correct.' A representation could be accurate but deemed 'incomplete' by a Seller looking for an excuse to terminate. This creates a 'backdoor' termination right.
R67.title: Overly Broad Standard for Representations

R68.description: The paragraph allows for termination if conditions are not met but fails to specify that the Deposit must be returned to the Buyer if the termination is due to a failure of a condition (rather than a default). Without this, the Seller might attempt to retain the Deposit after terminating.
R68.title: Lack of Deposit Return Clarity

R69.description: The paragraph refers to 'Sections 5.1 through 5.4' and 'Section 5.5'. Based on the provided text, [p_45] appears to be Section 5.5. If the numbering in the final document does not align perfectly, the waiver and termination rights may be legally unenforceable or applied to the wrong sections.
R69.title: Potential Internal Reference Mismatch

R7.description: Verify via title report that all necessary easements for access, utilities, and drainage are indeed appurtenant to the land and not personal to the current owner.
R7.title: Verification of Appurtenant Rights

R70.description: Confirm that the paragraph numbers in the final execution version match the 'Section 5.x' references in [p_49].
R70.title: Verify Section Numbering

R71.description: The clause requires the Buyer to pay half of the escrow cancellation fees regardless of why the agreement is terminated (unless under Section 13). If the Seller defaults or a condition precedent fails through no fault of the Buyer, the Buyer should not be penalized with these costs.
R71.title: Unfair Allocation of Cancellation Fees

R72.description: Verify that Section 13 (referenced in p_50) adequately covers Seller Default and provides for the return of the Deposit to the Buyer.
R72.title: Cross-reference Section 13

R73.description: While the paragraph states the agreement doesn't violate contracts, it does not explicitly state that no third-party or governmental consents are required for the Seller to complete the sale. This could lead to delays or legal challenges if a lender or partner consent is missing.
R73.title: Missing Representation on Consents

R74.description: There is no representation that the Seller is not currently involved in bankruptcy proceedings or is not insolvent. This is a standard protection for Buyers to ensure the transaction isn't voidable as a fraudulent transfer.
R74.title: Lack of Anti-Insolvency Representation

R75.description: The Rent Roll is the primary basis for property valuation. Qualifying this representation with 'Seller's Actual Knowledge'—especially when the defined term 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' explicitly disclaims any duty to investigate—is highly risky for the Buyer. The Seller should be able to warrant the accuracy of their own financial records absolutely.
R75.title: Weak Knowledge Qualifier for Rent Roll

R76.description: The phrase 'in all material respects' is subjective. In a large multi-tenant property, small errors across many leases can aggregate into a significant financial discrepancy that the Seller might argue is not 'material' to the whole deal.
R76.title: Vague Materiality Standard

R77.description: The definition of 'Seller's Actual Knowledge' contains a blank space for a name. Ensure a specific individual (e.g., the Asset Manager or Principal) is named and that they are the person most likely to have knowledge of the property's operations.
R77.title: Identify Knowledge Party

R78.description: The representation regarding governmental violations is qualified by 'Seller's Actual Knowledge,' which, as defined in [p_59], excludes any duty to investigate. This allows the Seller to remain willfully ignorant of violations that would be discovered by a simple review of property records or inquiry with the property manager.
R78.title: Knowledge-Qualified Violation Rep

R79.description: The representation only covers litigation against the 'Seller' entity. It does not explicitly cover litigation against the 'Property' itself (e.g., in rem actions) or litigation against the Seller that specifically relates to the Property.
R79.title: Narrow Scope of Litigation Rep

R8.description: The definition excludes fixtures leased by Seller or owned by tenants without requiring a specific list. This creates a risk that essential operating equipment (e.g., HVAC units, solar panels, or specialized lighting) might be removed or reclaimed by third parties after closing without the Buyer's prior knowledge.
R8.title: Ambiguity in Excluded Fixtures

R80.description: Verify through independent title search and zoning report, as the 'Actual Knowledge' qualifier limits the Seller's liability if they haven't checked recent municipal filings.
R80.title: Condemnation Verification

R81.description: This paragraph uses 'To the best of Seller’s knowledge,' whereas other paragraphs use 'To Seller's Actual Knowledge.' Since 'Actual Knowledge' is specifically defined in [p_59] to limit liability, the use of a different, undefined term here creates ambiguity. Seller may argue it means the same as the restricted definition, while Buyer may argue it implies a duty to investigate.
R81.title: Inconsistent Knowledge Standard

R82.description: The representation that lease copies are 'true, correct and complete' is qualified by 'in all material respects.' This allows the Seller to omit minor amendments or side letters that they unilaterally deem non-material, which could impact Buyer's underwriting.
R82.title: Materiality Qualifier in Lease Accuracy

R83.description: Cross-reference the representations in this paragraph with the Tenant Estoppel Certificates obtained during due diligence to ensure no discrepancies exist regarding concessions or defaults.
R83.title: Tenant Estoppel Comparison

R84.description: The definition of 'Actual Knowledge' explicitly states it is 'without such person undertaking any investigation.' This is highly problematic for a Buyer as it protects a Seller who deliberately avoids checking their own files or speaking to their property manager to avoid 'actual' knowledge of a defect.
R84.title: Ostrich Clause (No Investigation)

R85.description: This clause states that if any Due Diligence Materials (which could be thousands of pages in a data room) contain information inconsistent with the Seller's representations, the representations are 'deemed modified.' This effectively shifts the entire burden of discovery to the Buyer and allows the Seller to make false representations as long as the truth is buried somewhere in the data room.
R85.title: Knowledge Override / Anti-Sandbagging

R86.description: While it is standard to limit liability to the entity, the broad covenant that Buyer will bring 'no action of any kind' against the named individuals could potentially bar claims for fraud or intentional misrepresentation by those individuals.
R86.title: Covenant Not to Sue Individuals

R87.description: Ensure the blank space for the named individual is filled with the person most likely to have day-to-day operational knowledge of the property (e.g., the Asset Manager or Lead Portfolio Manager).
R87.title: Identify Knowledge Individual

R88.description: The 'deemed to have known' provision creates an imputed knowledge standard. It allows the Seller to escape liability for a false representation if the truth was buried anywhere in the 'Property Information' (data room, reports, etc.), even if the Buyer did not actually see it. This effectively shifts the burden of the Seller's honesty onto the Buyer's diligence team.
R88.title: Constructive Knowledge/Anti-Sandbagging Clause

R89.description: The $50,000 floor is a 'basket' that prevents the Buyer from recovering for any breaches that don't meet this high dollar amount. Depending on the purchase price, $50,000 may be too high, allowing the Seller to make multiple 'small' misrepresentations with impunity.
R89.title: High Minimum Claim Threshold (Basket)

R9.description: Request a list of all third-party leased equipment and fixtures to ensure no critical infrastructure is excluded from the sale.
R9.title: Fixture Ownership Audit

R90.description: Cross-reference the definition of 'Property Information' in Section 1. If it is defined broadly to include all documents provided by Seller, the risk in B12_R1 is significantly amplified.
R90.title: Definition of Property Information

R91.description: The cap applies not just to representations and warranties, but also to 'covenants and other obligations.' This is dangerous for a Buyer. If the Seller fails to perform a post-closing covenant (like a tax proration or a repair obligation), their liability should not be capped. Furthermore, there is no exception for fraud or intentional misrepresentation.
R91.title: Overly Broad Liability Cap

R92.description: The liability cap is currently blank. Without a negotiated amount, the Buyer's potential recovery is undefined, and the Seller will likely push for a very low percentage of the purchase price.
R92.title: Undefined Liability Cap Amount

R93.description: Verify if the Buyer's liability should also be capped here. Usually, Buyer's liability is limited to the Earnest Money Deposit as liquidated damages. Ensure this cap doesn't conflict with or expand the Buyer's liability beyond the deposit.
R93.title: Mutual Cap Applicability

R94.description: Ensure the Buyer entity is properly formed and in good standing in its home state and the state where the property is located before signing.
R94.title: Entity Authority

R95.description: Confirm that entering into this Agreement does not violate any of Buyer's existing loan documents or joint venture agreements.
R95.title: Conflict Check

R96.description: A six-month survival period is relatively short for commercial real estate. Latent issues (such as tax liabilities or undisclosed litigation) often take longer than six months to surface after the closing date.
R96.title: Short Survival Period

R97.description: The clause requires the Buyer to actually commence litigation within the Survival Period to preserve a claim. This is overly aggressive; typically, providing written notice of a claim within the period is sufficient to preserve it.
R97.title: Requirement to Commence Litigation

R98.description: Verify that Sections 7.1 and 7.2 (referenced in p_65) and Sections 7(a) and (b) (referenced later in the same paragraph) are consistent and cover all critical Seller representations. The discrepancy in numbering (7.1 vs 7(a)) suggests a potential drafting error.
R98.title: Cross-Reference Verification

R99.description: If a representation becomes untrue before closing, the Buyer's only remedy is to terminate the agreement. This prevents the Buyer from closing and seeking damages (indemnification) even if the Seller caused the breach or if the Buyer still wants the property but needs to be made whole for the diminished value.
R99.title: Sole Remedy Limitation for Rep Breaches
